column4: SW 3 tree point LN and SW 170th St. Burien WA · Burien, WA
column5: Three Tree one tank dive. Open to all divers. meetup 6:15pm, splash 7pm. Viz has been poor these few days, but I'm hoping for an improvement. Bring working primary and secondary lights. Highly recommend carpooling. You can meet at the Safeway parking lot at SW 148th St and 1st Ave South. If not and if the parking lot is full at the dive site, then park on Maplewild Ave and hump your gear in. I anticipate other divers will be there earlier, since it is a Wednesday night.

All divers welcome to dive Three Tree this Tuesday. Due to parking limitations, this dive is limited to 8 participants. Come tour the slopes of Three Tree Point North. Plenty of hiding places for various critters. Surface to 40 feet down has been thick with plankton and algae, so it's pretty much night diving below. Second light and tank light needed. Carpooling encouraged. Meet at 7:30 and splash at 8pm. We'll exit the water at dusk.

Alki Cove 2 morning dive(s) for all skill levels. Meet at 8:15am, splash at 9:00am (ebb tide). We'll see how many classes & people have descended on Cove 2 after our first dive before deciding on whether to do a second dive. Some divers will be staying within OW limits (less than 60 feet) on these dives, but everyone is welcome. If someone wants to dive deeper than 60 feet, I'd ask that you please bring/arrange for a buddy beforehand.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Two site dive. 1st site DIW, -2.4E>8:28am>2.2F. Meetup 6:45am. 2nd dive at Saltwater park. Meetup 12pm, splash (approx.) 12:45pm. 1.9F>1:33pm>-2.0E You must be AOW, comfortable in current, able to deploy SMB in mid water to do Day Island. For Saltwater park it's open to all divers. This site can have a mind of it's own, so if you are not comfortable with the above skills, probably need to wait until you are. SWP requires park pass. Can purchase pass at gate (Kiosk). Those coming to Day Island, this will be a north entrance meetup consider carpooling if possible.

3.5 flood > 10:54 AM > 5.2 ebb: Meet 9:30 AM, Splash ~10:15-10:30. Timing is critical here. It's an early dive as most people will have to leave Seattle early. Traffic should be light though. This is a smaller exchange and suitable for divers ready for the next BIG step to high current for much of the dive. Experienced, advanced current divers only! NOT FOR LEARNING CURRENT DIVING. Once you start this dive you are absolutely committed. Don't even think about it unless you are very confident of your diving skills and current experience. If you have questions contact me. I don't like surprises on this dive. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, overhead boat traffic, fishing line, and seldom has even decent viz. Buddy separation can be an ever present issue and happens easily here. It is difficult re-connect once separated, which can happen rapidly, and is not uncommon. For your risk and effort you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. It is colorful and spectacular. 150-200 yard walk to the water with a medium hill. Good parking, restroom on site. Discover Pass required. Randy 206-387-6749 cell

Saltwater State Park tides: 5.4 at 7:03am to 7.6 at 11:47am to 1.9 at 6:02pm Planned meet 8:30am, splash 9/9:15 get out 10:30, splash #2 around 11:30 to 12. A good day to dive all day here at Saltwater. This is more of a big critter site consisting of three rock reefs. There is a very long swim out to the site itself (about 300m each way) and you should be comfortable going down to 70-80 feet as the reefs don't really start till around 50 feet. Chances of seeing wolf eel, octopus, tons of rockfish - including Vermillions - and the largest lingcod this side of Edmonds. A discovery pass is required, cost 35$/year avaliable on site via automated kiosk or at the discover pass site ( http://www.discoverpass.wa.gov/ ) If you plan to dive the 2nd tank with us please be aware that the estimate for the 2nd splash is very rough as swimming speeds getting to/from the site vary considerably.

column4: 832 W Boathaven Dr, , WA · Port Angeles, WA
column5: --- Only 2 seats available --- This is a Moss Bay Dive and looking to fill the last 2 seat. Off the Dock: 7:30am 2 dives Skill Level: Advanced Divers, comfortable in current Required to Dive: Surface Marker & Dive Alert / Noise Maker Cost: $150 per person, "Payment in advance is required" Due upon sign-up. Checks payable to: NW Dive Charters Send Deposit Checks to: "seat not confirmed until payment is received" Randy Koch, Diamond Knot 11659 104th Ave NE Kirkland, WA 98034 The Diamond Knot has achieved the status of legend amongst divers in the Pacific Northwest, as one of the most difficult, yet rewarding dives in the cold waters off of Washington State. The massive 326 foot wreck lies off of tongue point in the current swept Straits of Juan de Fuca, where it sank in 1947 after colliding in the fog with the SS Fen Victory. When she went to the bottom, she carried 154,000 cases of Alaskan canned salmon with her. The cargo was then valued at over four million dollars and represented ten percent of the Alaska salmon catch that year! For divers, the nutrient rich currents can be tricky, but oh so rewarding when you time the tides and weather right and drop down the line to the Knot. Every square inch of her massive structure is covered with huge billowy white Metridium Anemones. Warbonnets and Wolf eels slither across the decks and companionways in search of their next meal. Huge schools of Black and Yellowtail rockfish duck out of the current behind bits of the wreckage, along with an occasional Canary or colorful China rockfish. The back section of the wreck is most often visited by divers and is the shallower section of the ship, which lies on its starboard side. The wheelhouse, lifeboat winches and much of the aft deck structure are still in place and are covered with colorful sponges and spectacular marine growth. The forward section of the shipwreck is rarely visited, but just as rewarding. Large wolf eels and octopus are found throughout the wreckage along with many colorful grunt sculpins and gunnels. The wreck was salvaged in 1947 for its cargo of canned salmon, using an innovative water vacuum to suck up the cans. Large holes were cut in the side of the ship to access the cargo holds, which eventually caused the middle section of the wreck to collapse. This makes navigating from the front section of the ship to the stern section a “leap of faith” across a rubble strewn field that is scattered about the bottom of the Straits of Juan de Fuca. The Diamond Knot isn’t really that deep. The port side of the hull on the aft section is only about 80’ deep, which the bottom only about 125’ deep. What makes the Diamond Knot so alluring for divers is the 60 years of growth, and the extremely challenging conditions that divers can face when diving this magnificent site. The surface conditions in the Straits are often very choppy on top of a large ocean swell coming in from the Pacific Ocean. Add to that a fickle, but strong current that frequently changes direction, and you’ll understand why the wreck is considered a very advanced dive. When you time the currents and weather just right, dropping down onto the deck of the Diamond Knot is a dream dive. There is so much color and life to see everywhere you look. The history of the salvage and the amazing hard hat divers that worked the ship pervades the ghost like appearance of the remaining structure. Leaving the ship at the end of your dive is hard to do and very sad. There is almost always some current on the wreck, and you’ll find yourself hiding out in the lee of a piece of wreckage, admiring a vase sponge or warbonnet. Suddenly, the current will swap directions and shoot you up over the hull and out into the emerald green waters of the straits. This can happen very fast and catches even the most experienced divers by surprise. I know several divers that made a free ascent in green water after being blown off of the wreck, and have then spent several hours drifting in the Straits of Juan de Fuca, waiting for the boat to pick then up. The boat often can’t see them drifting away due to the very rough surface conditions that frequent this site. Drifting in the straits all alone isn’t the best way to spend an afternoon, and even the large nine foot tall surface marker buoys can often be very hard to spot in the large swell and chop that seem to come up so quickly.

Soren Huber will be giving a presentation on the Pacific sand lance, an ecologically and economically valuable forage fish consumed by larger fish, sea birds, and mammals. We have been locating and measuring Pacific sand lance in the San Juan archipelago, looking for annual and seasonal trends and characterizing the population over time.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA

Meet up either in the free spots or, more likely if the weather is good, the pay lot here at Redondo. This is a very beginner friendly site but as this is a night dive either prior night dive experience or you should have dove Redondo before recently*. Primary and backup lights required, tank light recommended. *if any newer member hasn't done Redondo or prior night dives please let me know when signing up and we can meet early and do a daylight dive before the night dive. Frequently not much to see here during daylight hours though.

column2: Madrona Park Wall, Lake Washington, Fresh Water Dive
column5: Let's do something different: fresh water wall dive in Lake Washington. Note: this is a wall dive, the wall goes all the way down to 190 ft, so you should have good buoyancy control, you should have experience with wall dives. Also, remember that for fresh water you must reduce your weight by 5-6 lbs. Visibility may be poor, so close cooperation with your dive buddy is a must, good dive torch is necessary and tank a tank flashing light is strongly recommended. Let's meet at 10 a.m., splash at ~10:40. We can potentially do two tanks if you're interested. Access: Shore dive from the beach. Parking: Park on the north side of the park. Amenities: Bathrooms Attractions: Great Rock Formations, and good crawdad hunting. Details: Swim out past the south swim platform and drop 20', then head due west down the slope to 30' where you will hit the top of the wall. Wall drops straight to 190'. Depth 30-190 feet More information on the dive: https://www.planyourdive.com/map/sites/746/Madrona%20Park%20Wall/

Ledges seem to be between 15 ft and 80ft. There is a restroom on site. You will also find a 15 stair steps and then 125 paces down a straight hill to the cobblestone beach. column3: Deception Pass State Park, North Beach
column5: The Grand Daddy of all Washington Shore Dives, Deception Pass State Park. This site has walls full of colors that compare with any in the world. Meet time 9:45am, be ready to enter the water by 10:45am (better to wait then be late). Slack is predicted for 11:29am. State Park Discovery Pass or $10 day fee required per vehicle. ADVANCED DIVERS ONLY WITH RECENT EXPERIENCE DIVING CURRENT. Please note, advanced diver for this dive site does not simply mean Advanced Diver certification. This is one of the most challenging dives in Washington, you should have experience with high current, updrafts and downdrafts, limited visibility and excellent buoyancy control.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.14E -> 8:04am -> 1.75F Splash 7:15. Dive in hopefully mild current. This is the north entrance going north profile, the easiest day island profile on what looks to be a very mild current exchange. Con - you'll have to be a real early riser...or still up from the night before. Recommended to have some experience in current, preferably at day island. If you haven't done day island before please message me before (or at least when) signing up. Note: You may be noticing the splash time seems slightly off. This is because the current table for South Narrows Midstream changed recently, it seems to be showing slack occurring 12 minutes earlier than the 'old' tables with the known correction factors - and dives using the old tables/factors still work fine. Hence the slightly different correction.

column2: Seattle Aquarium's third Octopus Symposium & Workshop: Apr. 19, 8-5
column5: This is an "FYI" notification to Marker Buoy members who might be interested in attending. This event highlights current research about octopus species by researchers from around the world. The workshop will feature several papers and round-table discussions about octopus husbandry, biology, ecology, and behavior. Early-Bird Registration (thru March 17) is $75. The event will be at the Seattle Aquarium, April 19, 2017, 8 AM - 5 PM. More information and online registration is available on the Seattle Aquarium website, see "Aquarium Events." If you have questions about the Octopus Workshop, please call the aquarium's workshop production manager Becky Bingham at b.bingham@seattleaquarium.org or by phone at (206) 423-3119. I have attended the first two Octopus Symposium & Workshops and have found them very worthwhile. Carl Baird

The current sites we are planning to dive are...... First Dive: Long Island Wall Second Dive: To be determined Each diver who signs up should have a minimum of 50 dives and have been diving within the last 30 days. Previous cold water dives are a must. Thank you, Bruce Brown 425 334-7763 Home 425 512-7457 Cell

Dive cancelled due to wind. A discovery pass is required, cost 35$/year avaliable on site via automated kiosk or at the discover pass site (http://www.discoverpass.wa.gov/) A good site for seeing tons of rock fish, including the rarer vermillions. Generally lots of all types of fish with chances for wolf eel and octopus. I'll bring a tank for a 2nd dive as well - the currents actually get better the longer we stay on this day.
This month's guest speaker will be Pam Moriarty, who will be telling us about the how and why of low oxygen events in Hood Canal.
Casual dinner before the meeting for those who can make it. Probably 5:45 to 6 is best arrival to leave time for dinner and driving to meeting, just a few minutes away.

column4: SW 3 tree point LN and SW 170th St. Burien WA · Burien, WA
column5: ***THE DIVE DATE HAS BEEN CHANGED FROM WEDNESDAY TO THURSDAY DUE TO EXPECTED HIGH WINDS AND RAIN.***** Three Tree One Tank Night Dive. Meetup 6pm, splash 6:45pm. .8F> 7:15 slack>-.6E AOW cert. Night dive experience. Must have working Primary and secondary lights. This dive will be no guest. It would seem that the cool critters are coming out in the evening and so this is an opportunity for photographers and those divers that has never seen a Spiny Pacific Lumpsucker (Lumpy). Pretty sure the big Octo under the golf ball boat will still be there. Possible sightings would be, Gunnel's, Grunt Sculpin, Red Octo's, Wolf Eel, Opalescent Squid and eggs and Bay Pipe Fish. All of which I personally have seen at one time or another at this site. You must park your car on Maple Wilder and hump your gear from there to the water and back, unless I post differently closer to the dive day, just monitor this posting for any updates. I'd recommend carpooling. You can meet at the Safeway (1st Ave South & SW 148st) parking lot, then come in one car. *******Due to high winds expected on Wed this dive is moved to Thursday night. All times remain the same.******* ##### It is my understanding that Three Tree is now open. The limit on divers has been removed and is now open to all club members, only the no guest portion is still in place. #####

Come on down and help us plan some spring dives. Bring friends, spouses, partners or anybody who'd like to participate (the more the merrier). Bring your laptops as I have wifi and your dive planning tools. Bring something for a potluck. I'll provide a bar b que, drinks (beer, wine, coffee, & softdrinks....tea too), snacks, plates, utensils and cups. Contact me with any questions or ideas. Phone: 360 957 2249 email: jhford2@mac.com. There will be a dive prior at Sunrise Beach....its just not posted yet. The splash will be at 10:20am. I'm planning on having the party conclude by 5pm....but I can and will be flexible on this.

column2: One Tank dive before Planning party
column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Sunrise One Tank Members Only Dive. Meetup 9:15am. -2.3E> 11:18S> 2.4F. Splash at 10:20am. This is for advance divers that are comfortable in current and able to deploy SMB in mid-water. This site's current can fluctuate a lot and you need to have the experience to deal with it should it become unruly. Call me if you are unsure. GPO's and Wolf Eels are what we look for, but Warbonnets, Nudibranch and Gunnels are also found here. This is a great spot for photographers. "The Hill", It's long and arduous. Humping this sucker sometimes require dropping some of your gear and then returning to pick it up. That's up to you. I find small and very slow steps works for me. There is a Porta Potty and 2 benches, but no running water Once we have stowed our gear we will head over to Dennis and Jolee's home for the Dive Planning Party. For those that will not make the dive, but would like to come down and check out the site as well as be shore support, by all means join us. You can even haul gear. You can then come with us to the party, but if not, then just join us at the party. This is usually a very good social event and you could learn how easy it is to post dives. I estimate a 60 minute drive from south Seattle without heavy traffic. Use your best judgement.

Junkyard one tank night dive. Open to all skills levels. Must have night dive experience. 6:15pm meet up. splash @7pm, -0.4E> slack 8:15>0.5F This is a night dive with moderate current. If you have never done a night dive before, this would be the time for it, but I can only take one new diver, so it will be first one to sign up will go, any others will have to wait. You must have working primary and secondary lights. Last I heard, viz was 20ft with a lot of critters and octopus out in the open. You'll pickup the line about 50ft and head north at 1500psi go to 15-20ft and cruise the eel grass, then exist where you had entered.

column3: Ocean Quest Dive Charters - Des Moines Marina
column4: 22307 Dock Ave S. · Des Moines, WA
column5: Our two dive sites are Fox Island East Wall and Day Island Wall! After you sign up on MeetUp, go to the Ocean Quest website to reserve and pay for your spot ($90 at oceanquestdivecharters.com) That is the ONLY way to guarantee your spot on the boat. We can take up to 8 people. Please note that today's dive require divers to have strong experience in deep diving, current, good buoyancy control, be able to ascend without reference, and able to use a DSMB. To ensure that everyone can "get their money's worth" from the dive, unless you are signing up with buddy who is okay with shorter dive times, you should be able to get 60 minutes from a tank. Wow! Talk about great wall diving! Questions? Let me know!

column4: SW 3 tree point LN and SW 170th St. Burien WA · Burien, WA
column5: Three Tree 2 tank dive. All skill levels. Meetup 7:30, splash @ 8am. Second dive approximately 10:15am. This site is still officially closed, but I've got the key. There is no parking available right now. You must park out on Maplewild Ave. SW and lug your gear in. This dive will be limited to 8 club members only. Maybe afterwards we can do a Pho soup lunch

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Edit: Forgot to add, open to almost* all skill levels, I just ask you either have dove Redondo before or have done a night dive before, either works. Also remember to bring a primary and backup light! Redondo may be a rather boring site by day but at night it can be teeming with life. Recently there have been lots of octopus and horn shrimp (think armored and spiked unicorn shrimp) and moderate amounts of squid seen here shortly after sunset. With sunset at 7:18pm we'll meet at 7 and splash right at/after sunset! Hope to see you here.
Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda, hopefully this week, please let me know if you'd like something added.

column4: 28201 Redondo Beach Dr S · Des Moines, WA
column5: Redondo one tank dive for all divers. Meetup 9:45am, Splash at 10:45 on the flood. Slack 11:17. Good opportunity for new divers to get a dive under your belt. Expect dive shops and divers to be there. Use pay parking. It'll be simpler than looking for a free spot.
With no signups as of 8pm, dive cancelled. Will try again next week.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Day Island Wall 9:30am meetup, 10:30am splash with Slack 11:27. Must have current experience and skilled in deploying SMB in mid water. Come out and hand feed the wolf eels, bring frozen Sardines in a non clear bag to hold them in during the dive. Take photos of them swimming in and around you. Find Big GPO's either in their den or out in the open. Nudibranchs also found. Recommend you bring a plastic troll in case mother nature decides to mess with us during our return to shore. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal.

column2: You don't want to miss this southern night dive
column5: How many of you have done Saltwater State Park? Quite a few of you, yeah but at NIGHT? Rhoda Green has made it possible (Permit) to do night dives at SW Park. On Feb 18th will be the first of possibly many more. Meetup is 4pm with a 5:00pm Splash. -3.0E to 1.4F at the North Narrows station. slack at 5:41pm. Sunset is 5:34pm. We may get lucky and get a slight push coming in during the flood This is an all divers dive who have night dive experience and good navigational skills. If your navigation is in need of a refresher, then I highly recommend you take Bob Bailey's workshop on Jan 29th or the second one if the first one is full. See club calendar for details. Very long swim out. Up to 175 - 200 yards surface swim. There are 3 rock piles running in a east/west direction and ranging from 55ft to 85ft deep. The southern most is normally called the 1st rock pile. You can use the yellow buoy as a guide to the pile, but drop about 50 yards short of it to find the beginning of the pile. The 2nd or middle rock pile (I believe it's the largest one) is approximately 60-70ft north of #1 pile and it is the same for #3 from #2 pile. For a more shallow dive checkout the remnants of the old barge skeletal remains and tire field north of it. The barge is in 40-50ft of water. At the north end of the barge you'll find a large tire with a one inch rope tied to it. This will take you on approximately a 350 degree heading through the tire field. To end your dive just back track. What will you find? Ling Cods, GPO's, a large variety of Rockfish including Vermilian's. Sanddab's, Nudibranch, Wolf Eels, Greenlings, Sculpins and maybe, just maybe a six gill shark and who knows what else since no one could dive the park at night. Bring your compass, working primary and secondary lights. I also recommend tank light. Don't forget your camera. The restroom will be open, but the showers are off. You will be required to have a park pass, which can be purchased from the machine at the guard house. Randy Williams will be providing colored navigational lights should you surface swim in.

column2: Hornby Island Adventure: Dive with Sea Lions and More!
column4: South Hornby Island · Hornby Island, BC
column5: Diving with Sea Lions is an amazing and memorable experience... something every PNW diver should experience. The Sea Lions at this location are curious about divers and jump off their island to check you out. You can stay back and just watch these agile underwater acrobats play with other divers or jump in and get highly 'interactive'. There are great 'non-Sea Lion' dive site where you will see many creatures that are rare here in Puget Sound. You can anticipate visibility that significantly exceeds what we have locally. Above water there is are possibilities to explore local cultural sites such as a re-discovered clam garden and a local mead winery. Our itinerary of dives and after dive activities will be chosen by the divers that sign up for this adventure. In addition to Marker Buoy club members, we will be joined by Joe Gaydos, a marine mammal veterinary and Director of the Sea Doc Society. Joe will be available as a naturalist during the dives and give us a presentation on Stellar Sea Lions one evening. Hornby Island Diving is a top notch dive operation that provides simple but very comfortable accommodations and excellent meals. Their package includes: • 4 nights accommodation -­‐ Friday, Saturday, Sunday, Monday nights • All meals during your stay – dinner Friday through breakfast Tuesday • 6 boat dives, plus unlimited shore diving • Air fills, tanks and weights Cost is $916 (Canadian) plus taxes. A deposit of US$250 will hold your spot. It is payable to me via Paypal at doug.coutts@salishseadiving.com (We will settle up in February based on US/CDN currency exchange rate at that.) This opportunity is limited to 10 divers.

column5: I'm on the mailing list for project updates. There is an open house to view updated design plans for the new Mukilteo ferry terminal and learn about upcoming construction activity. I can' make it but I thought others might be interested. >

column2: Help me christen my new dry suit
column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: My new dry suit arrived and I'm ready to test it out. But... I need dive buddies. A dive here seems like just the thing to get it broken in. Splash at 11:00AM.
Featured speakers will be Rick Stratton and Jim Trask, talking about the Washington Scuba Alliance and the Dive Expo 2017.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: Let's do a night dive at Edmonds Underwater Park. Slack is sometime around 8pm. So let's meet at 6:45pm and splash around 7:30pm. All skill levels with night diving experience are welcome. Don't forget your primary and secondary lights. A tank light or a strobe would also be helpful.

column4: 2706 S 301st St. · Federal Way, WA 98003, WA
column5: Workshop discussion at my house with a dive at Redondo to practice skills. Bring pencil and paper and your compass and gauges, plus all of your dive gear.

Keystone 2 tank dive. Must be comfortable in current. Meetup 10:45am, splash 11:50am, slack 12:18. Second dive is expected to be milder then the first dive and can be done anytime after surface interval. Huge variety of sealife to enjoy and photograph. Mukilteo Ferry leaves every half hour starting at 6am. Once at Clinton dock it's about half hour to dive site. You can catch the 9 9:30 or 10am ferry. Vehicles under 14ft is $6.85 each way. Passenger $4.90, ages over 65 is $2.45, YES!!! Bring a lunch snack/drinks or dine at the café (good chili and clam chowder). Also recommend bring warm water to soak your hood and glove between dives. State Park pass require and available for purchase at the parking lot for $10 day pass or $30 for annual pass. Restroom and showers available

column4: Ocean Quest Dive Charters - Des Moines Marina
column5: Our two sites are Alki Fishing Reef followed by Blake Island Reef. After you sign up on MeetUp, go to the Ocean Quest website to reserve and pay for your spot ($90 at oceanquestdivecharters.com) That is the ONLY way to guarantee your spot on the boat. We can take up to 8 people. Please note that both sites require divers to have experience in current, good buoyancy control, be able to ascend without reference, and able to use a DSMB. To ensure that everyone can "get their money's worth" from the dive, unless you are signing up with buddy who is okay with shorter dive times, you should be able to get 60 minutes from a tank. Alki Fishing Reef is an artificial series of reefs created to attract fish and other marine life. The reef consists of numerous piles of concrete and rock debris that provide great structure for marine habitat. These reefs are set in patterns parallel to shore with depths between 40′ to 80′ depending on the height of the tide and the location of which reef the diver chooses to explore. Blake Island Reef also consists of man made structures (concrete slabs, boxes, and other debris) which encourage the attraction of marine life. These were barged in and deposited on a sandy/silt sea floor ranging in depths of 40′ to 100′ plus. The structures generally run parallel to the shore of Blake Island and are spread over a considerable distance which can accommodate multiple divers and boats. Questions? Let me know! These sites are both good for observing fish life, photography and even DPVs!

column2: Night Dive at Alki Beach Cove 2
column5: Night dive at Alki Beach Cove 2 for all level. Meet up time at 6:30 PM and splash at 7 PM. Please bring working primary and second dive light. Highly recommend tank light.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Redondo Beach (https://maps.google.com/maps?q=Redondo%20Beach%20Dr.%20S.%20%20%26amp%3B%20%20Redondo%20Way%20S.%2C%20Federal%20Way%2C%20WA) dive for all divers. 7 pm meetup with 7:30 pm. Have working primary and second lite. highly recommend tank light. This is a great site for variety. Bring your camera for sure.

column2: South Sound Current Dive - Open again
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 3.3 Ebb > 1:26 PM slack > 3.4 Flood - South Narrows substation Meetup 11:30 AM, splash ~ 12:30 PM We haven't done anything 'stout' for awhile. This is a North entrance, north and back dive. Large Exchange. Suitable for experienced DIW divers only. It will be a current dive. You will be in current for a good portion of the dive. I probably won't be too bad, but I can't guarantee that. Strong legs are good, a calm 'head' is more important. Bring your trowel. If you've never been here don't bother unless you talk to me personally. Day Island is a serious shore dive and needs to be treated as such. No rescue, no boat pickup. "There is no try, you do or you don't do." [Yoda] Swim out about 100 yards over a slowly sloping gravel bottom to a small wall. On an ebb (going north) the wall stays small and is composed of small to large ledges. Lots of dens for wolf eels and GPO. There should be a current switch ~30" into the dive to bring you back near the entrance. You can bail to shore anywhere along this wall if needed. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda, hopefully this week, please let me know if you'd like something added. Blue Jeans Meeting Link: https://bluejeans.com/759267734/
Meet at Hoodsport N Dive at 9 AM. Plan for two dives. Potluck surface interval ... bring something to share.

1.8F >10:55AM > 1.3E - Fidalgo Head-Burrows Island between 1.1F > 11:27AM > 2.6E - Rosario Strait Skyline dive. Meetup 10am, Splash 10:30pm. Only 30" prep time. This is the 2nd of an experiment to see how Skyline fares as a dive in the winter months. Similar profile to Dec. 10 and I may make adjustments depending on how that goes. In the past I've just quit going there from fall when the rains hit until late spring when the weather improves. Potential issues are a decrease in visibility, and fresh water mixed in causing the invertebrate 'garden' to be pulled in and less colorful. This is what we are going to find out. If the viz is acceptable it's still a pretty dive. Advanced dive with a long 200 yard swim , in current, with current possible the whole dive. Potential poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not) puts some challenge in keep buddy pairs intact. When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. Divers should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be a big issue, less so in the winter months. I strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. No facilities on site -stop in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park before coming over. Debriefing in Anacortes after the dive; Brown Lantern, Rockfish, or the Bowling Alley depending on how busy things are. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell
Soren Huber will be telling us about her marine biology work up at the UW research lab in Friday Harbor

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Day Island wall dive. -2.3E to 2.4F. Slack 11:40am, splash 10:40am. meetup 10am. Must be Advanced diver that's comfortable in current and able to deploy SMB. We will be going in at the north entrance floating north and back again. Expect a 100 yard swim to wall at about 45-50ft. Current should switch after 30'. This is a residential neighborhood, so carpool if possible.

Due to winter conditions, I would like you to dived at this site before. Exchange looks decent for a dive on Dec 27 at 10:45 am slack (-1.8 kt ebb going to a 0.6kt Flood). With Winter in full swing, this dive will be chilly but vis might be good. So... Meet at Keystone Jetty at 9:30am for a 10:15am splash. Slack is at 10:43am. 8:30am ferry (20 minute ride) out of Mukilteo to Clinton should give enough time to suit up if you're reasonably efficient at and are not starting by the pilings. Drive time to Jetty from Clinton, WA, is about 30 minutes. If you want a more leisurely start, consider going to Keystone Cafe for a cup of tea and second breakfast where you can stay warm until the rest of us arrive. Possible lunch at Cozy's Roadhouse near the Clinton ferry terminal.

Junkyard night dive for all skill levels. Meetup 6:30pm with a quick gear up and splash at 7pm. Slack is at 6:37pm, which isn't a problem with current only .02kts on the flood. Bring working primary and secondary lights. Highly recommend tank light. Dive is between 50-60ft usually your following a line, that may or may not be covered over with sand. Artificial reefs along the line route. Opalescent Squid have be laying eggs in the area and you may get a chance to watch them going through the process. Always a good place to take pictures.

column2: Last minute: Weds Daytime North of Seattle Dive
column5: If you have time during the day, let's meet to take advantage of good weather and favorable tides/currents: High Slack ~11am. Mukilteo T-dock. Meet at ~ 9:30 for ~10:30 splash) Txt me or call 425.273.0801 with ?'s etc

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Night Dive. Be sure to bring a backup and a tank light. Must have dove this site in the daylight before doing a night dive here. Sunset at 4:20 pm. Meet time should give us time to get ready in the daylight before splashing. Fairly high tide even at the preceding low tide. Tide will be over 8 ft any time from 4:00pm. on to max flood tide of 9.7 ft at 6:18 pm. This is normally a great photographers dive. Many of us make it a fairly shallow dive to look for lumpsuckers, pipefish, snailfish, stubbysquid, red octos and more. But that's up to you.
Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda, hopefully this week, please let me know if you'd like something added.

Let's do a lazy Sunday afternoon dive at Edmonds Underwater Park. We will meet up at 12:15pm for a 1:15pm splash. Slack is around 2:10pm, but I am planning for an early splash to allow for buddy checks and the surface swim. This dive is for all skill levels as current will not be a problem (0.1 flood to a -0.8 ebb). This dive will also be shallow as it usually does not get any deeper than 40ft at this dive site. Finally, this is not a night dive. There is lots to see at this dive site. There are many sunken structures and sunken boats that support sea life. You can dive this site often and there is always something new to see.

Potential issues are a decrease in visibility, and fresh water mixed in causing the invertebrate 'garden' to be pulled in and less colorful. This is what we are going to find out. Advanced dive with a long 200 yard swim , in current, with current possible the whole dive. Potential poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not) puts some challenge in keep buddy pairs intact. When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. Divers should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be a big issue, less so in the winter months. I strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. No facilities on site -stop in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park before coming over. Debriefing in Anacortes after the dive; Brown Lantern, Rockfish, or the Bowling Alley depending on how busy things are. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column2: Early southern Wall and Drift dive
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Day Island dive for advanced divers comfortable in current. This is a north entry drifting north. Expect a 100yd swim to the wall. We will have a -2.1 ebb to 3.5 flood with slack at 8:02am. Splash is 7:00am with meetup at 6:30am. Should be a fairly relaxed dive, but you should know how to deploy your SMB, just in case. Bring Sardines and feed the wolf eel if you like or just photograph others doing it. Because of the early hour, I would like to keep the noise at a minimum, so please have your gear assembled prior to arrival.

column2: Happy ALL of the Holidays Party!!
column5: It's the 2016 MBDC "Happy ALL of the Holidays" party! Rather than a club meeting , every December, MBDC gathers to enjoy some delicious food, hang out with club buddies both new and old and take part in a holiday gift exchange. So: Bring something to share at the potluck dinner buffet. Plates, etc provided. Bring drinks. Cups and ice provided. Bring a gift to exchange in the traditional MBDC holiday gift exchange. Recommended: a scuba, underwater or marine life theme, $25.00 cost limit. Feel free to bring your spouse, your kids, you kid's spouse, your spouse's kids -- the whole family is welcome. More details to follow!

column2: Meeting Friends of Saltwater State Park
column5: Interested in Saltwater State Park? Help support watershed/marine stewardship and amenities for park patrons.

Let's Dive the Mukilteo Clay Wall now that the farmer's market is not blocking the parking lot. Meet up at 7:45 am for an 8:45am Splash. I know this is early, but the next slack would make this a night dive. All Skill Levels are welcome as current should not be a big issue. It is going from a 0.2 flood to a -0.4 ebb. Slack is at 9:14am. This is a clay wall abundant with various sea life. We will move slowly along the wall looking in the nooks and crannies to see what we can find. How To Find Us: Travel towards the Mukilteo Ferry, but pass the toll booth. Make a left at the stop sign (Ivar's will be on the corner on your right). Take your very next left. There will be a large parking lot on your right, pass this and keep going until you get to the turn around. Park somewhere here as this is close to where we enter the water.

column4: 2706 S 301st St. · Federal Way, WA 98003, WA
column5: Come on down and help us plan some winter dives. Bring friends, spouses, partners, or anybody who'd like to participate. Bring your laptops (I have wi fi) and dive planning tools. And bring something for a potluck. I'll provide drinks and snacks, as well as plates, utensils and cups. Contact me with questions or ideas. Phone - 425-478-3781 Email - baileyrj@comcast.net

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Day Island North, 2.33 Ebb > 2:52 pm > 2.18 Flood Narrows South Midstream. Meet at 12:45 splash at 1:50. This is the most mild of Day Island exchanges profiles on a rather mild exchange but there is still potential for current and no boat to pick you up. As this is my first time leading day island I would ask you have prior experience at Day Island but not necessarily have mastered it. After the dive I plan to head to Bob Bailey's dive planning party and would encourage anybody else who attends to go as well - if possible. Hope to see you there! As always carpooling recommended if possible. I'll be coming from the Federal Way area and can take one other person w/ gear if anybody is interested.

Let's dive at Edmonds Underwater Park. All skills are welcome. I'll take an underwater map of the park with me so we can practice navigation and get more familiar with the park. Predicted slack current is at 3:13pm so let's meet at 2:00pm, splash at 2:40pm (maybe a bit earlier in case we decide to do a bit of current swim).

Let's dive at Edmonds Underwater Park. All skills are welcome. I'll take an underwater map of the park with me so we can practice navigation and get more familiar with the park. Predicted slack current is at 2:43pm so let's meet at 1:15pm, splash at 2:15pm (maybe a bit earlier in case we decide to do a bit of current swim).

A one tank dive at Saltwater State Park starting at 9am. This dive site is a fairly long walk or swim, looks to be a swim on this day. We'll be looking at a 6 foot tidal swing from 6.2 at 9:42am to a 11.2 at 2:58pm which should be favorable conditions for diving this site. Plan to splash around 9:45 to 10:00. There is some potential for current at this site and it is a very long swim, nearly 300m each way, so make sure you are up getting a little cardio on the day after Thanksgiving! Note that a discover pass is required to park here, it can be purchased beforehand or at the gate from an automated kiosk.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Redondo one tank nite dive. 7pm meetup with an 7:30pm splash. Slack at 8:01 going into a flood. All skill levels with night diving experience. Have working Primary and Secondary light. This means your suppose to test them before coming. Highly recommend a tank light. Have your tank preassembled before you arrive. This will allow for a quick gearing up or just come earlier. I figure there will be less highway traffic and give those up north ample time to Redondo. Viz has been very good at all dive locations and I don't anticipate any change to that. Bob Bailey has been seeing Lumpsuckers on the southern side of the fishing pier and some of you photographers may want to take advantage of that. There has also been a great variety of critters to see for all to enjoy.

column2: North Sound Early Evening Night Dive
column5: Admiralty Inlet 2.41 Ebb > 5:20pm adjusted Slack > 0.58 Flood. Meet up at 4pm with a 5pm Splash. This should be an easy dive for all skill levels with night dive experience or experience with the EUP during the day. This is a night dive as sunset is at 4:28pm. You will need a working primary and secondary light and a tank light is recommended. Since we will probably getting out of the water around 6pm, we can walk up main street and get dinner at a local restaurant, if anybody is interested.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.9 Ebb > 3:53 PM slack > 2.8 Flood - South Narrows substation Meetup 1:45 PM, splash ~ 2:45 PM This is a North entrance, north and back dive. This is a 'borderline exchange'. Completely suitable for experienced DIW divers. For those who have never been there......."are you rough enough, are you tough enough"? It will be a current dive. You will be in current for a good portion of the dive. I probably won't be too bad, but I can't guarantee that. Strong legs are good, a calm 'head' is more important. The north drift is shallower and stays closer to shore. This is an advantage for bailing out. Day Island is a serious shore dive and needs to be treated as such. No rescue, no boat pickup. "There is no try, you do or you don't do." [Yoda] Swim out about 100 yards over a slowly sloping gravel bottom to a small wall. On an ebb (going north) the wall stays small and is composed of small to large ledges. Lots of dens for wolf eels and GPO. There should be a current switch ~30" into the dive to bring you back near the entrance. You can bail to shore anywhere along this wall if needed. If you are not sure if this is a dive for you, email or call me. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: 28201 Redondo Beach Dr S · Des Moines, WA
column5: One tank Redondo dive. Looking to go somewhat deep and investigate a boat past the hobby-horse. Splash at 11:15 or so.
Matthew Pearson

column2: Mid-week Two-tank Boat Dive on Ocean Quest
column3: Ocean Quest Dive Charters - Des Moines Marina
column4: 22307 Dock Ave S. · Des Moines, WA
column5: November skies might be cloudy, but the water clears up at this time of year. Once you sign up on Meet Up, go to the Ocean Quest Dive Charter website reservation calendar to reserve and pay for your spot. We can go with as few as 5 divers and a max of 8 divers. The cost is $90 for two dives. Dive sites are Point Defiance Wall and Dalco Wall. From the Ocean Quest website - description of the sites and recommended diver skill levels are as follow: Point Defiance Wall: This gentle sloping wall consists of sandstone and rock structures beginning at 20′ and generally running down to 70-100′ but most divers choose to stay 70′ or more shallow. Clams that bore horizontal into the wall have made thousands of holes that have become homes for a great deal of marine life. Although this area has octopus and larger fish, most divers admire it for the structure it provides. All skill levels. Dalco Wall: This is a true wall dive. Most often we anchor in approximately 30′ of water and direct the divers out to approximately 40-60′ depth where the wall begins. This is where the sea floor is like walking to the edge of the Space Needle and provides a vertical drop down to 130-160′ before the sea floor becomes visible again. Current swept most of the time, this wall provides a great deal of food for small clinging marine life as well as cut back holes for wolf eel and octopus. The wall itself is often covered with shrimp so thick at times you cannot see the wall itself. *We encourage and strongly recommend that divers be advanced level or higher for this dive due to current and depth. We recommend that all divers carry Surface Marker Buoys (SMB) in case you need to make a mid water ascent.
Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda, hopefully this week, please let me know if you'd like something added.

Edmonds Underwater Park one tank dive. All levels are welcome. I have a map we can take underwater and practice navigation and get more familiar with EUP. Slack is at 3pm so let's plan splash for 2:45pm.
stephen kalilimoku

Limit - 25 divers. This is about all the venue will hold. We live in an area rich with tides and the resulting currents. Either you dive non-current intensive sites, throw yourself on the mercy and knowledge of others to figure them out, or you learn how to calculate when it's safe to dive sites impacted by current. A smart diver learns how to figure the currents. You are the one out there. What you will need: • Some kind of CURRENT reference/chart. This can be computer based (laptop), tablet, phone, or printed (I think you can still get these in marine stores). A tide only reference will not be helpful. Tides create the currents, but we need the current info to work with. Doug Miller has posted some good references (http://www.meetup.com/Marker-Buoy-Dive-Club/pages/6446802/Scuba-related_links/) in Meetup. • Some paper and writing utensil to calculate with. Strongly suggested: Northwest Shore Dives, 3rd Ed. Stephen Fischnaller. (https://www.amazon.com/Northwest-Shore-Dives-Stephen-Fischnaller/dp/0961710624/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1477417280&sr=8-1-fkmr0&keywords=Northwest+Shore+Dives%2C+3rd+Ed.+Stephen+Fishnaller.)Read the chapter in the beginning, [Currents, Current Tables, and Tide Tables]. If you are familiar with that chapter you will get a lot more out of this class. The book is no longer in print, but available from Amazon, possibly used book stores, or other agencies (2nd Ed. is OK if you can't get 3rd Ed.). NWSD lists dozens of shore dives in the NW along with critical current correction factors. The correction factors are key to knowing when is the appropriate TIME to dive a site. Local knowledge and experience are key to knowing HOW LARGE an exchange is to safely dive the site, along with unique features and characteristics of a dive site. This information is also in NWSD. Doug Coutts is loaning us his office in the University Heights Bldg. at 50th and University Way in the U. District. I think we'll have wifi (will confirm), and I'll be bringing the club projector. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Night dive at Redondo searching for squid, skate, and lump suckers. Bring 2 lights and a recommended tank light. Parking may be an issue with people fishing for squid.

Junkyard one tank night dive. Meetup 6:30pm, Splash 7:10pm on the flood. Current -.1 kts at splash time. All skills level with night dive experience. Have working Primary and Secondary lights, recommend tank light also. Dive site has a line at 50ft, that's travelling N-S. It's sometime buried in the sand, but if you stay around 50ft, you'll run into it off and on. Site offers a good mix of critters, both at depth and in the shallow eel grass. The idea is to move slowly. I usually find small Octo's in the open as well as Stubby squids.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Currents this day are similar to what we experienced (or didn't!) on October 23rd: Then, we dove between a flood of 3.9 and an ebb of 2.2. On the 6th, the flood is 3.7 and the ebb is 1.7. I'm thinking of trying a slightly earlier splash time: around 9:40 AM with a predicted slack of 10:23 AM. Meet at 8:30 AM. Please remember! This Sunday is the start of Standard Time, so set your clocks one hour behind ("Fall back"). As always, Sunrise is a great wall/slope/boulder field with lots of life. Octopus, wolf eels, grunt sculpins, rockfish, red Irish lords, swarms of surf perch, lots of nudibranchs, swimming scallops, etc. Yes, there is a long walk back to the parking lot after the dive, but it's worth it! Facilities include a picnic table and a porta-potty. After the dive we usually meet at Spiro's.

Today's good exchange (-1.8 ebb to a 1.6 flood) at a decent time makes for a possible to dive at the seldom listed Fox Island Bridge. Shallow water dive (probably less than 30 ft depth) features an abundance of life around and between the pilings with dens between the boulders leading up to the bridge. Meet at 2:45pm for a 3:15 splash. Predicted slack is around 3:50 pm at this time. We'll attempt to ride whatever's left of the current out through the pilings. Once the tide turns we'll promptly turn back, unless you have a scooter.

2.0 ebb > 5 PM > 1.9 flood - South Narrows Advanced current dive Change of plans. New meet time 2:45 Splash ~ 3:45. Advanced current dive with a LONG swim. Newer DIW divers have dropped out. South entrance > drift to the north entrance, or out and back to the south entrance. Buddy preference or situational decision based on current. You have to know enough about this dive to be able to make this decision. Divers still wishing to do the N. entrance are welcome to do so. It should be a very benign dive allowing you to go south if you want and roam as you please. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell
Michael Werner, producer of the PBS documentary on sixgill sharks, will be coming to discuss with us the making of that TV show.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 3.0Ebb > 12:45 PM > 3.4Flood - South Narrows Meetup 10:45 AM, splash ~ 11:45 AM Conflict with Pumpkin Carve on Sat. 29th so moving to Sunday. This is a North entrance, north and back dive. Higher current exchange. Only suitable for divers already experiences with Day Island. If you haven't been there do not come unless you talk to me first. The north drift is shallower and stays closer to shore. Day Island is a serious shore dive and needs to be treated as such. No rescue, no boat pickup. There is no try, you do or you don't do. Swim out about 100 yards over a slowly sloping gravel bottom to a small wall. On an ebb (going north) the wall stays small and is composed of small to large ledges. Lots of dens for wolf eels and GPO. There should be a current switch ~30" into the dive to bring you back near the entrance. You can bail to shore anywhere along this wall if needed. If you are not sure if this is a dive for you, email or call me. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

It's pumpkin carving, underwater! Of course, we follow the Helsinki Protocol from the International Underwater Pumpkin Carving Association. As I am sure you recall, the Helsinki Protocol stipulates two conditions for competition; that the pumpkin (or gourd) cannot be punctured prior to submersion and a minimum carving depth of 10 feet. Divers carve in teams (dive buddies, ya know...) and supply their own pumpkins and carving implements. Carving implements should be blunt tipped for safety. All additional items used to decorate the submitted carved pumpkin need to be taken from the marine environment. No life animal life can be used as pumpkin accessories and/or decoration As tradition dictates, we will team up with the Boeing Seahorses, Moss Bay, Emerald Sea and the UW Underdawgs. A great time is sure to be had by all. More details to follow.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Redondo one tank nite dive. 7pm meetup 7:30 splash. Bring working Primary and Secondary lights. Recommend tank light.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: For those who would rather head south, I'd like to host a Sunrise dive on this Sunday. Yes, there's the infamous long, uphill slog with your gear back to your car, and a fairly long walk along the shore to where we start the dive, but I think the wall with all its critters and wolf eels and octopuses is well worth it. Lots of rockfish, sculpins, nudibranchs, and swimming scallops. Great topography as well. This is a dive that's probably not ideal for beginners. Most of the time, currents cooperate. But sometimes, they just don't die down and we have to deal with current for the whole dive. Meet time is around 11:15 AM for a splash around 12:30. We'll be shooting for a minimum current before ebb (estimated slack time of 1:02 PM). There's not much in the way of facilities at Sunrise other than one picnic bench and a porta potty. Afterwards, we usually like to meet at Spiro's in Gig Harbor for great pizza (assuming the ovens are working this time!)

2.6F > 12:44PM > 0.7E - Fidalgo Head-Burrows Island between 1.6F > 1:16PM > 1.4E - Rosario Strait Skyline dive. Meetup 11:15pm, Splash 12:15pm. Advanced dive with a long 200 yard swim , in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not) puts some challenge in keep buddy pairs intact. When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. Divers should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be a big issue. I strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park before coming over. Debriefing in Anacortes after the dive; Brown Lantern, Rockfish, or the Bowling Alley depending on how busy things are. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: Ocean Quest Dive Charters - Des Moines Marina
column5: 2 tank Ocean Quest boat dive. All ability levels ok. Please go to Ocean Quest and pay to hold your place. http://oceanquestdivecharters.com/ We have 2 Canadians also going (not with Marker Buoy) so we only have 6 slots. The plan is Sunrise and Z Reef....a rare combination! (thus the early meet up time!). Plan to load by 8am as we will depart promptly at 8:30am.

column2: Down South One Tank Nite dive
column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Redondo night Dive for all skill levels with night dive experience. Bring working Primary and secondary light. Highly recommend tank light. 7pm meetup with a 7:45ish splash. We will be going in on the flood with a 9:48pm slack. Site isn't difficult. It has a line that runs down to the Carousel Boat at 85ft. Off of that same line at 70ft going north is the black Pearl and a smaller line off of that running to an artificial reef. There is another line around 50ft that would lead you through a number of artificial piles. Once you hit 1500psi head into the shallows. If you go to 40ft, while heading south there is a small boat and large pipe that may have Octo's and grunt sculpins.

column4: Nearest address: 8343 S Franklin Rd, Clinton, WA 98236 · Clinton, WA

Be sure to have a Discover Pass & cash to reimburse me for the $25.00 beach access/ special parking permit, which I'll arrange beforehand... Skill Level; New diver to very advanced available here...

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 1.6 ebb > 6:22 PM slack > 1.7 flood - ~5:20 splash, 4:30 meet. Very small exchange going north. Suitable for a first current experience. Even though this is an easy day on an easy profile it should not be considered an easy dive. You still have a fair amount of swimming. There is no rescue. For this exchange expect to swim ~150 yards underwater and drop onto the Day Island wall at 45' going north. There is less of a wall this direction, more big to huge shelf. Depth will be in the 45'- 60. As with any shore based current dive there is no boat to bail you out if things don't go according to plan. You should feel confident of your dive skills and be looking to take a step up before considering this dive. If you aren't sure, call me to discuss it before showing up. This is a quiet residential neighborhood with on street parking and no facilities. Use bathroom facilities at Titlow nearby (water play area), or one of the establishments up on the hill. Carpooling is highly encouraged to limit impact on the neighborhood. This is a small exchange so other divers could well be present. Debrief at Steamers or Boathouse 19 in the marina. Fritz 206-525-0736 home (screening message on) 206-370-4720 cell

CHANGED DIVE PLAN: YIKES! NOAA predicts south winds to 25 kt tomorrow by noon... So Keystone will NOT be dive-able! Options: Listed in Order of MY preference; 1) KVI Beach on Vashon I. this is a very pretty artificial reef accessible via a long walk over flat terrain... Lots of good pubs on Vashon too, for the post dive de-brief... 2) Rockaway Beach Park on Bainbridge I... Also sheltered pretty well from a south wind with 3 interesting finger reefs projecting east toward Blakeley Rks... 3) Wautaugah SP on Rich Passage; Nice geology & critters; VERY likely GPO & Wolfies may be seen... I have not dived this from shore, so I do not know how accessible the beach is from the parking area... 4 )Agate Pass Drift dive...If you vote for this one, be sure to check this site again around 10:00 tonight... I'll post more data as I discover it... I will share that the quantity of marine life here has steadily declined since I first dove here in 1969... So Dive buddies, PLEASE view this posting & respond tonight by 8:00- 8:30... I won't pursue the 4th option unless there's interest

column2: 16th Annual Seattle Aquarium Octopus Census: Oct 8-16
column5: Please set up your own Meetup, or simply count GPO on any Meetup you are going to during the 8-16 period. Help collect data on a Puget Sound icon! If you go diving anytime during October 8–16, we’d like to know whether or not you see any giant Pacific octopuses. Collect your data at these suggested sites: Sund Rock, Octopus Hole, Flagpole, Jorsted Creek, Black Point, Point Whitney, Pulali Point, Alki Pipeline, Alki Junkyard, Alki Cove 2, Elliott Bay Marina, Harper's Ferry, Waterman's Wall, Rich Passage, Boeing Creek Reef, Edmonds Underwater Park, Fox Island, Z's Reef, Day Island, Titlow Beach, Point Defiance, Sunrise, Les Davis, Tramp Harbor, Three Tree Point North, Redondo, Mukilteo State Park, Langley Tire Reef, Possession Point, Alaskan Reef Wreck, Public Dock (Port Townsend), Hudson Point and Keystone. Data to collect: Date of dive Depth Den type General size Location of dive site Bottom substrate How many giant Pacific octopuses were seen at a single dive site during each dive. (How to tell the difference between a giant Pactific octopus and a Pacific red octopus ) (http://www.seattleaquarium.org/octopus/giant-vs-red) Is the octopus on eggs The data form will be made available October 8-31. (http://www.seattleaquarium.org/image/2011--events/Dive-sites.jpg)

Junkyard one tank nite dive. All skill levels. There is a 3 foot exchange with a .1kt on the flood to a .2kt ebb, slack is at 5:42 pm. Tide and current will not be an issue. Meetup 6:15pm splash 6:45pm. Bring working Primary and secondary lights. Recommend tank light. A good dive plan would be to swim out to the buoy and drop, it'll be about 50ft. Swim north and inspect all the artificial reefs long the way. Once at 1500psi go to 15-20ft (where the eel grass is) for your safety stop while heading south, usually you'll get a mild push back to the exit. There is always young Octo's to be found as well as stubby squid. Other critters of interest are Painted Greenling (possibly eggs too), Grunt sculpins, water spiders, gunnels, Skates, Opalescent squid, Sea Pens and Nudibranch. The line is at 50ft, but diving between 40 and 70ft can yield all kinds of critters. Parking can be a problem depending on weather.
Change in speaker ... Ed McNichol is going back out on assignment. Our new speaker will be Nirupam Nigam, who will be telling us about his recent work in Alaska for the Dept. of Fisheries.

A permit is required for the Group which costs $25.00. I'll take care of that and get reimbursement from those attending. Discover Pass required for vehicles. Carpooling recommended. Shore dive to a large clay wall with multiple fingers. This dive is suitable for intermediate to advanced divers. Some surface current may be present but normally none at depth. Good buoyancy control necessary as the wall goes very deep. This is a great scooter dive. -2.6 ebb slack 12:59 SBF + 1.7 flood

column2: San Juan Long Island Wall Dive
column5: San Juan Boat dive! Date: Saturday October 1st. The price is $90 per person and must be paid in advance. The plan is to meet at the boat at 8:00 AM so we can load all the gear and leave by 8:30 AM. Expect to return about 4:00 PM. We are planning to dive...... LONG ISLAND WALL and 2nd dive will be determined based on weather. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com (http://www.lujacsquest.com/) for more information and directions to the boat. Requirements: Each diver must have been diving within the last 60 days and have cold water diving experience. You will need all dive equipment, which includes 2-tanks, a BC, safe second, dive computer, safety sausage & whistle. We recommend this charter for experienced divers only, due to currents and live boat operations. Each diver must have been diving within the last 30 days and have Advanced Certification with a minimum of 50 logged dives. Thanks, Bruce Brown 425 512-7457 Cell 425 334-7763 Home

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: A nice morning splash for all skill levels. This is a nice place to see octopus as well as sometimes squid and various nudibranchs. Plenty of parking along the road (free) or in the paid lot (just a few dollars, includes a rinse station right next to the pay booth). Hope to see you there! *This is likely to be the only friday morning splash for a month (at least lead by me) as I'll be out of town much of October.*
Mukilteo T-Dock

The town and area becomes a zoo. 2.0 Flood > 2:53 > 0.6 Ebb Fidalgo Head-Burrows Is between 1.4F > 1:55 > 1.1E Rosario Strait Skyline dive. Meetup 1:30pm, Splash 2:30pm. Recommend people NOT go through town Map link. Come in on Hwy 20. Turn right at the traffic circle onto the main road into town, go 3 blocks and turn left on 32nd St. Go about 1/4 mile and turn right on D Street. Proceed north until you hit Hwy 20 again (main road out to the ferry and Skyline). Turn left and proceed to Skyline. Advanced dive with a long 200 yard swim , in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not) puts some challenge in keep buddy pairs intact. When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. Divers they should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be a big issue. I strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. Historically the motorcycles a have not been an issue here. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park before coming over. Debriefing in is up in the air due to the generalize congestion in town. Maybe go back to Mt. Vernon Skagit Valley Pub. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Meet: 12:30pm Splash: 2:00pm Skill Lv: Advanced or comfortable diving on a Wall Special Note: This is a cross posted dive with Moss Bay Dive Club, with between dive meal. Do to the permit and food any small donation would be appreciated. Plan for 2 dives Description The Possession Point Reef is made of multiple rocky "fingers-like" projections on the southern tip of Whidbey Island that cascade down from about 30 ft to well over 130 ft in a series of rugged walls and ledges with sheer drop-offs in places creating absolutely stunning terrain. There are many nooks and crevices to explore for octopus. Many nudibranchs and sponges can be found nestled on the silty walls, while schools of perch pass over rockfish, kelp greenling and lingcod. Special Restrictions: This site is subject to heavy current and a moderate amount of boat traffic. The fingers run very deep making a good site for tech divers. Please watch your bottom time and use a live boat. Many good local dive charters frequent this area. Visibility is affected by nearby river runoff (the snohomish). How to get there: The Possession Point Fingers is located on the southern tip of Whidbey Island. It can be found by the large cleared lawn area surrounding the southern-most building on the east side of Possession point. Multiple fingers extend just south of this location and should be easily recognizable from the water's edge.

column4: 1453 Ozette Drive Fi · Fox Island, WA
column5: This is a current sensitive dive. That said, we're looking at a 3.9 flood to a -1.9 ebb. Such an exchange will give us an opportunity to take us south (and away from shore) and then back on the ebb where shore is near. Cold water diving experience (around 15 dives in Puget Sound) required. Participants with only Open Water certification will stay on the upper wall. This is an opportunity to experience some current without much a swim to return to shore. The wall is primarily layered sandstone south of the fishing pier at Fox Island Fishing Pier parking site. Ledges seem to be between 15 ft and 80ft. There is a restroom on site. You will also find a 15 stair steps and then 125 paces down a straight hill to the cobblestone beach. There are few logs on shore for staging and rigging your gear if you choose to do so at the water's edge. Slack is 12:41pm. So, meet at 11:15 am or so and splash at around 12:10pm for an hour long dive. Potential to dive Fox Island West wall afterward. It's only a short drive to the West Wall

The charter is with Ocean Quest, 22307 Dock Ave. S, Des Moines Marina Cost is $90 per person
Kimber Chard

Must have working Primary and secondary lights. Recommend tank light also. This is a great spot for photographers as well as divers. Skates have been seen here on several occasions. column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Sunset is at 7:17pm, so plan to splash anytime between 7:15 and 7:30 for a night dive here at Redondo. When the sun goes down this site really comes alive with squid, octopus, and smaller fish coming out in droves. Recommended to have dove Redondo during the day or have night dive experience. Primary and 2ndary lights required, tank light recommended.

San Juan Boat dive! Date: Saturday September 17th. The price is $90 per person and must be paid in advance. The plan is to meet at the boat at 8:00 AM so we can load all the gear and leave by 8:30 AM. Expect to return about 4:00 PM. We are planning to dive...... LONG ISLAND WALL and 2nd dive will be determined based on weather. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com (http://www.lujacsquest.com/) for more information and directions to the boat. Requirements: Each diver must have been diving within the last 60 days and have cold water diving experience. You will need all dive equipment, which includes 2-tanks, a BC, safe second, dive computer, safety sausage & whistle. We recommend this charter for experienced divers only, due to currents and live boat operations. Each diver must have been diving within the last 30 days and have Advanced Certification with a minimum of 50 logged dives. Thanks, Bruce Brown 425 512-7457 Cell 425 334-7763 Home
Kimber Chard

column2: More mid-week boat dives: Dalco Wall & Sunrise Reef
column5: Take a day off work? Or maybe you are self-employed, retired or can be a slacker for a day! Let's enjoy the great Pacific Northwest early fall weather with a couple of great boat dives. Ocean Quest recommends, for these sites, at least advanced certification with experience in currents, good buoyancy control and experience in mid-water ascents with SMB. Sign up on Meet Up and then immediately go to Ocean Quest Dive Charters website to reserve and pay for your spot. ($90 for two dives). Dalco Wall: This is a true wall dive. Most often we anchor in approximately 30′ of water and direct the divers out to approximately 40-60′ depth where the wall begins. This is where the sea floor is like walking to the edge of the Space Needle and provides a vertical drop down to 130-160′ before the sea floor becomes visible again.Current swept most of the time, this wall provides a great deal of food for small clinging marine life as well as cut back holes for wolf eel and octopus. The wall itself is often covered with shrimp so thick at times you cannot see the wall itself. Sunrise Reef: The premier of natural underwater reef structures. This reef consists of clay, sandstone, and rock and runs parallel to shore (north/south) beginning at about 45′ and max’s out at around 55-60′. This is a marine protected site, so it contains lots of colorful life – especially wolf eel and octopus, which are the main attraction.There are two mooring buoys installed by the Washington Scuba Alliance which makes this an convenient site to boat dive. Currents at times can be unpredictable, so always be prepared to expect some current and hope that it will be slack at dive time! Live boat pick up makes an easy exit at this site. Questions? Call or text me at 404-514-9622 or send me an email at myra 2640@comcast.net
Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda this weekend, please let me know if you'd like something added.

1.4F > 1:54 > 0.4E Fidalgo Head-Burrows Island 0.9F > 2:26 > 0.7E Rosario Skyline dive. Meetup 12:30pm, Splash 1:30pm. Advanced dive with a long 200 yard swim , in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not) puts some challenge in keep buddy pairs intact. When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. There's a school of Yellowtail rockfish been hanging out about midway. Divers they should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility, especially on the way back. Parking can be a big issue. I strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park before coming over. Debriefing in Anacortes after the dive; Brown Lantern, Rockfish, or the Bowling Alley depending on how busy things are. Skyline - Dive brief (http://files.meetup.com/6196802/Skyline_diving_timing.pdf) Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell Fritz

0ne tank dive at Keystone Jetty for all levels. Short walk to the Jetty (to 60ft max) or longer walk to (or from) the Keystone Pilings and/or the area in between. Either one is rich in sealife with huge lingcod to warbonnets and other smaller creatures. This State Park requires a Discover Pass and has bathrooms, shower, and picnic tables. Plan on a 12:00pm meet time for a 1:00pm splash. This dive is at slack coming from a predicted 1.3 kt flood to a -1.3 kt ebb. Pretty sweet! UPDATE! But there's more. We are approved to stay past dusk and do a second dive. This second (night) dive will be a very light exchange (-1.3kt ebb to a 0.2 Flood). Bring two tanks if you're inclined for a second dive. Bring a picnic dinner. Due to the Burn Ban only propane grills are allowed.

Something a bit different than the previous Friday slacker dives... 3.4 Flood > 12:30 > 1.4 Ebb - South Narrows Midstream (http://tides.mobilegeographics.com/locations/6432.html?y=2016&m=9&d=9) A good day to get into the Titlow pilings for a long photography session! This is a great site for macro photography - the site consists of two sets of pilings with a scattering of single pilings in towards shore. The outer set of pilings can be exposed to quite a bit of current, which means it has quite a bit of life can be found there. This is a site for the smaller things though, small octos, nudibranchs, large barnacles and the like is mostly what we'll see. Remember to bring your macro lens! The plan is to meet at 11:00am, splash between 11:30 and 11:45 - splashing a bit on the latter side is good on this day as the ebb should be very minor. Plan for a 70+ minute dive, cold tolerance permitting. This is a most* skill levels dive. There should be some mild current and depending how deep into the pilings you get there may be some overhead. Bring a cutting insturment as I've seen fishing line here before!

column5: Redondo one tank nite dive meetup 7pm, splash 7:45ish. This is an all skill level dive. Must have working Primary and secondary lights. Recommend tank light also.

This is an all skill level dive. Meet at 9am, splash 9:30. This site never really has any current to speak of* so will be good to go on what is otherwise a high current day everywhere.

Yara's house "Dive Planning Party". Sorry for the late posting, but as many of you already know, Lars and I will be hosting the next Dive Planning Party. BYOB, Potluck, Barbeque grill hot, Paper plates, utensils, napkins and cups supplied. Lots of laughs and stories.
