On the dive today I was able to talk to the contractor who will be doing the renovations at Three Tree. Ground breaking takes place on the 29th of august so we can come here one last time before the site is closed for a good long while (likely until December or later) This is a good all skill level site. Usually slightly better visibility than a site like Redondo or Cove 2, although some difficulty with parking (not too bad on a friday morning). I will drive by on my way to work the night before to make sure the site can still be accessed and send out a message either way.
2 went

I can't make either the Thurs. PM or Fri. AM dives and and am experiencing acute dive withdrawal syndrome. Any folks up for a dive at Edmonds Weds. 8/24 late afternoon (slack is 6:06, so meet around 4:45 and plan to splash around 5:30 - very low current projected, not a big exchange)? Or even tomorrow, Mon., 8/22? Slack is at 4:07, so that would mean meet around 3 PM. If you are interested, indicate which day/time you prefer. I'm up to all of about 19 dives now, so if someone more experienced wants to come, it would be better for them to be "dive leader" than me. But I am hoping to get in a dive this week.

column2: Moonlight Beach Adventure at Edmonds Marina Beach Park
column5: Hey dive friends! Once again, the Marker Buoys have been asked by the Beach Rangers of Edmonds to help with their annual (our 7th time!) dive collection and live underwater video program. This is the gig where we have at least 5-6 divers out collecting marine critters to place in the beach "tide pools" at about 7pm, or so. We collect for an hour-ish. The folks get to see the amazing marine life we divers get to see on our dives. After dark, at about 9pm, we then do a "live-Dive" off the beach with a streaming video camera showing on a big screen..right on the beach. Our diver will be using an OTS full face mask with full audio comms so the guests and crew can here the Ranger and the diver describing all the cool stuff that we all know is down there. Over the years that the club has been doing this, we have had as many as 300 people join in on the fun. According to my main point of contact in the Edmonds Parks Dept, we have one of the best attended naturalist events they put on ALL YEAR! We are a big hit! What a great way to help educate people on the wonders of the marine world of Puget Sound. It's all just a few hundred feet off the beach. So...I need help from at least 6 divers and other folks to help us with setting-up the tent, video gear, cables, etc at the Edmonds Marina Beach Park. While I am out of commission, Gene Coronetz will be the diver on comms. I will need one diver to help him drag his comm and video lines along during the live program. We usually get done at about 9:45pm. Then, we have to get all our gear back to the parking lot and stowed away. We will try to be out of the park by 10:30pm. Bring good lights! It's dark on that thar beach. I prefer that we arrive to set-up at about 5pm, or so. That gives us time to do the parking spot shuffle with all the other people using the park. The Edmond Beach Rangers are fantastic! They love it when we do this show. Come on out and have a fun time and help educate the folks about our favorite dive place...Puget Sound. Contact me with any questions: Randy Williams 1-206-387-6749 helioxccr@gmail.com

column2: South Sound early morning dive - all skill levels
column5: One of the last times to dive Three Tree until 2017*! It will be closing for construction sometime later this month but should still be open on this date. A good site for all skill levels with little current. Plan is to meet 9am splash 9:30am and just putter around to see what we can see. *There are signs about construction starting soon and I have heard from someone who contacted the project (director? manager? something like that) that they plan to break ground in late august, but not quite by the 19th. Once this happens there will reportedly be no access at all until they have finished. Pitty I really like this site. I will be checking on the site status thursday night and will leave a message here as well as contacting anyone signed up directly if we need to relocate. Back up site will be Redondo.

Going to Edmonds Underwater Park. High tide slack before ebb is at 6pm so let's meet at 5:30pm and try to splash around 6pm. We'll stay not deeper than 20-30 ft. I'll try to have water-resistant map of the park with me so navigation is a bit easier.

column2: Mid-week boat dives with Ocean Quest: Blake Island Reef & Alki Fishing Reef
column5: Wednesday may be hump day, but you won't have to hump your gear up and down the beach for this two-tank boat diving day! Sign up on Meet Up and then go immediately to Ocean Quest web-site to reserve and pay for your spot. We can have up to 8 divers total. Cost is $90 for two dives. (Ocean Quest recommends that, for these sites, divers have at least advanced certification, experience in currents, good buoyancy skills and experience in mid-water ascents using an SMB.) Blake Island Reef: Man made structures consisting of concrete slabs, boxes, and other debris to encourage the attraction of marine life. These were barged in and deposited on a sandy/silt sea floor ranging in depths of 40′ to 100′ plus. Alki Fishing Reef: Man made artificial series of reefs which was created to encourage the attraction of fish and other marine life. This goal has definitely been accomplished, and provides a terrific environment for diving activities. The reef consists of numerous piles of concrete and rock debris that provide great structure for marine habitat. These reefs are set in patterns parallel to shore with depths between 40′ to 80′ depending on the height of the tide and the location of which reef the diver chooses to explore. Questions? Call or text me at 404-514-9622 or send me an email at myra2640@comcast.net

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: It might only be a rumor that the full moon brings out sea life, but I'll check it out. Meeting for an almost full moon, night dive at Redondo. Back-up light and tank light required. Meet at 7:15pm. First splash at or near 8pm. Second splash at or near 10:00 pm All divers welcome. Moonrise is at 7:10pm and sunset is at 8:14pm. p.s. Yes, I have changed the time on this meet up. Hope you can all still make it. Come to one or both dives!

Going to Edmonds Underwater Park. High tide slack before ebb is at 5pm so let's meet at 4:45pm and try to splash around 5:15pm. We'll stay not deeper than 20-30 ft. I'll try to have water-resistant map of the park with me so navigation is a bit easier.

Great high slack at 5PM. Get your work finished early, and finish the day with a dive. Depending on interest and visibility, we could explore along the deep line, then come up to the geodome, PVC pipes, etc. Meet at 4-4:15PM for spash ~4:45. Please let me know if you have ?'s etc.

Let's go for a dive in Edmonds Underwater Park. Plan is to get into water around 9am at slack. We can select area of the park to explore when we meet. For those unfamiliar with park there is plenty of aquatic life. Park itself is 40-45 ft in its deepest part. There may be a bit of current but otherwise it should be an easy dive. I'll be bringing my GoPro.

column2: Summer Social at Saltwater State Park
column5: Diving. Barbeque. Hanging out with your club buddies. It's a diver's trifecta! Join us at Saltwater State Park. We reserve a day use site, set up a shelter and fire up the grill. And we dive, walk the park's trails, have conversations and generally enjoy life. Bring: Dive gear, of course. Your family, divers or not. Lawn chairs, beach stuff Potluck food and whatever you want to grill Drinks The club provides plates, forks, napkins, cups and ice. I'll send more details as the date nears.

column2: South Sound Morning Dive - Most* skill levels
column5: Saltwater State Park. A good dive for anybody who can make the long surface swim or walk. Today it will be a swim of approx 250 meters each way and we'll have some small potential for current as there is a 6.8 foot tidal exchange. Facilities on site and plenty of parking, but you'll either need a Discover pass - 35$ annually purchased here: http://discoverpass.wa.gov/ or a 10$ day pass purchased at the gate. *Make sure you are comfortable doing a long swim potentially with a little drift before signing up. Other than that this site can accomidate all skill levels.

This will be a Crabbing and Night dive combined. You can do either one or both if the crabbing sucks. Meetup is 8pm with a splash around 8:40. Peak current is 8:50pm at .2kt on the flood. Have working primary and secondary lights with tank light recommended. Night dive experience required. Crabber's require License, measuring scale (Dungeness minimum is 6.25" and Red Rock crabs 5") and grab bag. Non crabber's can enjoy the line with it's many critters. I have seen 4 Skates since diving here and since Sixgills around, that maybe a possibility.

column4: 1453 Ozette Drive Fi · Fox Island, WA
column5: For experienced current divers, please. This is a current sensitive dive. The layered sandstone ledges I will focus on are south of the fishing pier at Fox Island Fishing Pier parking site. Ledges seem to be between 15 ft and 80ft. There is a restroom on site. You will also find a 15 stair steps and then 125 paces down a straight hill to the cobblestone beach. There are few logs on shore for staging and rigging your gear if you choose to do so at the water's edge. We'll be diving at slack before a flooding tide coming from a max current of -1.2 knots and going to a max current of 1.9 knots. Slack is 6:18 pm. So, meet at 5:00 pm or so and splash at 5:45ish for an hour long dive.
Board members, please RSVP for the board meeting to be sure we have a quorum. I'll also send out an agenda this weekend, please let me know if you'd like something added.

column2: South Sound morning dive - all skill levels
column5: Another friday where the currents and tides keep us out of some of the more interesting sites. So back to Three Tree! There are only 5 parking spots - with some more out on the road itself, but it shouldn't be too much of a problem on a friday morning. Meet at 9am splash ~9:30. This is a big exchange day so there may be a little current here but not unmanageable. Hope to see you there!

column2: Down South one tank night dive
column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Redondo Beach night dive. Meetup 7:15pm. Splash at 8pm, with slack at 8:30pm before the ebb. Bring working primary and secondary lights. Recommend tank light also. This is an all skills level dive for those with night dive experience. At the recent," Dive Around the Clock", twice a six gill shark was seen. I can't see why we couldn't see one either. Bring your camera or GoPro I expect it to be busy there with the nice weather and you may need to use the paid parking lot.
This month's speaker will be Bob Bailey, discussing sidemount for recreational diving

column5: Another site to do if the currents won't cooperate. This site is open to all skill levels and is a good place to find octopus - both the resident GPOs and numerous smaller ruby octos. There is a paid parking lot but there should be plenty of free parking out on the street on a friday morning. Plan to meet 8:45 splash 9:15 to 9:30.

Just a fun dive in the afternoon at EUWP. You might want to come a bit early - it was overrun with roving Pokemon Go players last week when I was there. Meet at 4:00pm, splash around 4:45 to 5:00pm. Low tide is around 5:15pm, so hopefully the tide will be fairly gentle. See you there!
Meet at 8:00 am and splash when ready. You will need a crabbing license, a goodie bag and a crab gauge to measure your catch (Dungeness Crab minimum size is 6.25").

column2: South Sound Friday Morning - All skill levels
column5: An early morning dive for all skill levels. While parking at this site is somewhat limited it shouldn't be too much of a problem on a friday morning. Meet at 8:45 splash 9:15-9:30. Usually a good site to do to see life when currents just won't cooperate.

Have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be a big issue. One tank dusk dive, Cove 2. Meetup 7pm, Splash 7:45pm. Bring two working lights and tank lite optional.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Altered the dive to Redondo to get around any visibility problems. Altered the time to a later point so that we can hit closer to the slack. Please contact me with any questions. I removed references to Edmonds dive. This is a Redondo dive, meeting at 945 and hitting water at 1015. If you have any questions please don't hesitate to contact me. Redondo has a lot of parking and bathrooms.

column2: North Sound (Edmonds) Sunday AM Dive - Meet @ 8AM
column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: It looks like previously scheduled dive moved to South Sound, so here is another opportunity for a North End dive: - Ease into Sunday morning with a dive at Edmonds. - Gentle exchange and easy entry. - If shallow viz is poor, we can surface swim out further and see what Northern Lights or Boundary Way have to offer. - Convenient restrooms and showers. - Easy to refill tank after at Edmonds Underwater Sports (and buy more dive gear!) Meet at 8AM for 9AM splash.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.8 flood > 10:20 slack > 2.7 ebb - South Narrows prediction Day Island Wall (DIW) 8am meet up, 8:45-9am splash. Flood is going south, which is deeper, farther from shore, and more challenging direction than going north. The dive is most suitable for people already experienced with current and some familiarity with DIW. The exchange is fairly reasonable. For this exchange expect to swim ~150 yards underwater and drop onto the Day Island wall at 45' going south. Depth will be in the 45'-75- if you stay on top the wall, and down to 90'+ if you drop to the bottom. As with any shore based current dive there is no boat to bail you out if things don't go according to plan. You should feel confident of your dive skills and be looking to take a step up before considering this dive. If you aren't sure, call me to discuss it before showing up. This is a quiet residential neighborhood with on street parking and no facilities. Use bathroom facilities at Titlow nearby (water play area), or one of the establishments up on the hill. Carpooling is highly encouraged to limit impact on the neighborhood. Lunch at Steamers, which is open now. Fritz 206-525-0736 home (screening message on) 206-370-4720 cell
Board members, new and old, please RSVP for the board meeting.

column4: W. Green Lake Dr. N. · Seattle, WA
column5: Our second biggest social event of the year! The Annual Picnic is Wed, July 6th, 6-9 PM. This event takes the place of the July monthly meeting. Click on the address above to get close. It's off W. Green Lake Dr. N. at the north end of Green Lake, across from the Put-Put Golf course and the Old Aqua theater. Turn up the hill near the tennis courts and make the first left at the top of the hill. It is also easily accessible from 99N. This link will get you closer. http://www.seattle.gov/parks/_images/maps/picnics/Woodland4-7.pdf BBQ/potluck/BYOB. The Club will have the grills going and provide plates and plastic cups+utensils. Bring something to cook for yourself and something to share with the group. Should you like the elegance of glass for your beverage you need to bring that yourself. Alcohol is not allowed in parks so discretion is required. I WILL call Parks and will have the nearby bathroom open this year. No electricity. We will have a glass/aluminum and compost recycle containers this year. Please use them. Hopefully weather be great! Do come, the more members, the better time we have. I am looking forward to it! Mark

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: No dives posted this weekend....boring, so let's add a little excitement. I have NEVER done an exchange this large at DIW. I consider anything over 3.5k to be 'pushing it'. This one is: 5.7 flood > 5:40 PM slack >2.5 ebb - yup, 5.7k flood. Bring your trowels, scooters and any talisman you think might help. Confident, competent, and cocky divers should like this. This is ONLY for experienced DIW divers. We are going south, the more challenging direction, hopefully will come back. Realistically, if I thought we'd all be swept away I wouldn't do it. But I don't know how it will come out. We'll splash somewhere between 4:45 and 5 PM, maybe a tad later. I'll just have to watch it, and guess. This may be a fast trip to south bay and maybe still get back. We might have to exit south. You will need to be able to think on your fins. We'll see, but that's what experimental dives are about. The usual stuff about Day Island protocols, bathrooms, etc. If you don't know it, you haven't been there with me, so you shouldn't come Fritz

column5: A large time window here to fit folks' schedules and allow us some flexibility with the tides. First dive: Meet at 4:30p, splash at 5:30p. Second dive: Splash at 7:30p.

Not suitable for a first current experience. Flood is going south, which is a deeper, farther from shore, and more challenging direction than going north. The dive is most suitable for people already experienced with current and some familiarity with DIW. The exchange is fairly reasonable. For this exchange expect to swim ~150 yards underwater and drop onto the Day Island wall at 45' going south. Depth will be in the 45'-75- if you stay on top the wall, and down to 90'+ if you drop to the bottom. As with any shore based current dive there is no boat to bail you out if things don't go according to plan. You should feel confident of your dive skills and be looking to take a step up before considering this dive. If you aren't sure, call me to discuss it before showing up. This is a quiet residential neighborhood with on street parking and no facilities. Use bathroom facilities at Titlow nearby (water play area), or one of the establishments up on the hill. Carpooling is highly encouraged to limit impact on the neighborhood. Debrief Steamers or Boathouse 19 in the marina. Fritz 206-525-0736 home (screening message on) 206-370-4720 cell

column2: Watch Wildlife Detectives featuring Puget Sound's 6-gill sharks
column5: KCTS-9 is airing an hour-long documentary about the 6-gill sharks of Puget Sound. I'd like to see watch it with other divers, BUT I don't have television service. Anyone willing to host? Here is the wesbite information published about it: http://kcts9.org/programs/wildlife-detectives/coming-soon-wildlife-detectives-mystery-sharks-seattle It looks really interesting. Viewing begins at 9pm, so maybe an 8ish meet-up for socializing and dispensing of what we know about the 6-gills. 9pm is SHOWTIME! RSVPs are currently closed for this location. If you are interested in offering another location for viewing please begin a new meet up. Thanks :-)
Please RSVP if attending or not to be sure we have a Quorum. Let me know if you plan to call in. I will set up a GotoMeeting.

NOTE: Due to the building wind and waves and a concern for safety, I am changing the location for this dive to Alki Cove 2. For those interested in doing REEF surveys, we'll be diving at the pipeline with meet time around 6pm and splash at 7pm. I'll have REEF survey sheets. Bring a light in case viz is poor. This dive is appropriate for all levels.

Current conditions seem adequate for a dive at Keystone Jetty, pilings, and points in between (sea-floor hauserline). Come for a one-tank dive! The visiting all three locations gives a good taste of different kinds of life. Today's dive is around slack at 11:30am from a 0.6knot flood to a 1.7knot ebb. Discovery Passes are required. Plenty of parking, bathroom facilities, and shower are available. Meet at 10am, splash at 11:00 for an hour long dive. Actual splash time varies with your expected bottom time as slack is around 11:30.

Salt water state park. Meetup 9am, Splash 10am. Second dive meetup 12pm meet up splash 1pm. This would be a good picnic opportunity, so bring hot dogs or whatever. There will be a small grill available. Bring your own drink

column2: Meeting Friends of Saltwater State Park
column5: Interested in Saltwater State Park? Help support watershed/marine stewardship and amenities for park patrons.

Let's get together and plan some dives! And even if you aren't up for planning any dives, and just want to get together with other Marker Buoy members to enjoy good food and good company, we'll be doing that too. So come on over! Spouses and partners are invited too! I'll provide plates, utensils etc as well as soft drinks and some hot and cold snacks. Bring anything else that you might like to have/share for eating and drinking. We have a grill on the deck if you want to bring something to grill. Our home overlooks the Puget Sound & Maury Island and there is currently an eagle family visible that is in residence down the slope from the house. Questions? Suggestions? Call or email at 404-514-9622/ myra2640@comcast.net

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Come down and dive once or twice this Thursday while we look for little critters. First splash at 5:15 or so and second splash at 7:15 or so.

column2: Come to the monthly club meeting
column5: Dave Ballard

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Intermediate/advance divers, due to possible significant current. Be aware there is a long hill to and from the beach. The reward is one of the best dives in the south Sound. There are wolfeels, octopus and much, much more. Splash is around 10:50 am. This is a slack before ebb with a very nice exchange between a max current of 1.9 and a 2.5 kt There is plenty of parking and an outhouse near by. If you can, plan to join everyone for a debrief at Spiro's in Gig Harbor after the dive.

Hey Everyone! I'm flexible on Sat/Sun depending on where the interest is but lets plan for 0730 splash time, meetup at 0700. Since parking is limited, if more than 3-4 people are interested then we should car pool to make parking less stressful. Let me know if you have any questions! If I get a lot of interest we may need to bump it to Redondo to accommodate.

Somehow my dive got cancelled, so I do not remember the exact times. If anyone had that info pls let me know the meetup and splash times. Please RSVP again. Meetup 7pm, splash at 7:45pm. Bring working primary and backup lights. We'll be going in on the flood. Last time I dove here we found a Skate at 11ft in the eel grass, you too could find one.

The Last San Juan Boat Dive to Long Island Wall was so good so lets do it again!!! Long Island Wall Dive Date: Saturday, May 21st Meet time at Skyline Marina in Anacortes is 8:30 AM, so we can load all the gear and leave promptly by 8:30 AM. Expect to return about 4:30 PM. Cost: $90 for a two tank boat charter payable in advance to secure your spot. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. The plan is to Dive Long Island wall and 2nd dive TBD. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com (http://www.lujacsquest.com/) for more information and directions to the boat. REQUIREMENTS: Each diver must have been diving in cold water within the last 60 days and have cold water diving experience before joining us to maximize your enjoyment and safety on the charter. EQUIPMENT REQUIREMENTS: You will need all dive equipment and two full tanks. This includes having a BC, depth & pressure gauge, dive computer, safety sausage and whistle. Directions to Skyline Marina: From I-5 take the SR-20 exit (#230) toward Anacortes (west). It takes at least 15 minutes to get into town. Follow the signs for the state ferry for the San Juan Islands: turn right onto Commercial (north), follow to 12th street (at the corner with a Chevron station and Safeway). Turn left onto 12th Street like you are going to the ferry. Go west until you get to the light, about 2.5 miles. A right down the hill takes you to the ferry dock, but go straight on Sunset Ave. Continue west to the sign for Skyline Marina at the bottom of the hill, about half a mile. Turn left (south) and go straight at the stop sign. Continue a few blocks to the Skyline Marina North Island Boat Company signs on your left. Pull into the parking lot. The boat is on TD dock next to the marina office, Slip no. TD-22. The gates will be open and tank carts will be unlocked. Thank you, Bruce Brown 425 334-7763 Home 425 512-7457 Cell

column2: God's Pocket Resort incl. Nakwakto Rapids - May 2016
column5: Join us for five days of diving up at God's Pocket Resort near Port Hardy, BC. This trip will include a trip to Nakwakto Rapids (weather and sea-state permitting). Head up to Port Hardy on Friday, May 13 returning Thursday, May 19th. Complete information is available at http://tinyurl.com/GodsPocket . Big shout out to Jen Vanderhoof for starting the ball rolling on this idea and to Ken Gatherum (Co-organizer) for doing all of the leg work and putting together all of the documentation for this trip. Some things I want you to know. I am not leading the dives, that is the job of Bill Weeks at God's Pocket. Bill will be leading the dives, evaluating conditions, and deciding who will be making the dives. Bill has the experience to evaluate divers and match them with the proper sites. Bill was instrumental in helping Ken and I put together all the information for this dive, especially the section about diver qualifications. In addition, do know that I am paying the same price as you all. If we get 12 divers on board, the price will be the same for all of us. My role here is to simply let you all know that this opportunity is available.
Please RSVP if attending or not to be sure we have a Quorum. Let me know if you plan to call in. I will set up a GotoMeeting.

With the bad vis we've been having Three Tree offers slightly less bad visibility with the more rocky bottom. Sunset will be ~8:30pm so we'll aim to splash right at sunset to get more critters out and about. No facilities so plan ahead. Carpooling strongly encouraged as there are only 5 parking spaces at the site itself, you may need to drop your gear at the site and park out on the main road (thankfully you can still park there, just nowhere along the hedges). This will be a one tank hosted dive. *just realized I forgot to mention lights! Make sure to bring a primary and backup light!

column2: Come to the monthly club meeting.
column5: David Riley

column2: Meeting Friends of Saltwater State Park
column5: Interested in Saltwater State Park? Help support watershed/marine stewardship and amenities for park patrons.

3.2 flood > 10 AM > 5.7 ebb: Meet 8:30 AM, Splash ~9:30. Timing is critical here. It's an early dive as most people will have to leave Seattle 6:30 AM or so. Traffic should be light though. This is a smaller exchange and suitable for divers ready for the next big step to high current for much of the dive. Experienced, advanced current divers only! NOT FOR LEARNING CURRENT DIVING. Once you start this dive you are absolutely committed. Don't even think about it unless you are very confident of your diving skills and current experience. If you have questions contact me. I don't like surprises on this dive. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, overhead boat traffic, fishing line, and seldom has even decent viz. Buddy separation can be an ever present issue and happens easily here. It is difficult re-connect once separated, which can happen rapidly and is not uncommon. For your risk and effort you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. It is colorful and spectacular. 150-200 yard walk to the water with a medium hill. Good parking, restroom on site. Discover Pass required. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Want to get involved in doing critter surveys for REEF? Here's your chance to get some critter ID training, achieve REEF Experience Level 2 and do some diving. We are holding a two-day REEF event at Salt Water State Park on April 30th and May 1st which will include classes in the event room at the park and diving as well as socializing. Here is the tentative schedule: April 30th - 8am: Intro to REEF and Fish class - Noon: Dive and survey (focus on fish) - 2pm: BYO lunch, continue Fish class, review surveys, Fish quiz - Folks can camp and stay the night or go home, then… May 1st - 8am: Invertebrates Class - Noon: BYO lunch while you suit up - 1pm Dive and survey (focus on fish and inverts) - 3pm Review surveys and Invert quiz All attendees should buy their REEF class materials online before the classes. You can order the Pacific Northwest REEF Starter Kit here: http://www.reef.org/node/431 Classes will be given by Rhoda Green and Doug Miller. Space is limited so RSVP soon to reserve your spot. I will update this Meetup if arrangements change. If you have questions submit them in the discussion area here. For more information on REEF, see my presentation from the March 2015 meeting here: http://files.meetup.com/6196802/REEF-2015-MBDC.pptx

column2: MaST Center Redondo Pier and Beach Clean-up Day
column3: MaST - Marine Science and Technology Center
column4: 28203 Redondo Beach Dr. S · Des Moines, WA
column5: The MaST Center is once again sponsoring the pier, beach and underwater clean-up of the Redondo area and dive site.There is never a time when this poor place doesn't get hit with nasty trash. We need volunteer divers and shoreline folks. Please come out and help. Contact Jillian Mayer at the MaST Center. email: jmayer@highline.edu 1-941-321-9430 (her cell). If anyone is able, I'd like to get a team together to go ut past the deep boat/bottle field area and pick-up all the garbage that tends to wash into that swale. You got doubles, CCR...big monster single bottle? Let's go to town on that nasty area. Contact me as well about this dive plan: Randy Williams, helioxccr@gmail.com FB event: https://www.facebook.com/events/1570872246556466/
Michael Doyle

4.05 flood > 12:37 PM > 5.7 ebb: Meet 11:10, Splash 12:10. Somewhat larger ebb than 2 weeks ago. Timing is critical here. Experienced, advanced current divers only! Once you start this dive you are absolutely committed. This is not the dive learn current diving. Don't even think about it unless you are very confident of your diving skills and current experience. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, overhead boat traffic, fishing line, and seldom has even decent viz. Buddy separation can be an ever present issue. For your risk and effort you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. 150-200 yard walk to the water with a medium hill. Good parking, restroom on site. Discover Pass required. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Flexible on the time, but Redondo is always nice for ease of parking. I'm up for 1 or 2 dives but until I get some takers let's say 1- Splash at 830, meet at 8am.

3.3 flood > 12:05 PM > 5.2 ebb - Meet 10:30, Splash 11:30 Timing here is critical. Experienced, advanced current divers only! Once you start this dive you are absolutely committed.This is not the dive learn current diving. Don't even think about it unless you are very confident of your diving skills and current experience. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, overhead boat traffic, fishing line, and seldom has great viz. But, you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. 150-200 yard walk to the water with a medium hill. Good parking, restroom on site. Discover Pass required. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Predicted slack is right after sunset. Yay! Although slack is at 8:00pm, we'll plan to head in by 8:15 or so. Park near the west end of Alki Trail and we'll walk the stairs to the water's edge. Strong winds (and surf) from the north will prompt a change to Alki Pipeline. This is generally not a current sensitive site. Currents this day are < .5 knots.
Pretty straight forward. 4:30pm meetup 5:15 splash. Second dive 7:15pm splash show up early enough to setup your gear to make the splash time. Have working primary and backup lights

column4: Nearest address: 8343 S Franklin Rd, Clinton, WA 98236 · Clinton, WA
column5: The dive site is at Possession Point State Park, which I recently was able to correctly locate on Google Maps after years of being rebuffed! I checked it after our last outing and it does appear correctly. As this is a State Park, Discover Pass is required. As the P- Lot is tiny, Carpool is advised... So Friends, Thanks for the wonderful response! 12 divers is about the max this site can handle at one time without becoming too busy...one or 2 more =OK, but more than that isn't real manageable... so if you " miss the boat" this time around, be an early responder when I put it on the calendar again... Let's target the Mukelteo Ferry @ 0830... Best dive window is between 10:00 & 3:00, so 2 dives are available...

Saltwater State Park slacker dive for advance divers or better. 7:45am meetup, splash at 8:45am, slack at 9:17am before flood. Looks like it will be more swim then walk on this one. 3 rock piles with a good variety of critters, both small and large. Great photo op's as well as poking around the boulders. Wolf Eels, Ling Cos's, GPO's and assorted Rockfish including Vermilian's. There is an opportunity for a 2nd dive, but this one will not be hosted.

column2: South Sound Night Dive: Small critter/photography
column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Myra

column2: Dive Italia! It's the 2016 MBDC Annual Banquet!
column5: Exploring the world via diving is something Marker Buoy members do, and do well. In any given year, you can find MBDC members in nearly every corner of the world. To honor lesser-known diving destinations, the 2016 Annual Banquet celebrates: Dive Italia! Our buffet meal for this year is a rich and varied Italian feast with selections to suit all tastes. Add to that the many options on the raffle table and you have a great evening out with your dive buddies. Join us! Payments can either be sent via PayPal (the preferred method, using treasurer@markerbuoydiveclub.org) or email a check to the club at PO Box 31163, Seattle, WA 98103. PLEASE be sure to indicate that the payment is for the banquet so it does not get attributed to your 2016 club dues. If you have already RSVP'ed, please be sure to remit your payment. Thanks!
Please RSVP if attending and let me know if you plan to call in. I will set up a GotoMeeting.

column2: Clean-Up Dive at Sekiu. Clallam Bay, WA
column5: The Marine Science & Tech Center, Highline College (MaST Center) is sponsoring a clean-up dive at Sekiu on March 5. We will be working the marina area at the far end of the Sekiu are called Mason's Olsons Resort. http://www.olsons-resort.com/ Google map: https://www.google.com/maps/@48.2593307,-124.278783,15z?hl=en The local Chamber of Commerce in Clallam Bay is throwing in a catered lunch for the participants. on Saturday, March 5. Orientation is at 1030am at the site. two dives are planned at aprx 1100 and at 1300 hrs. The resort is offering a deep discounted room rate of $75/nite. The rooms offered have two queen size beds. If you want to spend the night, we will be diving at Sekiu Point on Sunday morning. BRING SCUBA TANKS!! Curleys does not open until April. Curley's has a compressor for future reference. PLEASE RSVP with Jillian Mayer at the MaST Center if you wish to come out and join in the fun. email at: jmayer@highline.edu. MaST web page: https://mast.highline.edu/ Scroll down to bottom of the page to see the flyer about the event. Sekiu is aprx 54 miles west of Port Angeles, WA on WA St Hwy 112.

I have never been to this site before, but it is another published site in Fischnaller's shore dives book that I want to check out. Although a shallow dive (18-47 ft), there is potential for considerable current. On March 5 predicted, adjusted, slack will be at 8:30 am before a flooding tide. Tide on the flood heads westward, so we'll endeavor to ride the ebbing current into the bridge pylon area around 8:00 or so and then ride it back when the tide turns. Max current on either side of slack max at 1.5knots on that date. So it ought to be manageable. Fischnaller is quite specific that we begin the return swim as soon as the current changes. We will see. Parking is north of the road on Fox Island.
David Riley

column2: Meeting Friends of Saltwater State Park
column5: Interested in Saltwater State Park? Help support watershed/marine stewardship and amenities for park patrons.

Hello Everybody, I'm a new diver (and new to Marker Buoys!) and eager to get some bottom time in- So I'm planning a dive in an effort to get to know you all better and to gain experience. I'm thinking a 9 am meetup time with a 930 splash time for Three Tree Point. Since parking is limited, if more than 3-4 people are interested then we should car pool to make parking less stressful. Let me know if you have any questions!

A favorite dive site, but not for beginners as experience with current is necessary . Meet time is 1 pm for a proposed splash at 2:15. We'll watch the water. Be prepared to drop earlier....or later. Carpooling is encouraged, given that we need to take the ferry over to Whidbey Island. And be aware that a Discover Pass is needed for the parking lot - or just pay $10 on-site. Plenty of parking here, picnic benches for staging, restrooms and shower. Post-dive debriefing with food and beverage is encouraged as always. URL for the Mukilteo/Clinton ferry schedule is below http://www.wsdot.com/ferries/schedule/ScheduleDetailByRoute.aspx?route=muk-cl

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 3.0 ebb > 11:15AM > 3.0 flood - Meet ~ 9:15. Splash ~ 10:15 Advanced, with some NW current experience (drift dives in Cozumel and the like do not count.) This is a North entrance, north and back dive. Mid-grade current, fine for experienced folks, OK if you have a good number of dives under your belt and are looking to up your current experience a bit. The north drift is shallower and stays closer to shore. I think it is the preferred dive to do as your first dive here. Note on terminology. When I use the term [Advanced] I do not mean PADI/NAUI 'Advanced'. In my opinion getting through 'Advanced Class' is just about a minimum to be exploring Puget Sound at the 'Basic' level. The use of that term for an entry level class is both confusing and counterproductive. Day Island is a serious shore dive and needs to be treated as such. No rescue, no boat pickup. There is no try, you do or you don't do. If you are not sure if this is a dive for you, email or call me. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell
Come out and join me for a celebration of my 900th Dive!!! Nothing fancy just looking forward to another wonderful dive with my favorite bunch of divers!!!

Junkyard nite dive 6:15pm meetup, 7pm splash with a 7:35 slack before a 11ft flood. The flood shouldn't be a problem since we'll be in the shallows heading back to our exist as it comes in. Have working primary and secondary lights. Recommend a tank light. This site usually yields great finds during the evening hours as opposed to nothing during the day. The line starts near the drop buoy between 50-55ft. There has been a young wolf eel at the beginning in some square tubes. Sailfin Sculpins, Octo's and stubby squids are plentiful and sometimes, if your lucky, a Skate. I have also found Sea spider's here. Jim, if your coming, meetup is at 5pm LOL

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Come join us to look for red octos, pipefish, snailfish, lumpies and more. Best time to find is them is at night. And I'm hearing that lumpies are being found. Great dive for photography. Good for all levels of experience. Must have dove this site before during the day. Bring two main lights and a tank light.

I love this site. Despite the new, parking regulations, I'm going to try this anyway. (No parking along the hedgerow.) After dark I don't expect too many cars in the legal parking area. In the event that more than 5 people sign up, we will need to carpool to the parking area. I'll be monitoring as the evening approaches. Slack is at 3:45pm, but current is rarely an issue at Three Tree. Come dive!
Please RSVP if attending and let me know if you plan to call in. I will set up a GotoMeeting.
Eugene Coronetz

Saltwater State Park. Meetup 9am, Splash 10am with slack before the flood at 10.35am. Some people say this is a long swim out, but if you just cruise and enjoy the view it ends up being short. There are 3 rock piles and all three can be done unless you find something very interesting. The life on it has really grown, with wolf eels, GPO's, assorted large rockfish. Ling Cod's have also moved in. I'd say the site is like diving Edmond's Underwater Park. There are also tire piles at a 25-55ft depth for open water divers, where I have found GPO's recently, as well as Grunt Sculpin's and Nudibranch.
Great place for a night dive....Usually no current issues. Primary and backup light required. Parking is $2.00 per hour from 8am to 8pm.
Myra

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.8k ebb > 5:30 PM > 2.9 flood - South Narrows indicator Meet 3:30 PM, Splash ~4:30 PM North entrance, going north and back. Medium current, not suitable for newer current divers. Prior experience required for this dive. Steamers is closed until March so we'll hit Boathouse 19 at the Marina for dinner after. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Myra

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Intermediate level experience required due to unpredictable current and long walk. This is also a slightly more aggressive profile than I've done before. Sunrise is one of the best dives in the South Sound for the variety of life including wolfeels and octopus. Be sure to arrive with enough time to get down to the entry on time. Suggested meet time 9:15 am. Splash is about 10:20 am. Should be down at the water around 10:05 am. This is a slack before flood between a 2.6 to 2.4k max currents.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

Had so much fun last time, We decided to do another dive planning party. Potluck and BYOB. Especially would like the non diving spouse to attend. This is a good opportunity for them to meet and mingle. I will have my new barbeque ready for all on comers, pop and tea will be available as well as plates & utensils etc. etc. New members, you do not have to post a dive to attend. Just show up and enjoy. You can ask question of our members about dive sites, which site fits your skill level, equipment, skill development such as dive planning, compass reading, night dives, understanding current or whatever tickles your fancy. Anyone having questions can call me at 206-931-2963

Some info indicates that Skyline may be clearing up. If the weather stays cold (snow not melting), with rain and flooding controlled I think I'd like to take a try at a winter Skyline dive....for a change. Maybe. This is not a dive to start out on if you have not done it before or don't have a LOT of current experience. 3.0F > 9:22AM > 1.2E: splash ~ 9AM, Meet ~8-8:30. Reasonable exchange. I think parking should not be a big issue this time of year. If you come later be prepared to suit up and get in. This is an advanced current dive with a long swim to a rocky wall covered with invertebrate life. Viz could be poor. The Skagit could start flooding again if the weather deteriorates. In that case, I'll pull the dive. I'll be updating these options as we get close to the date. Ultimate decision may be the night before. The dive is very condition dependent. Fritz Note - Family birthday Sat. evening so I've cancelled the Day Island option.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: This can be called a midweek/mid day slacker diver. Meet around 1:30 PM and splash at 2:00

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Dive closed. 2.3 ebb > 11:45 slack > 2.6 flood - North entrance going north and back Meet 9:45AM, splash about 10:45AM. This is a decent exchange for divers with recent diving experience but limited current experience to try out an outstanding current site. For this exchange expect to swim ~150 yards underwater and drop onto the Day Island wall at 45' going north. Depth will be in the 45'-60'. As with any shore based current dive there is no boat to bail you out if things don't go according to plan. You should feel confident of your dive skills and be looking to take a step up before considering this dive. If you aren't sure, call me to discuss it before showing up. This is most definitely NOT Cove 2 or Edmonds. This is a quiet residential neighborhood with on street parking and no facilities. Use bathroom facilities at Titlow nearby (water play area), or one of the establishments up on the hill. Carpooling is highly encouraged to limit impact on the neighborhood. I plan to debrief at Boathouse 19 in the nearby Day Island Marina. (Steamers received substantial flood damage during one of the big storms) Fritz 206-525-0736 home (screening message on) 206-370-4720 cell

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center Jon Crimmons from Central Whidbey State Parks joining us tonight. He'll be sharing information about REEF surveys (as noted in last month's newsletter).

Three Tree 1 or 2 tank dive. First meetup 7am, Splash 7:30am, so come with gear setup. 2nd dive meetup 8:45am, splash no later then 9:30am. This is a good spot for all skill levels and I encourage new members to do this dive I am expecting good weather, but it'll still be cold. Bring hot water for your hood and gloves, if your doing two dives. There has been issues with a couple of residents regarding parking and I recommend you make every effort to carpool. Parking too can be limited. Make the effort, help keep the peace between residents and divers. Lunch at Elliot Bay Brewery 255 SW 152nd St, Burien. Last two to arrive pays! Just kidding.

Down south after christmas dive will gives you an opportunity to try out all of your new dive toys Hopefully the weather will cooperate with us on this one and of course your not suffering from to many holiday cheers. This will be a one tank dive with a long swim out to the drop buoy. Meetup is 12pm with a splash at 1pm, the splash time maybe 30 minutes early. We'll watch and decide if it is or is not.

column2: 2 tank boat dive for $55 with Ocean Quest Dive Charters
column4: 22307 Dock Ave S. · Des Moines, WA
column5: Ocean Quest Dive Charters is offering special deal on a 2-tank boat dive for $55 and it looks like they still have space! George and Andrea have a great operation. column5: There's some nasty and volatile weather coming through this weekend. I .....think....most of it will be more up north for wind so I'm going to make a try at Day Island Sat. AM. But, it could get weathered out. 2.5F > 12:50 slack > 2.7E. Splash about 10:15 AM. Due to the wind advisories plus the extra exposure going south, this dive is only recommended for experienced DIW divers that have already done the south profile. Need to be careful on this one. I'll do an update this evening, 9-10 most likely. If it still looks possible I'll do an early AM update by 7AM which should give folks time to pack and drive down. Be sure to check the updates!! Fritz 206-525-0736 H 206-370-4720 C

column2: Want to be a Seattle Aquarium diver, deadline for turning in application.
column5: Want to become a volunteer diver at the Seattle Aquarium? As an Aquarium diver you share your enthusiasm and the stories of our animals with Aquarium visitors using state of the art underwater communication equipment while performing exhibit maintenance and animal husbandry tasks. Aquarium volunteer divers receive extensive training about our marine animals and interpretive communication techniques. For more information visit SeattleAquarium.org/diver. REMINDER: For the January 9, 2016 orientation, diver experience forms are due no later than December 9, 2015 at 5pm.

It's a Christmas party, a Holiday gathering, a post-Thanksgiving fete, a REALLY early New Year's Eve shindig AND a Hanukkah bash all rolled into one! Rather than conduct the standard club meeting, in December, MBDC members gather together for a low-key evening of camaraderie and cheer. The Details: EAT -- The club provides ham, cheeses, rolls and veggies, plus plates, napkins, utensils. You bring additional POTLUCK items to share, like casseroles, side dishes and desserts. DRINK - BYOB. We will provide cups and ice. BE MERRY - It's a GIFT EXCHANGE! - Please bring a wrapped gift for the gift exchange. We suggest you search for an item with a scuba, ocean or fish theme as that will appeal to any recipient. The recommended cost limit is $20.00. More information to follow. Any questions? Please ask Looking forward to seeing you there -- Andrea

column4: 1350-1406 Lakeside Ave S, Seattle, WA 98144 · Seattle, WA
column5: Haven't been here in a while and feel like it's long over due. Being that it's winter, we can avoid the boat traffic that keeps us away during the summer. This dive can be creepy, dark and murky with the current i-90 bridge above with the sounds of traffic. There is a long surface swim. BE AWARE that with the bridge above, will mean in an emergency you will NOT be able to surface. A while back the original I-90 bridge broke off and sank. You can go down and see a section of the old bridge. This consists primarily of concrete structures and grating. There is only one bridge deck left of the two. The remaining plate is some 200' feet long laying in 45' to 80' at the deep end of it. Lots of construction debris around. It's dark when you get near the bridge due to shadows cast by the live bridge above you. The sound the passing cars make over the bridge decking above adds to the surrealness of this dive.

column2: N End Dive Women Welcome Dive
column5: Dive Mukilteo. Meet at 10:00AM splash about 11:00AM. All levels all sexes welcome.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: All level of women divers welcome. Back by popular demand. A chance to meet, learn from, and dive with other women in the club. After party will be at Randy and Randi's which is not far from the dive site. Men are welcome to join the party. Bring something to grill and a side dish.

column2: 2-Tank Boat dive on Howe Sound, BC with Sea Dragon Charters - $85 US - 4 spots
column5: Saturday, Nov. 21, 2015: 2-Tank Boat Dive on Howe Sound, Canada - Sea Dragon Charters. Boat loading time starts at 8:30 AM. Boat departure time is 9:15 AM. Return to the marina around mid-afternoon. Sea Dragon Charters operates out of Sewell’s Marina next to the Horseshoe Bay Ferry Terminal in West Vancouver, BC. The address for Sewell’s Marina is 6409 Bay Street, Horseshoe Bay, BC, V7V Here is the link to the Sea Dragon Charters (604-329-3486) http://seadragoncharters.com (http://seadragoncharters.com/) The website has descriptions of their charter boat, the Topline, driving directions to Sewell’s Marina, what you can see at their favorite dive sites, etc. My first trip to the marina, two years ago, I used the GPS directions on my Garmin that sent me through downtown Vancouver (very slow). Directions from MapQuest will provide a better route via BC-99N, BC-91 N towards New West Minster, BC-91A N, Marine Way W, etc. Since this trip will be during the winter months, the Topline will be moored near Sewells’s fuel dock, on the west side of the marina (closest to the Bathhouse Restaurant). The Sea Dragon website, under Booking has advisory information about parking and a nice map showing where the Topline is moored November until March. http://seadragoncharters.com/wp-content/uploads/seadragon-horseshoe-bay.pdf Last year, Bruce Brown and I purchased coupons for 10 Sea Dragon 2-tank boat dives in 2015 at $85 US/dive trip. Between the two of us, we have 4 extra coupons that we would like to sell at cost ($85 US) to MBDC members that would like to join us on Sea Dragon’s Nov. 21 dive charter trip. Otherwise, to book a 2-tank boat dive with Sea Dragon Charters today would be $115.45 CDN (tax included). Bruce has three $85 US coupons to sell. I have only one $85 coupon to sell. So please give us a call. Bruce (cell: 425-512-7457), Carl (cell: 425-308-4625). First come, first serve for those four $85 coupons. Beyond the first 6, the Sea Dragon’s Topline should have room for others. However, you will need to pay the higher price, directly to Sea Dragon Charters. On July 22, Bruce and I and two other MBDC members enjoyed a great day on Howe Sound, using the $85 Sea Dragon coupons that we had purchased last year. We dove the Annapolis and a site called Crazy Crab Wall on Bowyer Island. At Sewell’s Marina, you will need a $1 Canadian coin (they call them a “Looni”) to insert into locking system that releases one marina wheelbarrow to haul your dive gear down to the Top Line and for then again for offloading at the end of the day. The marina has about four wheelbarrows to use. The nice thing about this wheelbarrow locking system is that it returns your Looni when you return to the wheelbarrow. You can unload your equipment at the loading zone at the dock. Then you must move your vehicle to a nearby pay lot. Consult their website about parking options. Questions, please contact Carl Baird (425-308-4625, carl.baird@wavecable.com).

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.5 ebb > 1:50 PM slack > 2.6 flood (South Narrows, mid-channel interpreted) Splash around 12:45 PM. Meet 11:45 AM. Advanced, with some NW current experience (drift dives in Cozumel and the like are just not the same.) This is a North entrance, north and back dive. Mid-grade current, fine for experienced folks, OK if you have a good number of dives under your belt and are looking to up your current experience a bit. The north drift is shallower and stays closer to shore. I think it is the preferred dive to do as your first dive here. I expect the viz to be in the 10-12' range with all the rain. Note on terminology. When I use the term [Advanced] I do not mean PADI/NAUI 'Advanced'. In my opinion getting through 'Advanced Class' is just about a minimum to be exploring Puget Sound at the 'Basic' level. The use of that term for an entry level class is both confusing and counterproductive. Day Island is a serious shore dive and needs to be treated as such. If you are not sure if this is a dive for you, email or call me. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged. Residential neighborhood and we want to keep our impact low and our presence minimal. Hit Steamer's afterward. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell
Kimber Chard

Three Tree nite dive. Meetup 6:30pm with a 7:15 splash. Have working primary and secondary lights. Tank light is recommended. To keep the peace with the neighbors, this dive is limited to 10 divers. Recommend carpooling if possible.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

1.5 flood > 1:50 slack > 1.1 ebb, splash ~ 1:30 PM Advanced dive with a long swim, in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible. Parking can be an issue, strongly suggest carpooling. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby WA. Park before coming over. Plan on a debrief in town after the dive. Important Note: This is late enough in the season that the Skagit River could be in flood which can mess up this dive. I could move this to Day Island at the last minute which has a more challenging profile this day (experienced current divers only 3.2 flood > 2:37 PM slack > 3.2 ebb). If you sign up stay posted for details as the dive gets near. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 3.2 Flood > 2:40 slack > 3.2 Ebb (S. Narrows, mid-stream). 12:15 meet, ~1:15 splash. This is an Advanced dive for experienced current divers only! We are going N > S and back which puts us deeper, farther from shore, and into the path of the potential out and down current in the south region. You need to have your legs and wits about you. Bring your trowel. Day Island is an exposed shore dive with some significant rewards for those willing to master current. You have a number of different dive options, plus the opportunity to see large wolf eels and GPO. About 125 yards off shore you drop into a small wall area. In this particular dive a dying flood pushes you south. The Day Island Wall forms this direction, gets larger, deeper and farther from shore. There are lots of dens and big critters living in them, especially if you make it all the way to South Bay. No facilities in a normal (OK high end) residential neighborhood. Titlow park has a nice restroom by the water park, or some other businesses nearby for the last pitstop. Since it is a neighborhood carpooling is nice to reduce auto impact. Good neighborhood manners are critical. Hit Steamer's afterward, maybe let Sat traffic die down a bit before heading home. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Open to divers of all skill levels. No facilities on site so if you need to use a restroom stop somewhere on the way. Parking is limited so carpooling is great if possible - but is shouldn't be too bad on a friday morning. Plan is to meet at 9AM splash 9:30AM.
Primary and backup light required. Tank light recomended.

November 4 ONLY: We are going to visit the Hyperbaric Chamber at Virginia Mason Hospital. Our tour starts at 7:00 pm. We'll meet in the main lobby along Seneca Street. Please arrive early as the tour will start promptly at 7:00PM For parking, there are several sites nearby. Go here ( https://www.virginiamason.org/SeattleParking ­ ) for a link of the area paid parking. Otherwise people could try to find something on the street. Rates in the area are $4 per hour until 8pm. After 8pm parking is free. I plan to take the bus. Possible post-tour discussion and libation at Six Arms McMenamins on Pike and Melrose (10 minute walk from the Hospital) . Please let us know if you are considering attending the post-tour debrief. Thanks to Justin M. for arranging this special Field trip

column2: CANCELLED - South Sound Current Drift Dive
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.7 ebb > 3:45 PM slack > 2.7 flood (South Narrows, mid-stream). Planning on doing this as a drift dive, south > north. Splash about 2:15 -2:30. This is a very long swim exposed to current the whole time. You need good navigation skills, good air consumption, and a familiarity with Day Island already to know where to get out, and how to bail if there are problems. Open to experienced DIW divers only unless you get cleared by me first. If you meet these criteria, you know the drill and I'll see you there. Fritz 205-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

Underwater Pumpkin Carving! Prizes! Food! Hilarity! It's the 2015 Underwater Pumpkin Carving Contest. This year is special because FIVE clubs are gathering together to compete for bragging rights. Scheduled to attend are the Boeing Seahorses, Moss Bay Dive Club and the UW Underdawgs (Go Huskies!) and, of course Marker Buoy Dive Club, plus the latest addition Emerald Sea Dive Club. Rules, you ask? We are using the Helsinki Convention of the International Underwater Pumpkin Carving Rules this year: • Buddy teams for diving and carving. • Any implements can be used as long as they can be sheathed. • BYOP - Bring your own pumpkin. • Pumpkins must be intact prior to carving. Designs may be stenciled on the gourd but the skin cannot be pierced. • Minimum carving depth is 10 feet. Meet at 0830, briefing at 0930, splash at 1000 and all submissions are due on the deck at 1100. Marker Buoy is providing pre-dive goodies and The Seahorses and Moss Bay are doing the post dive refreshments. HINT: Bring a goodie bag and extra weights to help submerge and stabilize your pumpkin. A scholarly article from the October 2014 newsletter offers some insight on this process. Judging is accomplished by recruiting random passers-by so feel free to stack the deck in your favor by encouraging friends and family to come root for your pumpkin. Any questions? Please let me know what I can tell you.

2.2 flood > 3PM slack > 1.1 ebb. Day Island is not cooperating (except on the weekend Joyce is hosting Sunrise) so back to Skyline. Splash about 2:30+. Usual drill: Advanced dive with a long swim, in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not). When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. I've been reminded to tell divers they should have a cutting tool and be aware of fishing line. The path along the shore is used by fisherman. With the complexity of the bottom and the poor viz, especially in the shallower areas, running into line is a real possibility. Parking can be an issue, strongly suggest carpooling, which helps with the longer drive also. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby WA. Park before coming over. Plan on a debrief in town after the dive. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column2: Annapolis Wreck Dive, Howe Sound, BC
column5: This is a charter dive with Sea Dragon Charters to go dive the wreck of the Annapolis. This is a one-day affair, drive up Saturday morning, do TWO dives on the Annapolis and come back the same day. No hotels required. If we can get six people to go, then we get the club discount of 103.95 Canadian (currently $79.81 US). The Annapolis is a Canadian military vessel that was made into an artificial reef in April of this year. Still has that new-wreck smell. The bridge is in about 50 feet of water, the bottom of the rudder is at 110 feet. I've been on this site three times this year; it is suitable for all experienced divers (I would not recommend this for new divers, you want a good SAC rate and good buoyancy control). You ascend and descent along an anchor line; safety stops are not a problem. Only members in good standing with the country of Canada need apply. :) Information about the ship is at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMCS_Annapolis_(DDH_265 ) UPDATE - July 24th: The following link takes you to a depth chart for the Annapolis. http://artificialreef.bc.ca/images/265_Annapolis/Annapolis_Depths.pdf UPDATE - July 31st: Here is a link to where the Sea Dragon Charter is located in the marina (marked with the letter A on this page). In the summer they dock at the east end of the marina and on the west end in the winter. When you enter the parking lot, head east to the end of the lot and unload your gear. http://binged.it/1LVI9CH On your way up, head towards the Horseshoe Bay Ferry Terminal, but stay to the left and head to "Horseshoe Bay Village" (some signs read just "Village". You will need to park your car after you unload. Here is some information about parking in Horseshoe Bay Village. http://seadragoncharters.com/wp-content/uploads/seadragon-horseshoe-bay.pdf UPDATE - September 15th I just sent you all an email using the email addresses you have listed on your MBDC Membership pages. If you did not receive an email from me, send a note to me at johndo88@gmail.com and I'll send you a copy. For you two who are bringing a +1, please forward a copy to your friend. For me anyway, October can't come soon enough. :) UPDATE - October 19th For once, Monday is a good day, we'll all be on the Annapolis THIS SATURDAY. By now I hope you all have: 1. Printed and completed a copy of the Assumption of Risk and Release of Liability form. 2. Paid Sea Dragon directly for your spot, making sure that they know that you are a member of the Marker Buoy Dive Club. 3. Have printed out a map or configured your GPS. 4. Understood and collected the documentation you need for a border crossing (e.g., Passport or Enhanced Drivers License). 5. Gotten psyched up what should be a great wreck dive. Cheers John *** IMPORTANT UPDATE *** - October 21st The air compressor on the Topline is down for repairs. Unknown if the parts will be available in time for our dive. Plan on bringing TWO tanks just in case. If they get it fixed at the last minute then we can leave our extra tanks in the car.

column4: 28203 Redondo Beach Dr S · Des Moines
column5: Hello everybody! Noting that we don't have a Friday morning slacker dive on the calendar I have decided it would be a perfect time to host my first dive. The plan is to meet at Redondo at 9 AM and splash ~9:30 AM. This is a great dive for divers of all skill levels and a good site for photography of small critters. Of special note a small Pacific Skate has been hanging out in the area near the far buoyancy rings for the past few weeks.
Slack is at 8:30.....Come join in and see what critters are roaming around at night.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Intermediate to Advanced dive due to possible current and long walk to beach. Consider whether you are in shape or willing to take on the long hill walk. Splash is between 2:25 and 2:40 P. Be sure to arrive in time to get your gear together and make the walk to the beach. Its all worth it. One of the best dive in the Sound. Wolfeels, GPO, and so much more. There will be a debriefing at Spiro's in Gig Harbor after the dive.

San Juan Boat dive! Date: Saturday October 17th. The price is $95 per person and must be paid in advance. The plan is to meet at the boat at 8:00 AM so we can load all the gear and leave by 8:30 AM. Expect to return about 4:00 PM. The first site we are planning to dive is...... Dinner Rock and 2nd dive will be determined based on weather. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com for more information and directions to the boat. Thanks, Bruce Brown 425 512-7457 Cell 425 334-7763 Home

Three Tree nite dive. Meetup 6:30pm with a 7:15 splash. Have working primary and secondary lights. Tank light is recommended. To keep the peace with the neighbors, this dive is limited to 10 divers. Recommend carpooling if possible.

What: Memorial Gathering for Ken Gatherum When: Saturday, October 10th, 2015 at 12:00 PM Where: Myra's home Details: Please join us to gather together to honor our dive buddy and friend Ken Gatherum. The event is a potluck lunch with MBDC providing the plates, napkins, cups and utensils. BYOB as well. Since Myra lives near Redondo, she suggested that a pre-party dive might be fun. She offers gear rinsing at her home to facilitate attending the party post dive. Pictures of Ken are still appreciated so if you have any, please send them to Myra. Any questions, please feel free to ask me. Thanks, all, in advance. Andrea

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: In honor of Ken there will be a 2 tank dive at Redondo. 1st meetup is at 7:00am with a 8:00am splash. The 2nd meetup is at 9:30am, for those who cannot get their tushy out of bed early, with a 10:30am splash. Myra has offered her garden hose to wash out our gear should you want to. I don't think she is offering free air fills though. Come do this one for Ken.

column5: All diver, slacker diver dive at Redondo Beach. The tide is in, the tide is out. Well, it shouldn't be too bad- low but flooding. Much to see at this site. Meet time at 9am, splash at 9:45. Full facilities here plus ample parking, either on street or minimal pay parking.

column5: All diver, slacker diver dive at Edmonds Underwater Park. Much to see at this site. See the big fish before they begin lunching or munching on divers. It will be a high tide so expect a bit of a surface swim. Meet time is 11am, splash at 11:45. Great facilities on site.

2.7 flood >11:33 slack > 0.6 ebb - should be a decent exchange. Hopefully the viz will be better for this than the spring dives. Splash ~ 11 AM. Advanced dive with a long swim, in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible (hopefully not). When it's good it's one of the best invert shore dives in the Sound, lots of color and great things to see. Possibilities for candy stripe shrimp, PS King Crab, juv. wolf eels, and GPO. Parking can be an issue, strongly suggest carpooling. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby WA. Park before coming over. Plan on a debrief in town after the dive. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

All divers, slacker dive at Three Tree. Expect a high tide, short walk to the water. Much to see at this site. Meet time is 9am, splash at 9:45. No facilities here so do your business before you arrive.

Junkyard nite dive. Meetup 6pm, splash at 6:30pm. Have gear setup upon arrival for a quick entry or come earlier and setup at your own leisure. Have working primary and secondary lights. Tank light is recommended. The site has a line at 50ft leading N&S from the white buoy. Most divers go north. Once you reach the end or get down to 1500psi head east into the eel grass starting at 22ft. Head south doing your safety stop between 15-20ft. The grass offers shelter to a variety of critters. The key is to go slow to see them. Skates, Sea spiders and stubby squids have been found here before.

IMPORTANT - This is Oyster Run weekend > hoards of motorcycles converging on Anacortes. We've done this before and it didn't affect the dive much but going into town after unless we just want to walk the sidewalks and observe the 'characters' makes a debrief/dinner in town a lot more challenging. But that could be a fun option for awhile. Don't want to make the trek to Hood Canal? Take the drive to Skyline for a wall/invert dive. I figure people won't want to do both. 2.7F > 4:35 slack > 1.1E - should be a decent exchange. Hopefully the viz will be better for this than the spring dives. Splash ~ 4-4:15 PM. Advanced dive with a long swim, in current, with current possible the whole dive. Poor visibility while in current possible. Parking can be an issue, strongly suggest carpooling. No facilities-stop in Anacortes or nearby WA. Park before coming over. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

column3: Glen Ayr Resort on Hood Canal
column5: Ken Gatherum and I have scheduled Pacific Adventure's Down Time for both Saturday and Sunday. In addition I will be hosting a dive at Sund Rock on Sat 09/26 and there is an unhosted dive at Sund Rock on Sun 09/27. Great opportunities for photography and critter viewing. We plan to stay at Glen Ayr Resort, which has both RV spots and rooms. There are barbeques and a hot tub at the resort. I have stayed there many times and it is a great place to access Pleasant Harbor Marina and Sund Rock. Ken has written a great description with full details of the weekend and provided links to Pacific Adventure, Glen Ary Resort and Hoodsport 'N Dive at: https://www.dropbox.com/s/6c8x6t2j5irmxva/Hood%20Canal%20-%20Sept%202015.pdf

All diver, Friday slacker dive. Very low tide on this day makes for some maneuvering at the water's edge to avoid spills. Check out some of the out-of-reach deep areas due to the low tide. Much to see here, even if you decide to stay shallow. Parking is always a challenge, but should be easily gotten on a weekday. Meet time is 9am, splash at 9:45. Facilities on site make this a great place to dive.

column4: 1453 Ozette Drive Fi · Fox Island, WA
column5: For experienced current divers, please. This is a current sensitive dive. This will be my first time at this site so I'm relying on published sources for ledge location and directions. The layered sandstone ledges I will focus on are south of the fishing pier at Fox Island Fishing Pier parking site. Ledges seem to be between 15 ft and 80ft. There is a restroom on site. You will also find a 15 stair steps and then 125 paces down a straight hill to the cobblestone beach. There are few logs on shore for staging and rigging your gear if you choose to do so at the water's edge. We'll be diving at slack before a flooding tide with max current adjacent on either side at 1.7 knots. Slack is 4:53 pm. So, meet at 3:30 pm and splash at 4:23ish for an hour long dive. Depending on time of exit, Fox Island West Wall is less than 5 miles from East Wall and consists of a modest wall and breakdown of firmer rock up to 6 feet tall with several small and large nooks and crannies. Second tank dive is possible at West Wall, and you might be able to shuttle to that site in your dry suit :-) Slack at West Wall is at 6:17pm. There is parking available to 5 vehicles if no other vehicles are already there. Please consider carpooling. Thanks :-)

Planning party is set for the 20th from 12 - 3pm. Snacks and pop will be provided as well as paper plates and utensils. If you are new to the club, this would be a good way to meet other club members and get some insights into hosting dives. You do not have to host a dive to attend, just come and mingle. Address is: 20917 118th place, Kent WA 98031 just one mile from Richard Sherman's house. Any questions call me: 206-931-2963

Advanced Dive Just south of Lincoln Park and the Fauntleroy Ferry dock in West Seattle, there are a couple of Street End beach access points, much like Three Tree Point directly to the south. I'm pretty sure the bottom is flat boring sand, much like Three Tree Point. What I have no idea of is how much "Habitat Enhancement" the locals have done over the years, like at Three Tree Point. Worse case scenario we're bored for an hour underwater. Best case scenario we find a brand new dive site! Calling this one an advanced dive due to the unknown nature of this dive, for the first look only experience advanced divers please. There are two different sites so opportunity to do two dives if you are so inclined. Meet up at my house about 5 minutes away so we can carpool down and reduce impact on the neighbors.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: All diver, Friday slacker dive. Best time to visit the park is early, and on a weekday to avoid the parking crunch. Much to see here; big and small. Meet time is 9am, splash at 9:45. Dive plan is to see the remnants of the Triumph and the large pontoon structure, and everything in between.

Nootka Sound Dive Trip Preliminary itinerary and cost. Date: Leave early Sept 17th 2015 and arrive in the evening. Catch the 10:00 AM Tsawwassen Ferry to Duke Point then a four hour drive to Nootka Sound of which 1 ½ hours are on a gravel road. Dive: Sept 18, 19 & 20, 2015 3 Dives Friday and Saturday, 2 dives on Sunday then boogie for home. You will get home very late so you may want to stay the night in route. Cost: About $520 per person (best guess based on quoted B&B and dive boat rates. Includes: Room, breakfast each morning and diving. Air fills are additional. Price does not include Ferry and transportation to Nootka Sound. Ferry cost is about $140 each way. Tahtsa Dive Charter web site: http://www.tahtsadivecharters.com (http://www.tahtsadivecharters.com/) Nootka Gold B&B Bed web site: http://www.nootkagold.com
I only have time for one dive on Sunday, but I really need to swim with the fishes... and other sea creatures. All divers welcome. Meet at 9am and splash at 10. This will be on an ebbing tide.

All diver slacker Friday dive at 3 Tree Point North. The viz has been great lately. Slip away from work and connect with other slackers. Much to see here. No facilities so make your pitstop in advance of arriving. Meet at 9:00am, splash at 9:45.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

All divers dive at Three Tree Point. Much to see at this dive site. Come and see the remnants of the GPO on eggs, or see some local rat fish doing their thing. Meet time at 9:00am, splash at 9:45. Parking can be cramped at times. Car pool if possible. No facilities on site so be sure to find a bathroom on the hill before arriving.

Join Sue Bream, Steve Metzner and me for two days of diving in beautiful Howe Sound. Day 1 will include two dives with Sea Dragon Charters. Day 2 will include two shore dives near Horseshoe Bay. The Horseshoe Bay Motel is a short walk from the marina where we will board the Sea Dragon's Topline, a large comfortable dive boat. You will get a discount if you mention Sea Dragon Charter when you make a hotel reservation. The hotel contact information is: 604-921-7454 http://www.horseshoebaymotel.ca/ You will also need to book with Sea Dragon Charter at 604-329-3486 http://seadragoncharters.com/contact/ Candidate sites for day 2 shore dives are all a short drive from Horseshoe Bay: - Whycliffe Park - Kelvin Grove - Porteau Cove

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: All diver Friday slacker dive. Much to see at Redondo when it isn't raining. Fingers crossed on this one. Meet time at 9:00am, splash at 9:45. On street or nominal paid parking available.
