Some pretty big tidal exchange (13ft on the flood) on this day, so Three Tree is a good choice. Meetup 5pm, splash 6pm and slack at 6:30pm.. I'd like to do a 2nd if there is any interest. I will bring a second tank just in case.

Ebb 1.2 kt -> 7:45pm -> Flood 1.7 kt. My first foray to Fox Island for diving. West Island wall can be described as more of a series of rock ledges at 50-65 ft depths where there are potential hiding places for Octopus and wolf-eel. Plenty of other creatures from the wall to the shallows as per Fischmaller's description. No facilities in this residential area. Limited parking, please carpool if attending. Meet at 6pm. Orientation to dive site shortly thereafter. Splash at 7:15pm.
I'm doing two dives at Three Tree in case anyone is interested. Meet 2pm. "this is not a hosted dive. Every person for himself, kinda dive"

Hey Marker Buoy folks! Once again, the folks at the Edmonds Beach Ranger program have invited us to help them with a fantastic educational marine science program. The Moonlight Beach Adventure and the Marker Buoy Dive club will once again be the hit of the evening at Edmonds Marina Beach Park. We've been doing this gig for a number of years. The past few years has seen over 300-350 people show-up to learn about what we see as divers. We divers are there to collect and help show/interpret local marine life that we carefully place into "pools' right at the beach. Working closely with the Beach Rangers, we need teams of divers to get out a few hours before sunset to bring in the cool critters. Just after sunset, we'll do a live streaming video event from just offshore at the Marina Beach Park. Randy Williams will be using a live video cam along with a full face mask to show and comment about what is right offshore. The live show is shown on a big screen right at the beach! The Beach Rangers are the MC's for the show. People come from all over to watch this event. It's a huge hit! here's the link: http://www.edmondswa.gov/calendars/city-calendar/event/344-moonlight-beach-adventure.html We need divers and friends to help collect and to assist with the gear set-up and removal. The Marine Science & Tech Center (MaST) co-sponsors by loaning us the camera and comm gear that I use for my monthly Live Dive program. Please join in. It's a fantastic opportunity for the Marker Buoy Dive Club to help with a marine science education program. Get there early to give yourself time to find parking. Bring a picnic dinner too! Randi and I usually try to arrive close to 5pm to set-up and relax with a picnic.

While cycling around Alki today I noticed rather favorable visibility. I've now an itch to go in at Three Tree and see how momma octo and her hatchlings are doing. Meet at 7:30 and splash at 8pm. Must have second light source and tank light.

column2: Alki, Cove II - after work splash
column5: The dive site is protected from major current. Meet at 6:30, in the water when all are ready. Can tailor the dive to the comfort zone of divers that show up, but a typical cruise would be to head out the buoys defining the no-go zone for the ferry, look for GPOs in the usual places, take a depth heading towards the I-Beams (again that depth being determined by who shows up) scanning the silt for Stubby Squid, pop down to the I-Beams to see what treasures are at the end, then up to the plumose covered pilings near what used to be the Honey Bear wreck. We typically find a few Decorated Warbonnets there, often fully out. Then swim back to the entrance with a long and interesting safety stop. For your convenience, have arranged for the tide to be high for an extremely easy entrance and exit. The park has bathrooms, and a shower to rinse gear. Parking however? That's the toughest part. You may have to circle a few times or take street parking. 2015-08-18 Tue 1:52 PM PDT 2.0 feet Low Tide 2015-08-18 Tue 8:16 PM PDT Sunset 2015-08-18 Tue 8:21 PM PDT 10.9 feet High Tide Bottom line is, I need to splash! Do you?
2 went

4xT's Dive (Three Tree Three Tank dive) All Divers. Slack is at 8:19am before a 12 foot flood. Meetup is 8am with a 9am splash. 2nd dive approx. 11-11:30am and 3rd dive 1pm. Those wishing to do later dive plan your arrival accordingly. Expect current, but nothing we can't manage. Come see the Octo on eggs. The hatching time is drawing near and if we're lucky we'll be there for it. If not, there are plenty of interesting things to look at. Ever see a swimming Anemone? Their there. If you are interested in becoming a REEF member, this site has a good variety of fish to help you develop you fish identification skills. Navigation is easy and the bottom is more cobble stone, so not as much silt as you would see at Cove 2 or Redondo. Parking is limited, carpooling is strongly advised. No restrooms, so plan wisely. If you are doing multiple dives recommend bringing food and drinks.

column4: 1321 Bay View Avenue · Neah Bay, WA
column5: Opening for 2 - 4 divers for Neah Bay. Itinerary The plan is make three dives on Wednesday & Thursday and two dives on Friday then head for home. If someone wants, we can do a shore dive at the Seiku Jetty in the afternoon of the 11th. Lu-Jacs will have breakfast snacks (coffee cake, fruit) out in the morning along with coffee, tea or hot chocolate. They will also provide lunch on the boat each day. Space is limited to 10 divers and will be on a first come basis. Depart Tuesday Aug 11th Price: $130 per day or $390 for all 3 days. Price is for charter only. Accommodations, food, transfers and permits are your own responsibility. Tip for deck hand is additional. Meals: . Most rooms have kitchenettes for cooking but there is a restaurant within walking distance of the hotel and one in Neah Bay. Both will be open before the boat meet time in the morning. We usually eat breakfast in Neah Bay before each dive day. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Air Fills: Available at Curley’s Resort but NO nitrox is available and you will need to have 3 tanks for Wednesday and Thursday. Hotel / Lodging: You need to book your place to stay as soon as possible, as accommodations are limited.www.curleysresort.com (http://www.curleysresort.com/) Dives Another option would be to camp or hotel it in Neah Bay. Contact: Bruce Brown 425 512-7457 Cell or e-mail @ brownb329@aol.com

column2: YO YO YOYs! Pacific Northwest Young of the Year Rockfish ID
column5: YOY (Young of the Year) Rockfish ID: Learn tips from REEF Expert and fish geek, Janna Nichols, on how to identify Young of Year (yearlings) Rockfish you'll see when diving the Pacific Northwest. This short, fun fishinar won't make your brain explode with fish overload - just the right amount of info! If you are not already a member of REEF, you will need to join (it's free!) and receive your REEF member number to complete the registration. Register here: https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/5984576185166345730

Dive! Eat! Socialize! It's a Summer trifecta. Potluck grillfest -- Bring stuff to grill and salad/sides/stuff to share. More details to follow as the date nears. Updated info -- Meet at 0900, splash at 0945, and 1230. Dive sites are BOTH the Lighthouse (general diving) and the Silver Cloud (for crabbing).

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center Our scheduled guest speaker WAS Mike Bartick, manager of the Crystal Blue Resort in Anilao, Philippines... Mike has just informed me that he must cancel his appearance in Seattle! Not to worry, though! Fritz, Joyce Judi Brooks & I spent a marvelous week together in March at Anilao, and will present the fabulous & hilarious macro videos produced by fellow Dive traveler Moses Ong... If you are interested in diving this area, or wish to learn more about the phenomenal creatures to be found while "muck diving", then be sure to attend this meeting!

1.3 flood > 3:42 slack > 0.2 ebb - Fidalgo Head-Burrows Island Between Small exchange having the right parameters. Should be good but could 'break'. Splash ~ 3:15. Advanced drift/current dive to a rocky slope covered with invertebrates. When it's good it's beautiful. Long swim to the drop site. There will be current, You need to be comfortable with current and long swims. Depths down to 85-90', but you can choose your depth. Visibility can be limited. Seems to be a lot of extra snow and glacial melt. No facilities. Use something in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park. Expect a 90 minute drive from N. Seattle. Weed side parking is gone so parking could be limited. Carpooling strongly encouraged. This is peak summer parking competition up there. If people are up for it we'll hit town for debriefing after the dive, which is always fun. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 205-370-4720 cell
Looking for a dive buddy to do a mapping project of Cove 2 for my Dive Master program. 1 dive. Meet at 1pm. Splash at 1:30pm before high tide. Note that the weather forecast says 50% chance of rain.

column4: 28299 Redondo Beach Dr S · Des Moines, WA
column5: If you didn't get enough Dive Around the Clock at Redondo, come dive it again Wednesday, July 22. Meet at 7pm, splash at 8pm. Sunset is at around 9:00pm and tide is flooding. Redondo is generally not a current sensitive site. Some free parking on the street, otherwise there is paid parking: 2 hours= $2.50, 3 hours = $3.50. The parking ticket machine does not make change, but does take debit cards.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

Aloha MB divers, Possession point is primed for a 2 tank dive. There will be an eleven foot flowed starting about 2pm with slack at 2:48pm. Meetup will be 11:30am, 1st splash is 12:30pm. 2nd splash anytime after surface interval. Sorry, this is for advance divers only The Mukilteo to Whidbey Island Ferry leaves every 1/2 hr. Recommend you take into consideration the possible long wait for the ferry, also carpool if at all possible. Recommend bringing some snack foods and drink along. I will get the special permit and combination number and contact those who sign up. **Note: was told that there is metered parking at lighthouse park and its only for 4 hours. Make needed carpool adjustments if you had planned to park there.**

Meet at 08:00 AM and splash when ready You will need a crabbing license and a goodie bag. We will go to the oil dock if demolition process hasn’t started yet. Access to the oil dock was still open last weekend.

column3: Redondo Beach Dr S & Redondo Way
column4: Redondo Beach Dr S & Redondo Way · Des Moines, Wa
column5: This has been a fabulous event for NINE (yep, 9) years. This may be the last DATC as the founders, Kyle Larson and Larry Trenda, have decided to (hopefully) pass the torch to a new set of sponsors. It's been a very successful run for a little 'ol group of Puget Sound divers who put their hearts into helping to raise funds for pediatric cancer research at Seattle Children's Hospital and their research facilities. Go to their webpage to get the details and to sign-up to dive at this great event. http://divearoundtheclock.com/ It's really worth your time. Randi and I have been involved with this group for eight years now. It's fun!

column2: Dive and BBQ at Karin and Doug's (plus diving planning party)
column4: 6074 Wynn Jones Rd E · PORT ORCHARD, WA
column5: Time for our annual dive and BBQ at our place. We live on Rich Passage near Port Orchard on Kitsap Peninsula. We'll be doing a mild drift dive out front with a splash time around 3pm. After the dive we'll host a potluck BBQ. Bring something for the grill, something to share and drinks. Bring lawn chairs if you can. Car pooling is encouraged as parking is limited. Non-divers are also welcome to come and enjoy the beach, kayak etc. We are also going to use this event as a diving planning party as Catherine and Steve have had to cancel the July dive planning party. Bring you ideas and plans for future dives and enter them in Meetup while you are here. You can get to our place via the Fauntleroy - Southworth ferry or drive around via the Tacoma Narrows bridge. We'll provide an update on recommended ferry times and other details closer to the day.

Meet at around 5pm for a 6pm splash late afternoon dive. It might still be hot so consider bringing extra water to pour over your head before walking down to the water. Tide will be low and on the flood when we splash.

Meet at 11:30 AM, splash 12:00 PM. Low tide -2.3ft at 1:12pm. 1-tank dive (for me at least). Features Small Wreck, Debris, Structures, Description This is the most popular of the Alki dive sites and an all-around great dive park. It is protected from major current and has lots of life in shallow water. If you are on the beach looking out there is a boat just inside the marker line at about 45ft. To the right you can find a decent sized boat called the Honey Bear in about 35 ft, near the base of a bunch of pilings that are angled out of the bottom. Several other piles of boulders and Pilings are scattered around this site. More experienced divers can venture to deeper depths to see the I-beams. Follow the rope under the buoy line to about 85 ft where it starts to turn North (to the left). Turn Right and hold that depth and you'll come across them quickly. There are a couple other small sunken boats and piles of rocks that are interesting to see on the way. Special Restrictions: You MUST stay outside of the buoy line. This is an active ferry/water taxi dock. There is a rope on the bottom with some bottles floating on it that marks the buoy line so that you can avoid crossing it. How to get there: From Seattle, take the west Seattle bridge to the Harbor Ave SW Exit and take a right on Harbor Ave SW. Follow it 1.3 miles along the water until you come to the fish-n-chips restaurant and the water taxi parking lot. You can either park in the lot or on the street. The South Side of the restaurant is Cove 2. Cove 1 is to the North side of the restaurant. Gear up and walk down to the water.

column5: Our second biggest social event of the year. The Annual Picnic is Wed, July 1st, 6-10 PM. Click on the address above to get close. It's off W. Green Lake Dr. N. at the north end of Green Lake, across from the Put-Put Golf course and the Old Aqua theater. Turn up the hill near the tennis courts and make the first left at the top of the hill. It is also easily accessible from 99N. This link will get you closer. http://www.seattle.gov/parks/_images/maps/picnics/Woodland4-7.pdf BBQ/potluck/BYOB. The Club will have the grills going and provide plates and plastic cups+utensils. Bring something to cook for yourself and something to share with the group. Should you like the elegance of glass for your beverage you need to bring that yourself. Alcohol is not allowed in parks so discretion is required. I WILL call Parks and will have the nearby bathroom open this year. No electricity. We will have a glass/aluminum and compost recycle containers this year. Please use them. Hopefully Weather be great! Do come, the more members, the better time we have. I am looking forward to it! Mark

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: I haven't been here since March, time to see how the wolfies are doing. Big tidal swings on weekends so has to be mid-week. But, this one is really nice: 2.5F > 1:18PM slack > 1.5E. If the dive is as good as the numbers it should be great. This will be an 11AM meet for an 11:45 splash. Sweet, allows morning rush hour traffic to go away, before lunch hour, and we should get out of there before the afternoon rush hour. Hows that for planning? Day Island rules apply: This is a possibly excellent exchange but it is still an advanced current dive on a wall with a lot of exposure. You need some current diving experience (drifting in Cozumel barely counts), good buoyancy, strong legs, and the ability to deal with current, depth, and potentially poor viz. If you aren't sure you are up to this level, you should talk to me first. The reward is a wall full of wolf eels and GPO. No facilities. Titlow has a nice bathroom and there are places up on the hill before you drop down. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell

This dive will be limited to 8 divers in an effort to maintain good relations with the local residents. Carpool if possible. Three Tree dusk dive. 7:30pm meetup, 8:15pm splash, slack at 8:45pm. Bring primary and secondary lights, tank light advised. You must have night dive experience

column2: North End Dive Part Two - Mukilteo (Hotel Site)
column5: MEET: 7:00pm SPLASH 7:30pm TIDES: Mild Ebb of 2-3/4 feet from 3:15 pm to 8:17 pm. HAZARDS: From the entry point, go north. South takes you to the ferry terminal. Another evening dive. Weather forecast is for no rain, temps about 60. Sunset at 9:10 This is an excellent dive for ANY SKILL LEVEL. GeoDome at about 60 feet. Fuel dock run for the scooter folks. Deeper dive for those so trained (e.g., meet the Mukilteo Man at about 110 feet). Entry side is at the north end of the Silver Cloud Inn in Mukilteo. Bing map at http://binged.it/1B0LP3B PARKING: Be prepared to pay for parking. This change occurred on June 1st.

column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: An entire underwater park devoted to divers! Can't beat that. This is a great dive for beginners and a lot of fun for divers of all levels. Slack is around 7pm, so let's try to be in the water between 6:30pm and 6:45pm.

Two tank dive at Three Tree, open to all divers. There is no restroom at this site, so plan ahead. Very limited parking so carpooling is recommended. 1st dive meetup 3:45pm, splash 4:30pm. 2nd dive meetup 5:45pm, splash 6:30pm .

column2: West Seattle Twilight REEF Survey Dive
column5: Whether you have done the REEF training or not, come on out for a twilight dive at the "Junkyard". Surveys are optional but I'll have survey sheets for those who want to do one. Should be a nice dive with little current. Bring a light. We'll meet at 6:30pm and plan to splash around 7pm. Slack is at 7:39pm.

Possibly the last Deception Pass dive of the year. This is Memorial Day. Parking is a day use area. It's early enough in the day that driving and parking should not be a problem. We'll be done with the dive and apres dive briefing to be ahead of the 3-day weekend traffic I think. The may be more fisherman than normal, mostly a problem in the entry zone. Experienced, advanced current divers only! This is not the dive to learn on. If you aren't sure don't show up without contacting me first. 3.8F > 10AM > 5.4E - Splash about 9:30 AM. You should be in the water and waiting for it by then. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, and seldom has great viz. But, you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. Good parking, restroom on site, 150 yard walk to the water. Discover Pass required.
4 went
Dave Ballard
Kimber Chard
Two dives. One at 5 and one at 7. Come and get wet.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

Experienced, advanced current divers only! This is not the dive to learn on. 3.7F > 9:32AM > 5.56E - Splash about 9 AM. You should be in the water and waiting for it by 9. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, and seldom has great viz. But, you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. Good parking, restroom on site, 150 yard walk to the water. Discover Pass required. I went through most of the year looking for DP dives. There are about 10 that match a pretty safe profile and of course some are mid-week. All are April-May. If you don't get a dive in during that time, you probably will not.

The tides and current are not cooperating this month, so I am hoping there are diver's willing to raise very early and dive Junkyard, which will leave the rest of the day for play. Junkyard meetup 4am, splash 4:40am. Slack is 4:37am going into a very weak flood. We should be done and gone by 6:30 am, leaving you the rest of the day to play or go back to sleep. Come with gear partly setup to minimize any delays going in and as usual have working, primary, secondary and tank lights.

Want to get involved in doing critter surveys for REEF? Here's your chance to get some critter ID training, get REEF certified and do some diving. We are holding a two day REEF event at Salt Water State Park on May 2 and 3 which will include classes in the event room at the park and diving as well as socializing. Here is the tentative schedule: May 2nd - 12pm Fish class - 3:30pm Fish quiz - 5pm Dive and survey (focus on fish) - 6:30pm Potluck dinner at the park and review surveys - Folks can camp and stay the night or go home, then… May 3rd - 8am Invertebrates Class - 11:45am Dive and survey (focus on fish and inverts) - 1pm Invert quiz, BYO lunch and review surveys - 2pm Finish Attendees can buy REEF materials during the classes. These include: - REEF Starter Kit - Everything You Need To Survey - ($38.00 each) Starter Kit Region: Pacific Northwest (w/deluxe white slate) - REEF Waterproof Identification Cards - ($8.00 each) ID Card Region: Pacific Northwest Invertebrates - REEF Waterproof Identification Cards - ($8.00 each) ID Card Region: West Coast US & Canada Fishes - Waterproof Survey Paper - ($0.75 each) Survey Form Region: Pacific Northwest and Alaska Please bring cash to the event for the items you want to buy. Classes will be given by Rhoda Green and Doug Miller. Space is limited so RSVP soon to reserve your spot. I will update this Meetup if arrangements change. If you have questions submit them in the discussion area here. For more information on REEF, see my presentation from the March meeting here: http://files.meetup.com/6196802/REEF-2015-MBDC.pptx

column2: UW Photo Workshop with Eiko Jones in Nanaimo
column5: Want to work on improving your u/w photo composition with coaching from one of the best photographers in the PNW, at a great dive location? Check this out! Travel to Nanaimo: It’s a two hour drive to the Tsawwassen ferry followed by a beautiful 2-hour ferry ride to Nanaimo. Accommodations at Marina Side Resort: We several 2-bedroom luxury suites reserved at highly discounted prices of CAD$238 per night (that's about US$188). Each suite has two bedrooms, two bathrooms, washer/dryer and a fully stocked kitchen. The resort is located on the same pier as the Sea Dragon so there is no need to drive after you get there. Book directly with the resort and mention the Sea Dragon photo workshop to get the discounted price: Email: reservations@themarinasideresort.com Phone: 250.591.0880 Out of water workshop: Saturday morning Eiko will lead a walking photo workshop near the marina. Taking photos topside gives every an opportunity to receive coaching in a context where verbal communication is easy. Cost for the workshop is approximately $75 per person to cover Eiko’s travel costs and room rental. I will collect this in advance of the workshop. Dive on the Sea Dragon: We will do two dives on Saturday afternoon and two more on Sunday morning. The cost is CAD$109.95 and you can pay on the boat. Saturday evening dinner: Let's get pick one of the suites to share food, look as some photos and do some serious debriefing. Sunday afternoon: travel back to Seattle. (If folks want to add another day of diving, that's possible too.)
Kimber Chard

column5: Experienced, advanced current divers only! This is not the dive to learn on. 3.5F > 10:25AM > 5.4E - Splash about 10 AM. You should be in the water and waiting for it a little before 10. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, and seldom has great viz. column2: It's Scubarbeque, the MBDC Annual Banquet!
column5: Who: Marker Buoy Dive Club, the best dive buddies around. What: It's Scubarbecue, 2015's version of the MBDC Annual Banquet! When: April 25th, 2015 at 6:00 PM. Where: Sunset Hill Community Center Why: It's a time-honored tradition that MBDC herald the coming of Spring with our Annual Banquet. We assemble to enjoy socializing, eat some delicious food and take part in the raffle to win cool diving related prizes. The bar is BYOB. What's new for 2015? Get ready for some YUMMY barbecue. The caterer this year is Famous Dave's, the award-winning barbecue restaurant chain. Pretty cool, huh? Ticket prices are $35.00 per person. Raffle tickets are $1.00 each or 6 for $5.00. There will be more information as the date approaches. Save the Date!

column4: SW 3 tree point LN and SW 170th St. Burien WA · Burien, WA
column5: Three Tree one tank dive. 11am meetup with a 12pm splash, slack at 12:27pm. Tides are pretty crazy on this day. There will be a 14 foot ebb. We may need to bring our own sea water. Still should be fun. If anyone is interested in lunch afterwards, we can do Elliott Bay Pub. There will be live Hawaiian singing and hula dancing for your entertainment while you wait for the splash time. please bring your vivid imagination with you. Mahalo

3.2F > 6:22 PM > 1.0E, Splash ~6 PM; Sunset 8:06 PM Seems most of the acceptable Skyline profiles on the weekend are late in the afternoon like this. Skyline/Burrows Pass runs that way sometimes. With Burrows Is. blocking the setting sun this may be a twilight dive-bring a backup light. Advanced drift/current dive to a rocky slope covered with invertebrates. When it's good it's beautiful. Long swim to the drop site. There will be current, You need to be comfortable with current and long swims. Depths down to 85-90', but you can choose your depth. Visibility can be limited if much flooding is happening on the Skagit River. I suspect this will not be an issue this year. No facilities. Use something in Anacortes or nearby Washington Park. Expect a 1 1/2 hour drive from N. Seattle. Weed side parking is gone so parking could be limited. Carpooling strongly encouraged. If people are up for it we'll hit town for debriefing after the dive. Fritz 206-525-0736 home 205-370-4720 cell

column4: Oak Harbor, WA · Oak Harbor, WA
column5: Experienced, advanced current divers only! This is not the dive to learn on. 3.2F > 9:27AM > 5.56E - Splash about 9 AM. You should be in the water and waiting for it by 9. DP is a unique and spectacular dive, but it has the potential for high currents, whirlpools, severe up and down eddies, and seldom has great viz. But, you get an invertebrate dive that is unlike any other in Puget Sound. Good parking, restroom on site. Discover Pass required. I went through most of the year looking for DP dives. There are about 10 that match a pretty safe profile and of course some are mid-week. All are April-May. If you don't get a dive in during that time, you probably will not.

Salt Water State Park dive. It's been awhile since we have done one here. This site has 3 lengthy rockpiles, each running east and west, that will go down to 85ft. Expect either a very long walk or swim (100 yards or more depending on tide). You will need a park pass a day pass, that can be purchased for $10's at the park. Very clean restrooms and an outside shower that should be on to rinse off gear. Meetup 9am, Splash 10am with slack on the ebb at 10:30am. This is an advance level dive because the rockpile's doesn't start until 60ft. Lunch and social gathering afterwards at Red Robin, last two to RSVP pays, Just Kidding.
Go deep or stay shallow....Something for everyone. Octos, Wolfeels, Sailfin Sculpins, and Anemones....are almost certain to be found..... This dive will be on the middle of the flood.
Time again to gather together and share good food and fill the dive calender......

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 3.3E > 2:44 PM > 4.1F - Yup, that big. Experienced and Advanced only! This is a a pretty good sized exchange. It certainly isn't suitable for anyone not well seasoned in current or looking for a lazy Sunday dive. Come with your best fins, your trowel, and your can-do attitude ready for whatever Day Island can dish up. This is a semi-exploratory dive. I've done similar but not for awhile. Last one was like this (which I screwed up): [3.36E>2:41>3.9F DIW High Current Exploration My timing was seriously off due to daylight saving time and my general time/date, uh, challenges. The interesting and unexpected good news - we all did fine being almost an hour off slack on the largest current day I've tried yet on Day Island. This dive has more latitude then I've thought, I think.....maybe.] So, we are doing something pretty similar, and I think I have the daylight saving time issue addressed for this dive. At least I tried. Unbalanced exchange, we may get in a tad early. Weather right now looks to be decent. Not worried about parking, no one else will be there. Survivors will gather at Steamers to celebrate. Not sure if you should come? You best call me. 206-525-0736 home 206-370-4720 cell Fritz

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center: Our guest this month Is Doug Miller, our very own club secretary, who is also a member of REEF; REEF is one of the largest scuba diving-related volunteer organizations in the world. REEF provides divers with training and a system for conducting fish and invertebrate surveys during dives in locations around the world. Marker Buoy Dive Club is a REEF Field Station and a number of our members are active surveyors. Come out to this presentation given by Doug Miller to hear more about REEF including how to get involved, how the data is used, the perks of becoming a Level 5 surveyor, REEF expeditions and some fun facts you probably don’t know about REEF.

column2: Night dive at Edmonds underwater park
column5: Copy Meetup

Join us for this two day workshop that includes two classroom sessions and four dives in in the clear waters of Howe Sound aboard the Sea Dragon Topline. Topics covered in the classroom sessions will include UW photography basics, creating compelling compositions, post-dive image processing. In-water sessions will focus on dive skills for UW photographers such as refining buoyancy and trim, finning backwards, how to avoid silting up a photo site. The classroom sessions and dive charter dock are located in Horseshoe Bay, BC, a three hours drive from Seattle. Accommodations and several restaurants are available a short walk from the marina. Fills are available onboard the Topline. Participants may sign up for one or both days.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center; Our Guest is Jessie Huggins, who has been working with Cascadia Research since 2004. As Stranding Coordinator, she leads Cascadia's responses to stranded marine mammals throughout Washington State. She has also been involved with field work and other components of Cascadia's long-term blue, gray and humpback whale photo-ID projects. In tonight’s Program,“ Marine Mammals of the Greater Puget Sound”, she will cover how to identify local species, highlight current ongoing research projects and discuss human impacts on marine mammal species. She will also detail what to do and how to report a marine mammal sighting or stranding.

One tank Night dive Three Tree. Meetup 7:30pm (less traffic), splash 8 :15pm. Be sure to have working primary, backup and tank lights. Bring camera. There is always something really cool to get pictures of.

column2: South Sound Drift and Scooter Dive
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Calling all MB'ers with scooters. We've never really done many dives as a group so here is a chance to do so. DIW Drift dive from N entrance to the ledges and back. Narrows N end 2.17E >10:25AM >1.98F Meet at 8:30AM splash 9:30AM. For those with scooters this is a great site to put them to use. For those without it's still a great site it just requires a bit more effort. This is a moderate but not extreme exchange so for those who have current experience and want to get to know this site it is probably appropriate. One caveat; I am hosting the dive but I'm using my scooter so I will not be able to buddy with anyone who is not familiar with the site.

Splash at 10:15 - 10:30 for the first dive. There is a 7:55 am ferry from both Edmonds/Kingston and Seattle/Bainbridge. Kingston is 53 minutes from Point Hudson, and Bainbridge Island is an hour and eight minutes. Both will get you there in plenty of time. We'll be diving the small jetty and dolphins where we typically find everything from Octopus, juvenile Wolf eel, Grunt and Scalyhead Sculpin, Hairy & Butterfly Crab and the occasional Puget Sound King Crab. It's an easy entry and the currents allow for two dives. Park at the Northwest Maritime Center 431 Water Street Port Townsend, WA 98368 They have nice restrooms/changing facilities, and the chandlery makes a mean latté. View the currents (or a lack thereof) if you're interested: Point Hudson, 0.5 mile E of, Washington Current 48.1167° N, 122.7167° W Flood direction 115° True Ebb direction 10° True 2015-01-31 9:16 AM PST 0.57 knots Max Flood 2015-01-31 10:57 AM PST -0.00 knots Slack, Ebb Begins 2015-01-31 3:41 PM PST -0.66 knots Max Ebb 2015-01-31 5:08 PM PST Sunset 2015-01-31 6:34 PM PST 0.00 knots Slack, Flood Begins 2015-01-31 10:26 PM PST 1.95 knots Max Flood Plenty of options for libations post dive, Sirens is within walking distance.

column2: New Member's Delight, North Seattle 2 dives
column5: "New Members Delight Dive, do one or both dives". Meetup 8:45am, splash @ 9:45am, Slack @ 10:40am with a .1 kt current @ 12:00pm, on the flood. 2nd dive at approximately 1pm with slack @ 1:50pm on the ebb Edmonds park depth is a max of 40-45ft with rope lines to guide you. There is a wide variety of structures and sunken boats to explore as well as fish and critters to find and or photograph. Parking and restroom available. Showers are turned off in the winter. Recommend bring hot water to heat up gloves and hood for 2nd dive.
Douglas Coutts

column2: South Sound Drift and GPO Count
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Read this all before you just 'jump in' unless you you have already done the South > North Drift profile. 2.4 ebb > 11:07 AM >2.9 flood Splash ~ 9:50 AM. Medium exchange but a LONG swim in current with nothing but a compass and judgement to orient you. This can be very disorienting. The exposure to current is significant. That's why it's an advanced site. Drift from the south entrance to the north entrance, or just go out and back, your choice but you should be ready to change your decision based on conditions. This is often necessary and adds to the complexity of the dive. This is the most difficult profile on DIW due to the long swim, exposure to current and depth. You definitely want current experience and be comfortable with long swims on an exposed shelf. There is nothing to grab onto. I sometimes bring a plastic garden trowel. There is no boat to rescue you. You have to be competent to deal with the hazards this dive provides and respond in a safe way to them. If you are thinking, "Yeah, I'd like to gain some current experience", > don't come. You already NEED current experience to do this. Several dives on the North part of DIW are highly desirable first. Bring a slate to record depth and time specifics for GPO.
Andrew Eve

column2: South Sound Drift and GPO Count
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Read the description before you RSVP please. NOT for the uninitiated. This is a fair sized current swing. I consider it an advanced dive and not by the lame interpretation of PADI 'advanced'. Both current and DIW experience required. If you don't have it, don't come. 2.3F > 1:50PM > 3.9F - 11:15AM meet, ~ 12:15 splash. This is a south drifting dive with a big switch at the end. It brings you down toward South Bay where there is a potential for down and out current, in this case a stiff one. Not a good situation to be in. Bring your trowels (cheap stiff strong plastic garden trowels work fine on the DIW gravel slope, knives, not so much). Maybe bring a slate to record depth and time specifics for GPO. Been awhile since I've done this profile, looking forward to it.

column2: Drift north through Agate Pass on a 3 kt ebb...
column5: We'll board the 6:10 AM Seattle/ Bainbridge I. Ferry and proceed west to the Agate Pass Bridge, where we'll all turn right onto Reitan Road and park beneath the bridge. There are no comfort facilities there, so be forewarned! We'll enter the channel right about 8:50 am and ride the EBB current north and west to Old Man Park, a distance of about 1 nautical mile... Max depth here is about 40 ft, so if you are comfortable with river like currents, this dive is '4-U!' There's lots of beautiful invertebrate life here, and an interesting bunch of fish too...For you history aficionados, this is the home of Chief Sealth (for whom Seattle is mis-named) and is certainly a place where he 'watered the bushes' as a youth... Beware of the muddy spots! If a 2nd dive is desired, we can repair to Norrander's Reef, adjacent to Blakely Harbor, on the east side of Bainbridge I. not far from the Winslow Ferry, which we'll ride back to Seattle...

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: We're back! Here's the dive I promised after our last awesome night dive here. Need to previously have dived this site during the day. Otherwise this is an all diver dive. Keep in mind that most divers will be photographers. Site is known for its photo opportunities at night. Lots of small critters such as snailfish, octos and lumpsuckers in the shallows, oh my! Be sure to bring a backup light. Meet time is before the sun goes down but it will be dark by the time we splash. Splash around 5:30p.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center: Our Guest Speaker is member Dan Clements, accomplished world wide travel adventurer, who will regale us with his late summer trip to British Columbia, swimming with & filming spawning salmon. This is a little 'off the beaten path' of our normal style of diving, and promises to be both informative & entertaining. Let's crowd the hall for Dan!

Anybody free during the day tomorrow (Wed) to get in a nice dive? OK, does anyone want to find an excuse to get away from the job for an afternoon? Dive and then head to the club meeting. Meet at 1PM.

This is a fairly easy intermediate level dive. Visibility can be less than optimal and the depth is beyond beginner level at the far end of the underwater bridge structure. This is to be considered a wreck dive and if you choose to go under the bridge make sure you tie of a line to somewhere outside the structure as a silt out could be deadly. Here is a link about the dive..... http://www.nwdiveclub.com/viewtopic.php?t=190

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Lake WA is an unusual dive. If you have not done that you might want to pick that up today. I absolutely do not want to poach on Kimber's dive. If not, I have a short notice DIW dive; Advanced, current, wall (OK big shelves in this case) dive. 2.7E > 11:33 AM > 2.7F - Splash ~ 10:30. This is a North entrance, north and back dive. Mid-grade current, good for experienced folks, OK if you have a good number of dives under your belt and are looking to up your current experience a bit. Note on terminology. When I use the term [Advanced] I do not mean PADI/NAUI 'Advanced'. In my opinion getting through 'Advanced Class' is just about a minimum to be exploring Puget Sound at the 'Basic' level. The use of that term for an entry level class is both confusing and counterproductive. If you are not sure if this is a dive for you, email or call me. Limited Parking, no facilities, carpooling encouraged.

A two tank day at Possession Point SP. Plan on catching the 9:30AM Mukilteo ferry. Slack before flood at 11:00AM. Mild currents until it turns at 2:45PM. Carpooling recommended and Discover Pass required on all vehicles.

column4: 1372 S Engle Rd 48° 9.44' N 122° 40.27' W · Coupeville, WA
column5: Looks like the Canadian contingent is heading down to Keystone. Join the photography crew for underwater shooting and the usual over the top pot luck. Very little tidal exchange until early afternoon.

column2: Let's get one last dive in for the year!
column5: Go deep or stay shallow....Something for everyone. Octos, Wolfeels, Sailfin Sculpins, and Anemones....are almost certain to be found..... This dive will be on the end of a large ebb. A little longer walk to the water and a chance to see some of the deeper stuff we don't always get to on a high tide.
Meet at 08:00 AM and splash when ready You will need a crabbing license and a goodie bag.
Jonathan Saenz

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Jim M and I are doing a one tank Brunch dive at Redondo. This isn't a hosted dive, I just want a place for Jim and I to post our pictures. Join us if you'd like 10am meetup

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: I'm looking to do Sunrise Beach a little differently this time! Northwest Shore Dives says that if divers splash 30 minutes before the slack before flood at The Narrows (11:31 AM slack before flood minus 30 minutes = an 11:01 AM splash), they can drift south with the current to the rock ledge. Current direction at Sunrise, shortly after flood begins at The Narrows, will then start flowing northward, carrying divers back to the entry point. For this particular dive I think it would be best for divers who are familiar with Sunrise and who are comfortable with current to attend. The currents at The Narrows aren't particularly strong: going from a -2.1 ebb to a 2.3 flood. As always, there's quite a hill to contend with, and facilities include ample parking, one picnic bench, and a porta-potty.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Read this all before you just 'jump in' unless you are already familiar with this dive profile. 2.1 ebb > 10:40 AM > 2.1 flood Splash ~ 9 AM. This is a fairly low exchange but a LONG swim in current with nothing but a compass and judgement to orient you. The last time I did this profile expecting it to be an easy one we had ~ 1/2 knot the whole dive....all the way out. It didn't slack until the end of the dive. The 'wizard' misses it sometimes. You need the skill and judgement to save your own butt on this shore dive. Just saying...... That's why it's an advanced site. Drift from the south entrance to the north entrance, or just go out and back, your choice but you should be ready to change your decision based on conditions. This is the most difficult profile on DIW due to the long swim, exposure to current and depth. You definitely want current experience and be comfortable with long swims on an exposed shelf (nothing to grab onto-I sometimes bring a plastic garden trowel). If you have DIW experience (up north), and want to expand your options on south DIW this is a lower current exchange to give it a try.
Copy Meetup
6:00 meet and splash whenever you like. Current is not an issue at this site. It will be on a low tide. A little longer walk to the water.
Kevin Devine

column4: 1372 S Engle Rd 48° 9.44' N 122° 40.27' W · Coupeville, WA
column5: I need diver's......for 2 Keystone, Night dives on Saturday Dec 13th. I have obtained a special activity permit to allow Marker Buoy members an opportunity to do two night dives at Keystone. Meetup 4:30pm, 1st dive is 5:30pm. Max current on flood is 7:42pm @ .4kts. 2nd splash is 8:40pm with slack at 9:10pm. Restroom will be open. Ferry departures schedule is 10:30 and 11:30 pm back to Mukilteo. You must have night and current experience for this dive. Have Primary, secondary and tank lights. You can eat dinner during surface interval, I like KFC LOL
Meet at 08:30 AM and splash when ready You will need a crabbing license and a goodie bag.
Go deep or stay shallow....Something for everyone. Octos, Wolfeels, Sailfin Sculpins, and Anemones....are almost certain to be found...... Current should is usually not an issue.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Meet @ 9:45/ splash @ 10:30... Those interested may make a 2'nd dive before dark. This will be a good dive for practicing/ refreshing basic skills with your buddy... I will be available to mentor those asking for assistance... Randy W. reports that the MaST pier suffered some damage in last weekend's storm; should provide some interest... Lots of critters to see here: stubby squid, juvenile wolfies, sailfin sculpin & more...

column4: SW 3 tree point LN and SW 170th St. Burien WA · Burien, WA
column5: This dive is for all skill levels. Great spot to practice skills, work on your buoyance and weight issues if any. Three Tree is not current sensitive, so 8:30am meetup, 9:15am splash. 2nd splash at 11:45am, meetup 11am . Slack is 9:59am and 2:40pm. Current peak is 11:18am @ .2kts. We can debrief at the the Elliott Bay Pub afterwards. If your doing only one dive recommend the 11:45am dive, so you may attend the debriefing. No restroom facilities, limited parking, carpool if possible. *I noticed that the map is not correct. drive directions are: Head towards airport on Hwy 518. When freeway ends turn left on 1st Ave South. Turn right on SW 152nd St. Stay on 152nd until it "Y's" and changes to Maplewilder Ave SW, about 2 miles. In about 1 1/2 to 2 miles on rightside you will see SW 170th St turn there, parking is directly in front of you, if available. If not anywhere along the street, but please do not block any driveways. Residents here have been very kind to us and we would like to keep it that way. If in doubt, ASK! Call me if you have trouble locating site.206-931-2963

Bake and share holiday cookies! ***Thanks to all who RSVP’d. Please bring eight ½-dozen packets of cookies. We have seven people bringing cookies for the exchange (there were a few extra RSVP’s). The extra ½ dozen is for a cookie raffle.*** You must RSVP to Meet Up or Catherine Knowlson CCKnowlson@aol.com by Friday Nov 28th. Please bring packets of ½ dozen cookies for each participant. You will get to take home ½ dozen from each participant. We will inform the participants of the final count on Friday, NOV 28. If possible, bring a plate of extra cookies for snacking at the party (there will be other sweet treats at the party). While we encourage participants to contribute homemade cookies, we appreciate that not everyone has the time or inclination to bake. Not a problem! All cookies are invited to the cookie exchange. Any questions? Please ask Catherine @ ccknowlson@aol.com Happy baking!

Welcome to the 2014 MBDC Holiday Party!! It's not your normal club meeting, folks. This is our Holiday Party and your presence is kindly requested. Featured at this event: Food -- Yes, we LOVE to eat! Finger foods and snacks will be provided We will also provide plates, napkins, cups and utensils. BYOB -- Water, soda and spiced cider will be provided. Please BYOB for any drinks beyond that. GIFT EXCHANGE - A new feature for 2014. Bring a wrapped new or "vintage" SCUBA-related gift (value of $20.00 or less) for the white elephant gift exchange. Numbers are drawn by the participants and gifts selected in numerical order. Some "stealing" by those with higher-order numbers is allowed until everyone has a gift. Cookie Exchange -- See the separate Meet-up just for this element.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: Josh S

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Cancelled- 3.1 Ebb > 5:50 PM > 2.9 Flood, Sunset 4;23 pm. Splash ~ 4:45 Medium current, but a night dive. Gear up with light, go in at deep twilight, dive in the dark. You should have experience with current, in the dark, preferably on north DIW, and night dive experience. 2 lights minimum, tank lights option as far as I'm concerned. I've only done a couple night dives here so it's as much adventure for me as anyone. No facilities, use something at Titlow or before you get there. Residential neighborhood, limited parking. Carpooling encouraged. Early enough we can go out for debriefing after....yes!

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Weather should be improved and not a huge tidal exchange. Splash at 10:30 means that Seattle and North can make it down to Redondo without fighting (too much) rush-hour traffic. Get in some underwater time before Thanksgiving takes over. One or two dives.....it's your choice.
Time once again for food, fun and dive planning. Bring some food and drink and some ideas of where you would like to dive.

column2: Lujac's San Juan Island Boat Dive
column5: Date: Saturday November 22nd. The plan is to meet at the boat at 8:30 AM so we can load all the gear and leave by 9:00 AM. Expect to return about 4:00 PM. The first site we are planning to dive is...... LONG ISLAND WALL and 2nd dive will be determined based on weather. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com (http://www.lujacsquest.com/) for more information and directions to the boat. The price is $90 per person and must be paid in advance. Thanks, Bruce Brown 425 512-7457 Cell 425 334-7763 Home

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: 2 tank Redondo dive. First dive meetup 8:15am, splash @ 9:00am. Second dive meetup is 10:30am, splash @ 11:30am. Slack @ 11:50am. Do both or anyone of the two dives. You will have ample time to make it to the dive planning party at 5:30pm see club meetup calendar for details.

column2: Let's have a Friday morning "Slacker Dive" at Redondo this Friday, November 21.
column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Friday, November 21, "Slacker" dive at Redondo. I know many of you have, of course, been here, but I just want to splash. Let's gather at 9:15 to determine buddies and then splash at 10:00 or as buddies are ready. Addendum... I know that several of us are planning on doing a second dive after the surface interval. I estimate that splash to be about noon. We'll gather again and determine buddies.
Let's head back to Possession Point for a single tank dive. We'll plan to catch the 8:30AM ferry from Mukilteo with a 10:00AM splash.

column4: 1372 S Engle Rd 48° 9.44' N 122° 40.27' W · Coupeville, WA
column5: The big feature here is a jetty made of big boulders covered in plumose sea anemones with lots of life around. There's also an old wharf with pilings and lots of tube worms to the east. Slack is at 12:18 PM and splash should be around 11:45 AM. This slack is in between a flood of 1.3 knots and an ebb of -2.5 knots. It's possible to start this dive at the wharf and let the early ebb current take you to the jetty. Or just spend the whole dive along the jetty -- there's plenty to check out and see. Facilities at Fort Casey State Park (which includes the Keystone area) include restrooms, an unheated shower outdoors, and picnic tables. A valid Discovery Pass or one-day pass is required to park at the site. It's about a 25-mile drive to Keystone if you're taking the Mukilteo ferry. Shooting for the 9:30 AM ferry to Clinton would be a good idea. Meeting up by the Mukilteo boat launch parking lot for car-pooling is always encouraged!

column2: Photo Workshop - Howe Sound - Sea Dragon
column5: I am facilitating a two-day UW photo workshop in Horseshoe Bay BC. I'd welcome participation from other Marker Buoy members as subject matter experts or students. The schedule includes 2 90-minute classroom sessions plus four dives over two days. The cost is $139 per day. Call me for more information regarding accommodations, car pooling, etc. (206) 528-3757 Reserve a space by calling the Sea Dragon folks at (604) 329-3486 or email them at info@seadragoncharters.com

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Coll Jaxen
Go deep or stay shallow....Something for everyone. Octos, Wolfeels, Sailfin Sculpins, and Anemones....are almost certain to be found...... Current should is usually not an issue.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: South Narrows: 3.0 ebb > 1:34PM > 3.1 flood; splash somewhere around 12:30. Will all the recent rain I hope this site to be a bit better than some but doubt viz will be great. This will be a north bound drift and back from the north access site. Current is sorta medium > a tad more. Good for those ratcheting up their current experience. Not good for Day Island or current newbies. The usual DIW conditions- no facilities, use Titlow or somewhere on the way there. Parking is limited, carpool if you can. Save gas, save parking, help save the environment, and get to know your fellow diver a bit better. If you can plan to debrief at Steamers or Boathouse 19 after the dive, it's a good part of the fun. Plan come and watch Joyce and Fritz plunge into the frigid waters of the Sound after 10 days in Hawaii. Brrr!

column4: I-90 trail and I-90 · Seattle, WA
column5: This is a fairly easy intermediate level dive. Visibility can be less than optimal and the depth is beyond beginner level at the far end of the underwater bridge structure. This is to be considered a wreck dive and if you choose to go under the bridge make sure you tie of a line to some where outside the structure. A silt out could be deadly. Here is a link about how the dive..... http://www.nwdiveclub.com/viewtopic.php?t=190

Sunrise at 7:03am. I chose this site over Redondo due to potential runoff if its raining. Anyway, this is a great dive site for any Friday. Easy access to the water, a lot of interesting marine life. However, no facilities are offered. So if you need a potty break, be sure you stop somewhere on the way to the site. Meet time is 9:15 for a 10am splash. Site location is 170th St and Maplewild Ave SW.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center: Our guest this month will be Jim Rakowski, a photographer of some renown in southern California, who has recently returned from Isla Mujeres off of the Yucatan coast of Mexico... While there he swam & filmed the magnificent whale sharks that congregate during the summer months; Come see the excitement Jim has captured, and learn who's who in providing access to them at an affordable cost. Thanks to Fritz Merkel for connecting Jim with our club!

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: Janney Jaxen

Three Tree dive, Viz has been 25'+ lately. Meetup is at 10:30am with an 11:30am Splash. Slack at 12:04pm. New members have an opportunity here, to meet and discuss diving with others. Or maybe dive a site you have never dove before. You are encouraged to attend and get your feet wet. We can stop off for lunch at the pub and swap stories regarding the dive. Note: I will be doing an earlier non-hosted dive, splashing at 9:30am, if anyone is interested. Limited parking, carpool if possible. No facilities, get your business done before you arrive. Expect 40% chance of showers. Gee I was hoping not to get wet!

The only thing scary about this dive is the big tidal exchange. Luckily, you'll hardly notice any current at this site. Costumes are optional, dry and wet suits are not. Lots of variety of marine life found here. Easy access to the shoreline. Bathroom facilities provided. Sunrise at 7:52am. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10am.

Three Tree night dive. Meetup 7:30pm, Splash 8:00pm. The later meetup time makes commuting easier, just have your equipment almost ready to go prior to arrival. Have your working, primary, secondary and tank lights with you. We should be home by 10pm "ish"

Coffee and Pastries will be available during your set-up starting at 9:00AM. There will be a dive briefing starting at 10:00AM with a shotgun start soon after. Hot Dogs, Snacks and Hot Cider will be provided following your dive and during judging. Parking is limited to on street so an early arrival is suggested. We can probably make arrangements to unload your gear near the pavillion but you may need to ferry it a fair distance. Rain or shine. Rules: · Must dive with a buddy · BYOP - Bring Your Own Pumpkin · Pumpkin cannot be punctured in any way before reaching final carving depth of 10'. · Pumpkins may be stenciled beforehand with a marker as long as no holes exist. · Only items found during the dive may be added to the pumpkin · Teams must return to dive site entrance within 60 minutes of official start. · All participants who are not club members must have a signed release of liability. · Any type of carving tool is allowed as long as it is in a sheath. Judging will be done by everyone around (so be sure to bring your friends to cheer for you!). There is a flyer in the files section.

The days are getting shorter. Sunrise is at 7:42am. Maybe catch some snoozing marine life on this dive! Can always hope for an amazing dive. No current issues here. Easy access to the water. No facilities at this location so make your pit stop before you arrive. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10am.

It's been several months since I last dove Cove 2. If you'd like to discover or rediscover this location then join me. This is a great site for new divers to develop their night diving skills and work on your buoyance. If you are new to diving I encourage you to attend, besides you did pay to get certified, so you might as well dive, right! Sunset is around 6:30pm, so 5:30pm meetup. You must have Primary, secondary and tank lights for this dive.

column2: Be counted at the Mukilteo Waterfront Master Plan Meeting
column5: This will be the first meeting regarding changes to the Mukilteo waterfront. The City has included references to a potential diving park and our community should be represented at the meeting. I won't actually be able to attend but I wanted to get this in front of everyone.

We'll meet aboard the 08:00 Mukelteo ferry; It takes less than an hour to cross and drive to the park. We can splash any time after 08:30 and can dive the entire flood with little current. This area is known for its' wonderful spread finger structure and varied fish & invertebrate life. Divers new to the club are especially encouraged to attend, as I will act as guide.* 2 dives are possible in this time frame. Carpool is encouraged, and the DISCOVER PASS is required to park at the park! *Late breaking glitch: My guidance will have to be from shore as I am now taking antibiotics & painkillers for a deep tissue infection in my foot... rather a contra-indication to diving!

Skyline/Burrows Pass. Advanced dive. 1.5F > 2:30 >.8E Splash 2-2:15 Drift dive with a long swim out to a rock wall full of inverts. Some of the best color in the Sound. You can find PS. King crabs, and candy striped shrimp here. Long swim, no facilities. Parking has been getting tighter with development in the areas. Carpooling highly encouraged.

column2: Sea Dragon Charters - Howe Sound BC
column5: This past week the vis in Howe Sound has been nothing short of spectacular... 80 feet! Also recently they have been seeing Six Gill Sharks and Humpback Whales. This Saturday, the boat has lots of space and right now only experienced divers have signed up. There is an inexpensive motel within walking distance of the harbor. A 2-tank dive is $110

column2: Seattle, Avoid the traffic Night Dive
column5: Junkyard Night Dive. In an attempt to by pass the "Rush Hour" I am scheduling this dive for a 7:50pm meetup with an 8:30 splash. Current will be .1kt @ 8:10pm, slack at 9:50pm on a mild flood. Bring primary, backup and tank lights. You should be able to eat dinner, make an easy commute to site, complete dive and be home in time for the news.

Three tree dive. 1st meetup 10:45am, splash 11:30am. 2nd dive meetup 1pm, splash 1:45 pm. You can do one or both dives. NO facilities, so get your business done before arriving. Parking is limited. This site is truly one of the better shore dives for variety. Recommend you look at some of the past photos to get a good idea of what's possible at this site. Any member wishing to learn how to host a dive is welcome to join me as a co-host or as an outside observer.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Dive here on a high tide. The viz appears to be better, and at the end of the dive you might be able to swim right up to the steps to the street. The run off from the Marine Science Center tends to chum the water and the perch sometimes appear in large numbers. Easy access to the water, close parking nearby. Full facilities. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10:00am.

With the days getting shorter and crabbing season closed for the summer......We might have some really great conditions for seeing some cool stuff. This is a site with few if any current issues and has a variety of dive profiles available. This site is suitable for all divers.

Skyline/Burrows Pass. 2.2F >2:46>0.8E Splash ~ 2:15-2:30PM Advanced dive. Drift dive with a long swim out to a rock wall full of inverts. Some of the best color in the Sound. You can find PS. King crabs, and candy striped shrimp here. San Juan dive without the boat. Long swim, no facilities. Parking has been getting tighter with development in the areas. Carpooling highly encouraged due to the long drive and parking hassles.

Just a few paces beyond Cove 2 is Cove 3. This dive site is commonly thought of as a training site for beginning divers. However, just off to the left is an old ferry terminal from the 19th century. You can still find an occasional relic from the past here, but there is also marine life that can be found around the pilings. On a good viz day, there are some awesome views. In fact, one diver set up an oil canvas underwater at this site to capture the beauty, some years ago. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10:00am.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center: Our Guest at the October Meeting will be Barb Roy, whom many of you know from her long association with NW dive News and the Bellingham dive shop, Adventures Down Under. Barb has worked as a freelance photojournalist and contributing editor for a variety of different magazines and on-line publications since 1995, specializing in underwater adventure, destination travel. She currently holds a PADI Master Instructor rating & Instructor ratings with IANTD, NAUI, DAN, among others; a very accomplished lady of diving indeed! Barb's work has been published in magazines including Skin Diver, NW Dive News, Sport Diver and many others… She’ll be speaking to us at the October 1st meeting on the topic entitled “NW Diving; what’s next?” For our members new to diving this will be a great opportunity to hear about the many opportunities for more advanced diving available in our region. And for all of our members, the trips that Barb has lined up will provide lots of dive action in BC (Including Howe Sound & the Nanaimo wrecks) & the San Juan Islands… Let’s pack the hall for this very special guest!

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: All divers. This will be a night dive so should have at least dove Redondo during the day. Great time to look for small critters in the shallows. We'll be diving slightly before slack before ebb to be sure we're at high tide. Splash around 7:00p. Sun sets around 7:00p

This is one of my best sites to visit on a weekday. There are always hidden treasures here to uncover. Easy entry, should be ample parking. But, no facilities on site. If you have to go, make your pit stop before you arrive. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10:00am. Note: the entrance to 3 Tree parking is at SW 170th St and Maplewild Ave.

With the days getting shorter and crabbing season closed for the summer......We might have some really great conditions for seeing some cool stuff. This is a site with few if any current issues and has a variety of dive profiles available. This site is suitable for all divers.

I'm hosting a Sept 21st Ocean Quest boat dive. This dive is full so do not RSVP, (only those confirmed for this dive may) but others have expressed an interest in doing a boat dive. If you are interested in doing an Oct dive please contact me. If 8 people are interested I would be glad to set it up or step aside and let one of our newer members host and I will help with the logistics. Mahalo Note: Meetup 8:30am with a 9am departure. It wouldn't hurt to be a few minutes earlier though to get all the loading done smoothly.

Noon meet up with a 1:00 splash. For folks who have not done this dive, this is one of the most diverse critter dives in Puget Sound. Lots of fish and inverts. In fact, this site still holds my record for the most REEF critter species of any site in the Pacific Northwest. It is usually an easy dive appropriate for all divers - just follow the jetty out and back with a nice sand beach entry. There is parking in front of the Wooden Boat Center located at the end of Water Street. There are washrooms, shower and a cafe at the dive site. We'll plan on grabbing a bite after the dive. Let me know if there are any questions.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: It looks like a low tide on this day. Not the best conditions but why not check it out. This is the place where the diver can get up-close and personal with the marine life in the park. Full facilities. Meet time is 9:15am, splash at 10:00am.

Great location for a night dive, never know what's going to be out and active! Night diving experience required. Bring a Dive Light and a Backup Light. Tank lights are good, too. Sunset officially at 7:17 PM, Slack leading to Flood around 8:25 PM, Max Flood @ .1 knot at 9:52 PM. Should be an easy evening.

Dive! Socialize! Eat! Join us for a great dive, then socialize, enjoy some delicious BBQ and explore the shore at Saltwater State Park. Bring your non-diving family and kids. The park offers a lot of amenities to accommodate everyone; volleyball fields, horseshoe pits, hiking and biking trails. Look here http://www.parks.wa.gov/578/Saltwater for more information and handy maps. The projection is to begin congregating about 0930 and enjoy the location and amenities at will. Tides/currents are favorable for splash about 1030 or so and perhaps later. Alcohol is allowed only in the campground, by registered campers of legal age. It is not allowed in any other areas of the park. They asked me to tell you that. And parking is by permit only, so you need either a current Discover Pass or a day-use permit ($10.00). We have reserved the Beach Point Fire Ring, which supplies us with 4 picnic tables and some concrete benches. The location is just to the right from the southern-most parking lot, across the creek from the scuba rinse station. It's easy to find as you will certainly see our MBDC banner and masses of dive gear strewn about. Restrooms are located about 150 feet away from our site. What should you bring? Dive gear, chairs, something to grill and something to share for the potluck. A couple of pop-ups (portable canopy tents i.e. quick-ups) would be greatly appreciated as well. The site does NOT provide us with a grill so two or three BBQ grills would be wonderful so we can cook. I'll bring a grill, set of BBQ cooking tools and some charcoal and a chimney starter. Oh, and hot mitts and my signature chef's toque, of course. Questions? Suggestions? Just ask ;) We look forward to seeing everyone there for a day of relaxation along the water.

column3: Bruce Higgins Underwater Trails (Edmonds Underwater Park)
column4: Main St & Railroad Av · Edmonds, WA
column5: Byron Bishop

This is another great site for divers, probably the most frequently dove spot in the Pacific NW. This site has a lot to offer; close to water, variety of marine life, bathroom facilities. On a Friday morning, parking shouldn't be a problem. Meet at 9:00, splash at 9:45am.
Go deep or stay shallow....Something for everyone. Current should not be an issue.

Board meeting open to all Club members. Board members please RSVP yes or no so we can be sure we have a quorum. If calling in please let me know when you RSVP. If the door is locked when you arrive please call 206-669-0292 for entry.

We'll meet aboard the 0930Mukelteo ferry; It takes less than an hour to cross and drive to the park. We can splash any time after 11:00 and can dive the entire flood with little current. This area is known for its' wonderful spread finger structure and varied fish & invertebrate life. Divers new to the club are especially encouraged to attend, as I will act as guide. 2 dives are possible in this time frame. Carpool is encouraged, and the DISCOVER PASS is required to park at the park!

column3: Redondo Beach Dr S & Redondo Way
column4: Redondo Beach Dr S & Redondo Way · Des Moines, Wa
column5: Big exchange day, but there are still some spots that are dive friendly. This site has great potential for a wide variety of marine life. Many pluses for this site include; street or paid parking, close to the water, bathroom accommodations. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10am.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Monthly Meeting at Sunset Hill Community Center: Program: Doug Miller will lead a discussion which derives from the Charter Dive we did in California at the end of May. His Wife, Karen, Judi Brooks, her niece & brother in law, & myself were all involved in an emergency rescue in which, sadly, the diver died... Bring your own insights & questions... What OUGHT we ask when booking a dive charter... Are certs enough? How often does a vendor practice rescue? Is the entire crew so trained? New divers & new members are especially encouraged to attend this meeting... There's a lot to be learned from a tragedy such as this...

column4: Oak Harbor, WA · Oak Harbor, WA
column5: Deception Pass: 4.9 Flood >11:17 slack > 5.2 Ebb This is a tad on the high side but possibly the last opportunity this year. I can't go, but it's out there for the ride.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Last chance to dive Sunrise for several months due to exchanges. Intermediate/Advance due to possible current and long walk. One of the best dives in the Sound. Splash around 10:40am. Portapoty on site.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: North entrance: 2.4E > 4:25 PM > 3.1F Advanced dive Splash ~ 3:30 PM Med current going N. and back. Easier profile. Good exchange for folks looking for more drift dive and current experience. Suitable for a first DIW dive, if you have some current experience. No facilities, use something at Titlow or before you get there. Residential neighborhood, limited parking. Carpooling encouraged.
The last crabbing weekend for the summer. 8:45am splash

On the backside of Alki lies the Pipeline dive. This can be a great dive for photographers when the conditions are right. This can be a long dive, but is also a shallow dive with max depth around 35 feet. There may be some slight current. Meet time is 7:45 for a splash time of 8:30am.

Got the day off with nothing to do, or has it been a while since you've been in the water? Come dive 3 Tree North in Burien. This is a great site for seeing pretty much anything the ocean has to offer. Parking is just a few steps from the entry and should not be a problem during a week day. No facilities here so be sure to make your pitstop in advance of arriving. Meet time is 9:15, splash at 10am.

Let's meet at Three Tree Point at 6:30 pm for a 7:30 splash. It will be great to have a mid-week break with a night dive to enjoy the amazing bioluminescence and other animal life. Remember to bring a dive light, back up light and tank light. Easy entry, limited parking, no facilities.

Wednesday, August 27th Carl Baird and I will diving on Sea Dragon Charter’s at their Howe Sound location which is a 30 minute drive from downtown Vancouver. They are located at Sewell’s Marina near the main ferry terminal in Horseshoe Bay and the dive sites a usually on a 10 – 15 minute boat ride away. The boat is comfortable with standup and benches for gearing up. Food is limited on the boat. We will receive a 10% discount if we have 6 Marker Buoy Dive Club members sigh up. The regular cost is $113 Canadian so the club cost will be about $95 with the discount and exchange rate. The meet time at the boat is 10:00 AM and expect to return to the dock about 3:00 PM. Directions to the boat and web site: http://seadragoncharters.com/locations/howe-sound/ Call me at 425 512-7457 if you have questions. Bruce Brown

We'll meet aboard the 10:00 Mukelteo ferry; It takes less than an hour to cross and drive to the park. We can splash any time after 11:30 and can dive the entire flood with little current. This area is known for its' wonderful spread finger structure and varied fish & invertebrate life. Divers new to the club are especially encouraged to attend, as I will act as guide. 2 dives are possible in this time frame. Carpool is encouraged, and the DISCOVER PASS is required to park at the park!
swim to the far end of the oil dock for large crabs

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Aug 23rd Redondo Beach dive. Meetup 10am, splash 11am with slack on the flood at 11:30am. Location has free and pay parking, shower, restroom and Easy stairs entrance/exit Site has a line to follow in the 50ft range (has street light reflector, pipes and a VW)and another line that will take you to 85ft. at the Carousel. Farther north in the shallows you may find lumpsucker's and midshipmen fish in the eel grass. This site is a good place to work on your buoyance. Note: I will bring a second tank just in case you didn't get enough the first time.

I have 1 spot open for Aug 23 and 24 diving with Bill Minton out of Neah Bay. I also have a rooms reserved at Curley's resort for Friday and Saturday nights. Dive Boat costs are $150.00 per day and the room is $55.00 per night. This is advanced boat diving in open water conditions with the potential for swell, current and wind. Advanced experienced divers only. But... This is classic NW coast diving with great current windows. We will plan to get at least one dive on Duncan Rock which is a classic. I don't need any deposits at this time but I need firm commitments for both days only. I will also be diving Salt Creek State Park and another dive to be determined on Friday Aug 22 if anyone is interested. If not you can meet up with us Friday night at Curley's

column4: 3506 Camp Hayden Rd · Port Angeles, WA
column5: As part of my trip to the peninsula this week we will be diving Salt Creek Park on Friday at 11:00AM. Some of us will be moving from there to Lake Crescent for a second dive. I'm posting this as a separate meetup because anyone can join us for this part of the trip. The Neah Bay trip is now full.
Mark Wilson

column4: Alki Ave SW & Stevens St. · Seattle, WA
column5: Junkyard Dive. Light tides. Meet at 7:00 PM, Splash around 7:30 or so. The usual night dive stuff, be familiar/experienced with night diving, a strong main and a trusty backup light is recommended. Light low tide @ 9:07
For participants in the club NITROX class that have successfully completed their eLearning.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: DIW S>N drift: 1.7E > 8:19PM > 2.2F; 6:30 meet, 7:7-15 splash. Meet at the S. entrance. Long swim with current exposure and a drift. Advanced divers. If you have DIW experience but not a drift yet this is a good one to get that experience. No facilities on site: use Titlow or one of the businesses on the way there. Residential neighborhood with limited parking, carpooling suggested. Note-this is not an optimal time to be getting down to DIW during rush hour. It is a very good exchange for a drift. Haven't done DIW in awhile or a drift in much longer so I thought it would be worth the effort.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: An intermediate-level dive with potential current. Splash a little after 11:30 (slack is predicted for 12:08 PM). A long walk down with an "even-longer" walk back up to the parking lot. Still, a great dive site with of fish and critters along a nice wall and slope. Facilities include a porta-potty.

The club assists the Edmonds Parks Beach Rangers through a collection dive and a "Live-Dive" video show. This is held on the beach at Edmonds Marina Beach Park. Last year there were over 300 people in attendance watching our dive/marine science show. The Edmonds Parks people are already getting many calls asking if the Marker Buoy divers will be there again this year. They love us! We'll need divers to bring up critters to place in the wading pools/touch-tanks. At just past sunset, we have a diver using a live video system go out and show the marine life on the big screen system. This is all at Edmonds Marina Beach Park, S. end of the marina, near the dog park. We need a good team for this event. It's a great time. Please...come out and help. It does entail moving a pile of gear out to the beach from the parking lot.
2 went

column4: 5031 University Way NE, Seattle, WA · Room 208, WA
column5: The free* course is open to club members who are interested in becoming NAUI NITROX certified. *Participants must purchase NAUI Education System w/ eLearning course materials (SKU 90035A) separately. These are available from local dive stores. Alternatively Doug/Kimber can supply these at cost and will place an order with NAUI on about August 1st..

Three Tree night dive Aug 8th. Meetup 8:15pm, Splash 9pm, slack 9:10pm. Bring primary, secondary and tank lights. This is a good site for new divers, most things of interest is above 60ft, the site has a gravel bottom limiting silt. For photographers always new and interesting subjects. For experienced members a chance to meet new members as well as enjoying a great dive site Anyone interested in co-hosting with me let me know and if we meet the air card requirements, you can have the card.
