column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Casey Mclean of the "Sound Side Marine Life Rescue Center" will present its' mission to us; that of rehabilitating marine mammals & birds following injuries from oil spills & other human contact, and make available to those interested the opportunity to participate in their good work. Bring your ideas and be ready for a lively discussion!

column4: 6074 Wynn Jones Rd E · Port Orchard, WA
column5: Time for our annual BBQ and dive. Come on over to Port Orchard for a BBQ pot luck and optional drift dive in Rich Passage at our house. If you are going to the Sunrise dive that morning come over after that dive. We'll have the BBQ going for lunch - bring your own food and drinks. We'll then do a dive with a splash at precisely 4:30pm in front of our place. This will be a drift dive out to Point Glover on the end of the ebb and then a return back to our place on the flood. This dive should be appropriate for all divers although if this is your first drift dive, pair up with an experienced diver. Timing is everything so we'll need to be starting our dive at no later than 4:30pm. Viz has been good in front of our place and we've been seeing lots of cool stuff.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Intermediate level dive due to long walk and possible current. One of the best dives in the Sound. Octo, wolfeels and much more. So the walk is worth it, if you're up for it. Its a pretty setup area as well. Good exchange this day. Slack before ebb. Meet time 10:00A. Splash around 11:00A. Portapotty was back last time we were there. The plan is to go to Doug and Karin's BBQ afterwards if you can. I highly recommended it.

column4: Alki Ave SW & Stevens St. · Seattle, WA
column5: Last minute invitation to go out to the Junkyard. I know the club was just there, but due to poor time management skills, I missed it. I'll be doing photo stuff. Meet at 7:00 PM, Splash around 7:30 or so. The usual night dive stuff, be familiar/experienced with night diving, a couple of lights are good things to have, go wild and bring a tank light (it's colorful). .71 max current at 4:52 PM, Slack before ebb is 8:25 PM High tide around 11 ft at 8:22 PM. I will be showing a member how to catch crab (Hawaiian Style LOL), also if you wish, I can show you how to clean them. Anyone wishing to join us is welcome. Meetup 11:15am, Splash 12 noon, slack before flood 1:09pm. If you wish to keep your crab you will need Crabbing license $8.75, measuring scale, grab bag and light. Dive site will be determined on night of dive based on current and tides. meetup time is 6pm at Des Moines Marina - 22307 Dock Ave S, Des Moines. New members, Three Tree Friday night dive. This dive will give older members a chance to meet new members and enjoy the rewards of a very good dive site. If you have seen some of the past posting and pictures you can see it's worth it. This is diving at it's best, with no long commute, no traffic issues and you can clean your gear the next day. Meetup 9pm, Splash 9:40pm with slack before the flood at 9:50pm. Bring primary, backup and tank lights. I will have a dive site map to help you get an idea of where and what things are there. Mahalo

Hoping to recreate my last dive here! Three Tree, Friday the 11th, 8:30pm meetup 9:10pm splash with a 9:25 slack. I am willing to do a second if there is any interest. Remember, dive Friday night, sleep late Saturday, then wake up and clean gear. Wife or husband happy cause you are home for the weekend. If they are not, you have all weekend to dive again, Yeesss!

column4: W. Green Lake Dr. N. · Seattle, WA
column5: Our second biggest social event of the year. The Annual Picnic is Wed, July 9th, 6-10 PM. Click on the address above to get close. It's off W. Green Lake Dr. N. at the north end of Green Lake, across from the Put-Put Golf course and the Old Aqua theater. Turn up the hill near the tennis courts and make the first left at the top of the hill. It is also easily accessible from 99N. This link will get you closer. http://www.seattle.gov/parks/_images/maps/picnics/Woodland4-7.pdf BBQ/potluck/BYOB. The Club will have the grills going and provide plates and plastic cups+utensils. Should you like the elegance of glass for your beverage you need to bring that yourself. Jim M and Catherine are conspiring to produce ice cream for dessert. Alcohol is not allowed in parks so discretion is required. I WILL call Parks and will have the nearby bathroom open this year. No electricity. We will have a glass/aluminum and compost recycle containers this year. Please use them. Hopefully Weather be great! Do come, the more members, the better time we have. I am looking forward to it! Mark

Not to compete with Gene's dive (which I would love to do), we have to drop tanks off for servicing in Port Townsend on Saturday so we will be doing a dive a Point Hudson with a splash time of 11am. If you can't make Gene's dive and want some fun come join us. The ebb is lighter until 5pm so folks can do two dives if they like. The Point Hudson jetty is a great dive with lots of critters and currents should be mild enough to make this appropriate for any diver. Easy entry, parking at the end of Water Street and facilities are available at the Wooden Boat Center.

This is the access to the site known as "The Fingers" and, when dived on the flood, will accommodate all skill levels. Earliest ferry is 0600; earliest splash therefore is 0730: I myself will target the 9:00 sailing, and arrive about 1:15 early to insure getting on that boat. Carpools are recommended, and the Discover Pass is required at the State Park. We can meet at the south side of the Mukelteo Lighthouse Park to arrange carpools... It looks like the latest splash time would be 2:30 (prox) though the ebb is small, it usually drives a strong current south along shore... dive able, but you must know how to manage it... Detailed dive briefing will be given to those new to this site. New Members; you'll find this dive a Delight!

column2: God's Pocket via the Nautilus Swell live aboard
column5: The Swell is looking for divers to fill their boat on 4/28-5/2 (M 6PM to F 8:30AM) They are offering 1/2 price accommodations! This is a fantastic price for some of the best cold water diving in the NW. This is a rare opportunity. I doubt you'll ever see this kind of deal again. It's good enough that 4 of us are turning right around and going back out on the Swell. Monday will be a drive day to get up there via Twassan Ferry. Friday will be return. Short notice....they need commitment SOON. The trip starts in a week. For more info on the boat go here: http://www.nautilusswell.com/ship_tour You can call them at: 1-888-434-8322. Tell them you are part of the Marker Buoy special. Good people, great boat, exceptional diving. I hate to see this one go wanting. If you have questions feel free to call me. Fritz 206-525-0736

The plan is to dive Sea Car which is a rock of an island off the south end of Lopez in the San Juan Channel area. It is a perfect dive site for the beginning of the Ebb tide. The rock goes straight down to about 120 feet and most of the water coming out of San Juan channel comes out that way, but the back side is protected from the current. It is common to see Puget Sound King Crab and various anenomies. Good for photography. Occasionally we will see ling cod and octopus. Wolf eels have been spotted but you need to look for them in the cracks and crevices. The price is $90 per person and must be paid in advance. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Lu-Jac's web site is http://www.lujacsquest.com for more information and directions to the boat. The boat will departure from the Anacortes dock at 9:30 AM but everyone should be to the boat at 9:00 AM so we can load all the gear and leave promptly by 9:30 AM. Expect to return about 4:00 PM. The dives include breakfast snacks, lunch, coffee, tea and bottled water. Cost is $90.00. This site selection is only based on the tides and the weather may dictate a different direction but not to worry, Phil knows the San Juan’s and he has never disappointed me. Thanks, Bruce Brown 425 334-7763 Home 425 512-7457 Cell

column2: Liveaboard dive trip on the Swell
column5: After the last meeting several of us were very interested in Mike Lever’s offer of a trip aboard the Swell leaving out of Anacortes. We currently have 9 slots filled and need another 3 to round out the boat. The Swell is a beautiful craft and diving off her is a blast. Here is the website; http://www.nautilusswell.com/ Note, this trip is not advertised on the site. We are looking at trip leaving Anacortes on 4/6/2014 and returning on 4/10/2014. Boarding in Anacortes is Sunday night at 8:00PM and it disembarks Thursday morning at 8:30 AM. That means we would be diving 4/7 to 4/9 but some of us are talking about adding some dives on the 10th. There would be an up-charge for this and it would be something the entire group needs to agree upon. I do not have pricing but it will be competitive. Since we have the entire boat booked the itinerary is very much up to the group and the weather and tides. Current talk is centering on the San Juan Islands, Neah Bay and Victoria. Here are the details from Mike: MB quiet pricing would be $8100 per trip which works out to $675 per person. Retail pricing through dive stores or on our website is $799 for stateroom accommodation and $999 for superior suites. Pricing includes everything with the exception of $35 port fee, bar, gift shop and nitrox and crew gratuities. Mid-week trips typically board at 8:00 pm on Sunday evenings and disembark at 8:30 a.m. Thursday morning. I need to stress that this trip is for advanced divers only. If you are interested you should be comfortable and able to: 1. Dive in current and surge. 2. Dive in an open ocean environment off a smaller boat. The Swell carries a tender that acts as a dive boat. it is 38 feet long though. 3. Carry and use an SMB in the event you get blown off a site. 4. Manage 3 dives a day to depths below 80fsw. Nitrox is available and highly recommended. To make this a go we need people who are committed to the trip. Please only RSVP if you are absolutely sure you can go. Payment will be needed very soon. If you have questions please post a comment or email me.

A DISCOUNT TICKET COUPON IS AVAILABLE IN THE FILES SECTION SEATTLE, WA – (Dive News Network (DNN) – Jan 24, 2014) Seattle has a new combined watersports Expo. The Scuba & H2O Adventure Show is coming to Seattle on April 5 and 6, 2014. The 7th annual event is moving to Seattle’s Pier 91 and combining all kinds of watersports and adventure for a fun mix of events, exhibits and entertainment. The Scuba & H2O Adventure Show (www.scubaH2Oshow.com) will = feature over 150 exhibitors from around the globe: prominent travel experts, consumer mini-clinics, interactive family-friendly activities, and industry focuses trade events. “Strategically located in the heart of Seattle’s downtown core, on Pier 91, this event is perfectly located for fun,” says event producer and DNN CEO Rick Stratton. “Our attendees have an appetite for travel adventure and water sports and this show is a great way to experience all there is to offer in one day. We are very excited about our partnerships within the city of Seattle. Being located on Pier 91 is the perfect way to access this water loving community.” Over 150 exhibitors representing some of the world’s most desired locations will be on hand to entice, educate and give details about their destinations and tours to attendees, including Fiji, Philippines, Mexico, Alaska, Palau, Bahamas, and popular Caribbean destinations. “Many of these destinations are offering incredible specials and trip giveaways. Our Grand Prize will be a trip to a beautiful resort in Fiji with Airfare – simply incredible,” says Stratton. Guests will enjoy all kinds of interactive demonstrations including a SCUBA demo pool, paddling demos, stand-up paddle boarding (SUP) demos and even SUP yoga demonstration. The shows invites guests to attend show floor seminars to learn about gear, safety, travel, and of course, try new water sports. Meet all kinds of specialty retailers, manufacturers and travel experts from around the corner and across the globe. Located on the northern end of Elliott Bay, Pier 91 is known as Smith Cove and is less than three miles from the downtown core. Smith Cove is home to the Cruise Ship Terminal and cruise lines like Carnival, Celebrity Cruises, Holland America, Princess Cruises and Royal Caribbean International. No matter the motivation, the draw to water sports is perhaps best described as a desire to connect with the ocean and discover something new. With the number of water sports available it wouldn’t be surprising to find equally numbered retailers, and manufacturers appealing to the love of water. What is surprising, however, is how easy it is to find all of them in one place! There are so many water adventures to choose from: whether in need of a tranquil afternoon on the kayak or seeking a heart-pounding thrill ride with white water rafting, guests can find their desire at the SCUBA & H2O Show this coming April. Sign up for Adventure and WIN great prizes! The 2014 SCUBA & H2O Adventure Show will take place on April 5 and 6 from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. (Saturday) and 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. (Sunday) at Seattle’s Pier 91 (Cruise Ship Terminal). Tickets are available at http://www.scubaH2Oshow.com with promo code “SPLASH” or at the door for $10. For more information please visit http://www.scubah2oshow.com or find us on http://www.facebook.com/scubah20show. Children nine years old and under are free. Military including retirees, all Police, Fire, or EMS personal who show credentials are also FREE ADMISSION. For tickets and event information, email selene@divenewsnetwork.com or call (360)240-1874

All divers dive at the Pipeline. Its the offseason and the photo opts may not be as easily to come by. Still, this is a nice easy shallow dive on the flip side of Alki Beach. Max depth will be about 35 feet. The Pipeline is a man made reef of boulders extending out into Puget Sound. Expect to see a large gathering of white plumose anenomes at the end of the pipeline. Hopefully, there is still marine life hanging around, waiting for the kelp to show up. If the wind is coming from the south, creating some surf, we can either relocate the dive to the Junkyard, or possibly to the Duwamish Head (Cove 4). Meet time is 7:45, splash at 8:30am.
Come and search out the night life and perhaps swim with the seals.... This is a night dive so be sure to bring the primary, backup and tank light for safety. Sunset is 7:42.

He'll be providing a brief history of the diving there, as well as an overview of the training and equipment needed to do this type of diving. Be prepared for a real treat!

Ahoy, Marker Buoys! You are cordially invited to attend the Marker Buoy Annual Banquet on March 22, 2014 at 6:00 PM at the Queen City Yacht Club (www.queencity.org) at 2608 Boyer Avenue East, Seattle, WA 98102. According to the time-honored Marker Buoy tradition, the event is BYOB. The evening's entertainment schedule includes several fun activities: A "Gilligan's Island" themed costume contest! Come dressed as your favorite island castaway. Judging is casual (no runway-style parade of participants) with prizes offered for Best Gilligan and Best Group. Grab your coconuts, rugby shirt and create! A slideshow of MB-sourced underwater and travel photography! Our cocktail hour and dinner will be accompanied by a slideshow that shows off MB travel and the undersea world we adore. Donations of pictures (with your watermark, if you prefer) are gratefully accepted for the slideshow. Prize raffle! As ever, great prizes are available in several raffle drawings. Prizes are varied and nothing beats getting something terrific for the price of a few tickets. Tickets are available for purchase at the banquet. A special after-party surprise! For those MB members who stay up late (past 9:30 PM!), we plan a surprise after the evening winds down... The Marker Buoy banquet cost is $37.00 per attendee and can be paid via PayPal or checks sent to Marker Buoy Dive Club, PO Box 31163, Seattle, WA 98103. See you there!

Come and search out the night life. Stubby Squid, baby Octos and colorful Anemones can be found here. This is a night dive so be sure to bring the primary, backup and tank light for safety. Sunset is 7:20.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Intermediate to Advance level dive due to potential current and the walk. Decent slack for this one ( slack before ebb 1.7 to 2.5 knot.) Long walk up a hill. Always an amazing critter dive. Normally lots of octos, wolfeels and possibility of most other critters of the sound. Out house has been back at the site recently. Whew! We'll plan to go out to Spiro's afterwards. Don't forget that this Sunday is the start of Daylight Savings Time. Set your clocks forward an hour on Saturday night.

column4: E/ 5 de Febrero y Navarro | Colonia El Manglito · La Paz, BCS
column5: Grey Whale Moms & Babies February/March, 2014. Trip estimate is $1,500 - $2,500 For the past three years my wife and I have spent time on Baja’s west coast viewing mother and baby grey whales before they migrate north to the Pacific Northwest. We have applied for permits from the Mexican government to dive or snorkel with the whales as part of an article on their migration. This would be a seven day trip, and would include room, lodging, and transportation round trip from La Paz. The higher cost would be for permits to dive or snorkel with the whales. If you are interested, let Dan know ASAP, as resumes need to be submitted. Objectives: Grey whales, mothers “nursing” babies.

column4: 48° 5.14' N 123° 44.66' W · Port Angeles Area, WA
column5: Looking to get your feet wet in Northwest waters? This dive site is perfect for you. This is a fresh water lake with crystal clear waters and no pesky tide chart to contend with. There are a few well known dive sites in this lake. Most are below 100’, but we will be visiting the sunken barge. Because of the visibility, you do have to remain aware of your depth because you can go really deep without realizing it. But all and all a good dive to contrast what you typically see in the Puget Sound. Bring your camera and work on your wide angle shots. Meetup time of 10:30am is based on catching the 7:55am Edmonds /Kingston ferry and a 2 hour dive. Mapquest sez the trip should take an hour forty. That gives a little wiggle room for finding lunch and what not. We will be meeting and diving around the swimming area, which is closed to scuba from May 1 to September 30. I don’t have much more info as I have not been on this site in a while. The splash time will be at 11:00am, but this is flexible as the tides are favorable. (yuck,yuck) If interest in this dive is early and vocal enough, we could turn this into an overnight event and dive a site on the coast near Port Angeles. If this interests you, please indicate so when you RSVP. Also carpooling would be nice, we could pair up on the message board, not unlike how your teachers did for you for square dancing. Questions? Please let me know on the interweb or touch base with me at the Wednesday meeting.

Should be a really nice dive at this site. Expect a pretty high tide, making for a bit deeper than usual dive. No current issues expected. Sunset at 5:39pm. Meet time is 6:30 for a 7:15pm splash. Be sure to bring the primary, backup and tank light to be safe.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: All divers dive. This is the off season at Redondo. The kelp is gone, its likely colder than usual. However, it can still be a great dive to learn the site, perhaps see a critter or two. No current issues here. Full facilities. Meet time 9:00, splash at 10:00am.

1.2F >4:36 slack > 1.2 E (5:30 sunset) Between Fidalgo Head and Burrows Island NOTE-If the rains start and the rivers flood I might cancel this dive. Stay posted if you are interested. Meet time 3:00p, splash about 4:00pm.This is a current dive with a long 200 yard swim to the drop. Timed right you get a boost out and back. It starts shallow on a steep rock face covered with invertebrate life, the highlight of this dive. When it's good it's very pretty indeed with lots of sea cucumbers and sponges. This is a place to see occasional candy stripe shrimp and PS King Crabs if you have good eyes and are lucky. As you travel out it gets deeper to ~ 95 feet. No need to go deeper if you don't want to. No facilities on site, stop at Anacortes or WA Park before you arrive. We have been using 'weed side' parking for several years. Building going on up there may have compromised the parking. It's a 90 minute drive from north Seattle. Because of both these factors carpooling is strongly recommended. We usually hit up the Brown Lantern in town after the dive for grub.

This one is ebbing toward a low tide. Great site to find variety among the marine life. No current issues here. Sunset at 5:28p. Meet time at 6:30, splash at 7:15pm so be sure to bring the primary, backup and tank light to make it fun and safe.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.0F > 12:36 slack > 3.2E South Narrows mid-channel Splash ~ 11AM. Advanced dive with current + depth. Potential long swim. This is somewhat more challenging than the north and back profile due to increasing depth, increasing distance from shore, and the possibility of down and out currents down at South Bay. Experience on DIW and in current highly desirable. This is #2 in the 'progression series'. The usual DIW drill; quiet neighborhood with no facilities and limited parking. Carpool if you can. column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Back by popular demand. Another night dive at Redondo looking for the elusive spiny lumpsucker and other strange and wonderful creatures. Wasn't expecting to schedule this so soon but it looks like the best tide for some time and no other dives are scheduled. Besides now we know better where to look. Can do a quick explore of the boats and then do either of the shallows (north of Salty's or south of the boat ramp). Or spend your whole time in the shallows. This is a night dive so bring a good main light and a backup light. Good dive for all divers, though best to have some night diving experience. There will likely be mostly photographers on the dive so you may need to be willing to spot for your buddy if you don't take pictures. Meet time 5:00pm. Splash as soon as you can get ready.
Nothing else seems to be going on. Suggestions open as to where and when.....

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.5E > 3:45PM >2.3F Potential S > N drift. Identical profile to Dec 15th which worked well. Current was present but modest. Meet 1:30, splash about 2:30. This should be OK for folks with some experience with DIW and not put off by a long swim in current. It's ~200 yards out....and back if you do the return. It's probably 400+ yards of swimming if you do the drift. Several of us did not drift, just went out and back. That's a nice profile with more time to explore South Bay. The down side is being deeper longer (60-90 feet) so it sucks down your tank and runs up your N2. Drifting gets you closer to shore and shallower. Leave yourself a bit of extra time to move vehicles if you expect to do the drift and don't want to hump your tank back. NOTE: For folks not up for the long swim and the drift this is a decent one for doing the North up and back dive. You know the drill, quiet neighborhood with no facilities. Carpool if you can. Fritz Merkel 206-525-0736. 206-370-4720-cell

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: Let's try again and hope for better weather this time. This is a Night Dive. It will be dark by meet time. Be sure to prepare for gearing up in limited light. Bring two dive lights. Intention is to find all the great critters that hang out mostly in the shallows at this site, lumpsuckers, snail fish, pipefish, baby octo's, and much more. Of course there are also things to see deeper if you want to do that. Perfect dive to see critters you may not have seen before. Great photographer's dive. Dive is appropriate for all levels of dive experience, but should have some night diving experience.
Diving the Fort Worden State Park underwater park and pier. You'll need a Discover Pass for parking. Facilities available. Appropriate for all divers. Follows the morning dive at Point Hudson.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.4E > 10:37AM > 2.5F Drift dive from south entrance to north Splash ~ 9:20-9:30AM This is a bit on the high side for the swim out for the drift. It's a long way and you best have your legs in good order. This could be another 'bring your trowel' kind of dive. Variation (for experienced DIW divers)- Swim to S. Bay, explore, then swim back to the S. entrance. You can spend more time exploring around there. It's deeper and farther from shore. Watch your air and N2. Check with Joyce or I about some new finds. Experienced DIW divers with drift experience only unless you clear it through me. Leave yourself a bit of extra time to move vehicles. NOTE: For folks not up for the long swim and the drift this is a decent one for doing the North drift and back dive. If there is interest and I can get and experienced diver to coordinate it this would be another option just splashing about 15" later. You know the drill, quiet neighborhood with no facilities. Carpool if you can. Fritz Merkel 206-525-0736. 206-370-4720-cell

It's been a while since the club had a dive at this site. Known for great photo opportunities in and about the pilings. The kelp is all but gone by now, but, we may still find GPO or wolf eels in some of the crevices. Site is current sensitive. Facilities may be lacking so do your business before you arrive. Meet time is 8, splash at 9:00am. May do a second dive at Les Davis on Ruston Way..

Last week's night dive began with a high tide, this week's dive will be a low tide. Perhaps the good viz will hold out during slack. The current is not the issue here. Check out this dive to see what this site has to offer. Meet time is 6:30, with splash at 7:15p. Be sure to bring the primary, backup and tank light for these early evening adventures.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Bill High - founder of PSI-PCI (Professional Scuba Inspectors) (Professional Cylinder Inspectors, Inc.) will be going over history of diving in the NW. Bill has been in the Scuba business for a long time, done some incredible diving and been part of some great history. He's written a fun book. Maybe he'll bring some for sale and autographing. Well worth the trip to the meeting. Here's a small bio off his website: [http://www.psicylinders.com/about] [Bill High is President of PSI, Inc., a training company for inspectors of high pressure cylinders. Located near Seattle, Washington, he began training cylinder inspectors in 1983 and set the SCUBA/SCBA industry standard for technical inspections. Presently Bill is the senior consultant to more than 70 cylinder inspector trainers in North America and at numerous international locations. Bill is a consultant to the NASA Neutral Buoyancy Laboratory. Trained as a marine scientist, Bill worked for more than 37 years in the marine science field using scuba and advanced diving systems as essential research tools. In the late 1950's and early 1960's Bill introduced and promoted diving to numerous marine science agencies that had not yet learned of the merits and value of scuba as a research tool. He served as the national diving officer for both the US Bureau of Commercial Fisheries and the National Marine Fisheries Service as well as NOAA's first National Diving Coordinator. Bill wrote the first scientific diving regulations for each agency. Bill led 4 first mission saturation scientific diving programs (Tektite, Hydrolab, Edalhab, and Helgoland) and directed 5 major deep submersible research expeditions in the Pacific Northwest and Alaska. He served as a diving consultant to the United Nations.

SMALL CHANGE OF PLAN- SINCE NO ONE HAS RSVP'D I AM NOT MEETING AT THE PARKING LOT BUT PROCEEDING DIRECTLY TO THE FERRY FOR A 9:30AM SAILING. All diver dive. Last day to a long Thanksgiving weekend, and the first dive in the final month of 2013. The water temperature is dropping, the kelp is long gone, and all that remains are the hard core residents; rock fish, rat fish, possibly a few GPO, and some hopeful wolf eels. Sunrise is at 7:37am. No facilities at this site so be sure to make your pit stop before you arrive. Meet time is 9:30am, splash at 10:30am.

column2: South Sound AM Current Drift Dive
column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.0E > 9:30AM > 2.9F; Sunrise @ 7:30AM A DIW Drift. We get in at the south entrance, fin out to South Bay (in current), and drift along to the north exit. Currents are moderate but this is the most exposed of the DIW dive profile options. Experience going south, especially all the way to South Bay from the north is highly desirable. If you have some experience on DIW, and feel comfortable in current (there will be current, this is a drift dive), then this is one to try out. Meet time is 7:15AM, splash at 8 - 8:15am. Give yourself a little extra time for moving cars and walking back to the dive entrance. Note: For folks not up for the long swim and the drift this is a decent one for doing the North drift and back dive. If someone wants to co-host this end of the dive it would be a decent one for DIW new divers. No facilities in a residential neighborhood. Carpooling recommended. Fritz Merkel 206-525-0736. 206-370-4720-cell
Last scheduled trip to the "Yard" in 2013. Make it a good one! Meet time is 6:30, splash at about 7:15p. Sunset is at 4:22p so be sure to bring primary, backup and tank light for your adventure.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: 2.1E > 5:06pm > 1.8F; Sunset 4:27PM This is a first for me. so probably for the Club, a DIW night drift. We get in at the south entrance in the evening, fin out to South Bay (in current), and drift along to the north exit at night. Currents are low but the highly exposed nature of this dive, the long swim in current, and the complication of finding the wall and the appropriate exit at night on a drift make this *ADVANCED FOR EXPERIENCED DIW DIVERS.....ONLY! No exceptions. If you've never done the drift before it's highly desirable you have a half dozen dives with several of them going south so you are familiar with the terrain. It WILL look different in the dark. If you aren't sure....talk to me. Or check out Nov. 30. Meet time is 3PM, splash at 4pm. Give yourself a little extra time for moving cars and walking back to the dive entrance. No facilities in a residential neighborhood. Carpooling recommended. Night time so good neighborhood manners are requested. Fritz Merkel 206-525-0736. 206-370-4720-cell

We'll be diving the Point Hudson jetty. This is a very light current day so there should be no current issues. Easy entry, outdoor shower and washrooms available. In the Narrows there's always the possibility of unexpected difficult current. Meet time is 2:45pm, splash ~3:45 pm. No facilities in a residential neighborhood. Carpooling recommended. column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Jim Trask, President of the Washington Scuba Alliance, will be our guest at this meeting. WSA's mission is to create more access to shore diving, and protect offshore sites by placing mooring buoys nearby. Come learn about what WSA has been working on in 2013, and what is planned for 2014!

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: 3.3 > 1.5 before Ebb. Skill level intermediate, due to possible current and long hike. If you like Day Island Wall, you'll like this dive; this shore dive offers an abundance of GPO and wolf eels on any given day. Long decline down to the water creates a long hike back up afterwards. Your reward is one of the best dives in the sound. Meet time at 10:30, splash at 11:30am. Currents look very good for this day. This is Sunrise however, so be aware that there is almost always some current and it can be unpredictable. The portapoti was back last time we were here. But you might want to stop in Gig Harbor before the dive just in case.

column2: La Paz, BC Whale Sharks, Sea Lions, & Marine Life
column4: E/ 5 de Febrero y Navarro | Colonia El Manglito · La Paz, BCS
column5: La Paz Whale Sharks, Sea Lions, & Marine Life October 19 - 26, 2013. Trip estimate is $1,100 We head back to La Paz, Baja California to snorkel with whale sharks, dive with sea lion, and check out eel, bleenies, jaw fish, and the other marine life the area has to offer. Lodging will be with Posada Luna Sol, diving with Buceo Carey, and whale shark outings with Mar y Aventuras. Price includes lodging, park permits, 3 tank dives on SCUBA days, lunch on diving days, and snorkeling with whale sharks from 8:30 AM to 1:00 PM on whale shark days. Does not include transportation to La Paz. Objectives: Whale sharks, sea lion, bleenies, eel, jaw fish.

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: All diver dive. Redondo always makes for a safe dive; Good facilities, easy parking, easy shore entry. Meet time 10, splash at 11am.

Between Fidalgo Head and Burrows Island: 2.1F>2:30p>0.5E. Should be a reliable exchange. Meet time 1:00p, splash about 2:00pm.This is a current dive with a long 200 yard swim to the drop. Timed right you get a boost out and back. It starts shallow on a steep rock face covered with invertebrate life, the highlight of this dive. When it's good it's very pretty indeed with lots of sea cucumbers and sponges. This is a place to see occasional candy stripe shrimp and PS King Crabs if you have good eyes and are lucky. As you travel out it gets deeper to ~ 95 feet. No need to go deeper if you don't want to. No facilities on site, stop at Anacortes or Wa Park before you arrive. We have been using 'weed side' parking for several years. Building going on up there may have compromised the parking. It's a 90 minute drive from north Seattle. Because of both these factors carpooling is strongly recommended. We usually hit up the Brown Lantern in town after the dive for grub. I have recently heard that the bowling alley (of all places) has some good food. Anyone been there?
Copy Meetup

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: 5 went

So, Here's the Friday Night update: 1) Drivers, be sure you have your 'Discover Pass' or be prepared to buy a $10.00 parking ticket @ the kiosk @ the PPSP parking lot, which is about 1/4 mile above the dive site access point. 2) The Map which is appended to this meetup is pretty good; However, the red balloon with the "A" within it, marking the park, is too far north. Notice that Franklin Lane ends near the beach. THAT's where we're going. We can offload our gear within 200 feet of the beach, then park up above in the lot... 3) If you are coming from the Keystone Ferry, follow Hi 525 south and turn right at the traffic light onto Cultus Bay Road. From the Clinton Ferry, Take a left onto Campbell Rd, then left again onto Cultus Bay Road to cut several unnecessary miles off of your drive. This road becomes Possession Point Road at the 90 degree left curve at the top (north) end of Cultus Bay... Proceed east and PP Road will turn 90 degrees to the right (south) at the intersection with Brockman, (which you will be on if you continue straight ahead... DON'T go there!) Follow PP Road south and you will arrive at a 180 degree switchback... Proceed ahead and you will arrive at Franklin Lane, AND the entrance to Possession Point COUNTY Park. Watch the signs carefully and take Franklin, which is the FIRST right turn you can make after the switchback... Keep to the right and you will arrive at the end of the road where the STATE PARK parking lot is located... This is where you will park AFTER you continue on past the sign that states "Authorized vehicles only beyond this point"... You'll wind down a narrow lane and arrive at the Ranger's white house... take the driveway to the right toward the wood shed... The driveway ends there and this is where you will off load your gear... 4) The "dive gate" actually opens at about 7:30 AM at the ebb slack; so, if you are familiar with this site and want an early start, take the 6:00 or 6:30 ferry from Mukelteo and you can be diving by 7:30 or 8:00... That's not for me! I'll be on the 9:00 Boat and diving by 10:30- 11:00. The flood slack occurs at about 5:30, so you'll want to be wrapped up by 5:00 or so... 5) 2 dives are practical during that time frame... or you can do one and then hang out and explore this little gem of a park... 6) I'll be available to new divers/ divers new to the area for a pre-dive orientation and will act as a guide on the first dive for any who might be interested in that opportunity... 7) New divers: remember that good buoyancy control is important here: please try not to touch the vertical clay walls over much; you might dislodge a rock that could hit a diver below you... 8) Photographers, explorers, "funsters"; You're gonna love this dive! Fabulous geology & sea life on display; be sure to explore all of the nooks and crannies that are here... 9) There is one plastic commode on site near the beach and more commodious restrooms at the adjoining county park (at that previously mentioned intersection after the switchback) 10) Bring a picnic as the nearest place to find food is back at Clinton 11) I will have 1 10x10 shade structure; but you might want to bring your own, and some camp chairs too... C-U All There & be prepared for big time Fun Gene C
Organizer tools

column4: Redondo Beach Dr. S. & Redondo Way S. · Federal Way, WA
column5: ( Saltwater SP moved to Redondo - Three large fingers of rocky artificial reef assembled in 2009 makes a home for many fish and other critters. I dove this early in the year where there were several egg nests of lingcod. Slack is at 8:48 am, but gates open at 8am. Meet at 8:00am, but try to have some portions of your gear assembled ahead of time to reduce parking lot suit-up time. Expect a surface swim/walk to drop down. Shallow reefs at appx 20-50ft. Deeper reefs out to 85ft.) meet up at 7:30am. splash at 8:15am

Cove 3 has a lot to offer. On a low tide it might be considered a shallow dive but when the sun is out it is also a photographer's dive. The old ferry terminal is over a 100 years old and it does on occasion reveal it's secrets. Meet at 8, splash at 9am.

Divers needed!!! Edmonds Discovery Programs Ranger-Naturalists and Beach Docents present a free evening of fun at Marina Beach! Wading pools are set up and divers retrieve creatures from the sound for all the kids and their parents to see and touch. The naturalists are there to to talk to those present about the critters and answer any questions. This is a great way to help kids and adults that don't dive become more aware of some of the amazing creatures that live in the Sound. Marker Buoy divers have been critical contributors to this event the last several years. We'll need at least 6 divers. Randy Williams will again be doing a live video feed. So along with the critter retrieval, Randy will also need some diver help. If you want to have a rewarding and very fun time, sign up here on Meetup. For more details contact Randy Williams (206) 387-6749.

column2: Rich Passage dive and planning BBQ
column4: 6074 Wynn Jones Rd E · PORT ORCHARD, WA
column5: NOTE: CHANGE OF PLAN - SEE BELOW Come on out to Doug and Karin's place for a dive and a potluck BBQ dive planning party. Sorry but there is a change of plans. We took the boat over to check the site today and my engine is overheating so we won't be able to do a boat dive on Sunday. But we can still go diving!! We will lead a dive out front of our house with a splash time of 10:15am. This means catching the earlier 8:35am ferry from (http://www.wsdot.com/Ferries/Schedule/ScheduleDetail.aspx?tripdate=20130616&departingterm=9&arrivingterm=20&roundtrip=true) Fauntleroy (http://www.wsdot.com/Ferries/Schedule/ScheduleDetail.aspx?tripdate=20130616&departingterm=9&arrivingterm=20&roundtrip=true). This will be a nice easy dive with some light current. We have three resident octopus right out front and while this dive is less fishy, there is still lots to see as we work our way up to Point Glover fingers. Slack is about 11:00am so we definitely want to be in the water no later than 10:30am - but aim for 10:15am. Then after the dive we'll have a BBQ. Bring your favorite food and drink. Lawn chairs are also a great idea. If you just coming for the planning party / BBQ come anytime and just hang out. Non-divers are welcome. There's lots of room to lounge outside or down at the beach. Or take a kayak out for a paddle. Parking is limited so car pooling is recommended. The ferry schedule can be found here (http://www.wsdot.com/Ferries/Schedule/ScheduleDetail.aspx?tripdate=20130616&departingterm=9&arrivingterm=20&roundtrip=true). If you need to reach us or get lost, my cell phone is 425-246-6499. If you itching for a second dive, a wild back and forth drift dive out front is possible starting at 4:45pm.

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: TOPIC: Giovannina Souers and Woody Mosespresent highlights of volunteering for marine conservation projects as they traveled around the world In February and March of 2012, Giovannina Souers (Broadening Participation Coordinator, Seattle Aquarium) and Woody Moses (Biology Professor, Highline Community College) had the good fortune to help with coral reef surveys on Australia's Great Barrier Reef and in several marine protected areas (MPAs) in the Philippines. Come learn how these spectacular ecosystems are being managed, the threats they face and the choices being made to help save them for future generations.

column4: 10015 Sunrise Beach Dr NW · Gig Harbor, WA
column5: Skill level intermediate, due to possible current and long hike. If you like Day Island Wall, you'll like this dive; this shore dive offers an abundance of GPO and wolf eels on any given day. Long decline down to the water creates a long hike back up afterwards. Your reward is one of the best dives in the sound. Meet time at 11:00, splash at 11:50pm. Currents look very good for this day. This is Sunrise however, so be aware that there is almost always some current and it can be unpredictable. The portapoti that use to be available seems to be permanently gone. Best to stop in Gig Harbor before you arrive.

column2: Advance Current Dive - The big one!
column4: Oak Harbor, WA · Oak Harbor, WA
column5: 3.7F > 10:47 >5.2E - Splash about 10-20-10:30 AM. This meets criteria to be able to dive. This is just about the most advanced shore dive we have in the Sound. When it's good, it's beautiful. Lot of inverts and fish. Dramatic canyon rock walls. Dangers are current, current, current (up wellings, down wellings), poor viz (Skagit River) and fishing line.Consider this a serious dive. Give yourself 1 1/2 hours from N. Seattle to the North Beach Day use area. There is plenty of parking and restrooms on site. It's a couple hundred yard carry to the beach. From there the water is right in front of you and you are looking up at the bridge. Take a look at the picture on the Meetup home page. That's the splash area with MBDC divers and a split picture (Jan Kocian) of the terrain you'll see below. Discover Pass or paid parking required. Fritz

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Our guest is Chris Bassett, a PhD candidate in the Mechanical Engineering Department and Applied Physics Lab at the University of Washington. His academic interests include passive acoustics studies to quantify underwater ambient noise, the environmental impacts of anthropogenic noise in the ocean, marine renewable energy, and the use of acoustics in oceanographic studies. The presentation will focus how scientists measure and discuss sound, how sound can be used to study the ocean, what sources of sound exist in the ocean, and why noise in the ocean matters. To do this I will focus on data and results from studies in Puget Sound. Following the presentation he will be happy to (try) answer any questions you have.
Organizer tools

Trip cost is $2,100, with Anacortes Diving. Several Marker Buoy’s already signed up. Travel to the far North end of Vancouver Island to Port Hardy. This is where Captain Bill will pick us up for the 10 mile boat ride through the wilds of Queen Charlotte Strait and take us to Hurst Island, where God's Pocket Resort is located. God's Pocket Resort is the only resident here nestled in a quiet cove off of Christie Passage. The resort is about a 5 minute boat ride from the famous Browning Wall, the most requested dive site in the area. Other incredible dives in the area are Barry Islet, Dillon Rock, Hunt Rock and Nakwakto Rapids to name a few. Each area is rich in colorful marine life from Wolf eels, Octopus, huge Lingcod, Clown Shrimp, Purple Ringed Top Snails, Grunt Sculpins, Sea lions and more nudibranchs than you can name. Contact: Dan Clements

column5: Sign up for Sunday Table. When you RSVP for a table slot please note your time in the Comments section. If you have a buddy add their name. I'll move them into this notification as they come in.Thanks for the help 10-12: Andrea Naert + Scott 12-2: Justin McClellan, Doug Miller, Karin Fletcher 2-4: Fritz and Joyce Please consider also doing some time as a volunteer for Expo. It takes 50 hours of volunteer time to pay for a table. http://www.divenewsnetwork.com/expo/index.php/volunteer

Dive the spectacular, frigid waters of Browning Pass from God's Pocket Resort! Accessible only by boat, it ís a secluded wilderness spot surrounded by forested islands and the waterways of the Queen Charlotte Strait. A visit to God's Pocket provides not only spectacular cold water diving, but also an opportunity for kayaking, hiking, shore walks, swimming with dolphins, and whale watching. The cost : $1256.23 per person all taxes included. What it doesn't include is transportation to and from Port Hardy, nor tip. If you're interested, send me a non-refundable deposit for $350.00 Please make checks out to God's Pocket Resort. The balance of $906.23 will be due by the first week of February 2013. This is a 5 day / 4 night package (3 full days of diving) Pick up Saturday, 4/21 in Port Hardy, BC; Dive 4/22, 4/23 & 4/24;Drop off at Port Hardy on 4/25 am For each person reserving a spot, either send a check of $350 to Katie or directly to God’s Pocket: info@godspocket.com Katie Morgan 3446 Walnut Ave SW Seattle, WA 98116 Balance will be due Feb 15th, 2013. Package Includes: “Hurst Isle” boat ride to and from God’s Pocket Resort from and to Port Hardy Meals, Baked Goods, and hot and cold drinks. (They do not provide sodas, alcohol or “junk” food. You can purchase these in Port Hardy and you are welcome to bring your own. Accommodation and Housekeeping Service All linens and towels Up to 3 boat dives per diving day Air fills Aluminum 80 tanks and steel 85 tank Weights and Belts Nitrox – $10.50 CDN plus taxes per fill for 85 cu/ft tanks. Larger tanks are $.13 per cu/ft. ie…100 cu/ft tank would cost $13.00 CND plus taxes per fill Argon – $20 CDN plus taxes per person for their charter BEFORE YOU COME – PLEASE make sure your equipment is serviced and in good working condition. They have a limited “save the dive” kit and Port Hardy is an expensive boat ride away. IMPORTANT: They do require proof of certification (a “C” card) from all divers, or they can’t dive you. No exceptions. More questions? Visit: http://www.godspocket.com or email me at lifeexhibits@gmail.com

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: TOPIC: Diving to the Ends of the Earth: Have you ever wondered what it is like to dive and travel to the polar regions? In this presentation, Faith will take you to the Antarctica Peninsula as well as the island of Spitsbergen well above the Arctic Circle. The underwater and above water images will amaze you and give a taste of the majesty of our poles.' Faith Ortins has been the VP of Sales for Diving Unlimited International for the past 11 years. Before that she lived in Boston, MA where she became known as a technical diver, dive store owner, dive charter operator and expedition leader. With over 3500 dives around the world, she successfully completed her goal of diving in all 5 oceans and off of all 7 continents last year.

Still looking for those eggs the bunny left behind? Perhaps they were dumped into Puget Sound and your job is to find them, or not. Large ebb exchange may create slight current. column2: CANCEL: Dive on the W Seattle Fish Reef
column5: HI Divers! Well, Lads, I am sad to say that the weather gods do not want us to do this dive tomorrow. Let's save it for a time when wind and waves abate adequately. If anyone NEEDS to dive tomorrow, we can throw in with the gang @ Redondo... Gene The weather forecast is not looking good for Saturday , with SSW winds to 16Kt predicted. That means waves; lots of 'em... Sunday looks much better right now. My preference is to stick with Lowman Beach, but we could switch to Blakely Rocks if the wind sticks around on Sunday... Note that we'll meet a little later on Sunday, as the slack is about 3:30PM. Let me know your preferences... Gene This dive is advanced due to the distance over open water and the large tide exchange. There will be current, and divers must have already demonstrated to me their ability to: right a capsized boat Manage their gear so as not to lose it & be able to load it back in your boat (by the way, your integrated weight BC MUST float without you in it!) exit & re-enter the boat, don & doff their gear in the water manage to dive while towing their boat Right now, I'm expecting rain. If it turns out that Sunday looks like better weather, I might change to that. Should know a lot more by Thursday evening... Standby! IF the wind comes up (over 7 kt) This little exercise will be cancelled. Big choppy waves while diving from kayaks is not a good combination Gene Beautiful anemone covered artificial boulder reef with LOT's of fish to see: We'll paddle our kayaks from Lowman Beach North on the ebb tide to the site; dive through the slack (about 3:00 PM) & return on the flood to the park...

column2: Hold a kayak diving / training clinic
column3: Warren G. Magnuson Park Boat Launch
column5: NEW:3/8/13 So, we'll meet as planned, but @ 0945... Dave; Please meet me at 0930 at 6230 33rd Ave NE and we'll load a kayak onto your vehicle- I have all of the tie downs and foam cradle blocks we'll need; Reminder: Bring (if you have them): line reel, 'dog bone' clips 2 or 4 long bungies + your 'regular dive gear. Josh may not make it as he's reported in with a cold headed his way. CU 2-morrow! G 3/3/13 I will provide 2 boats ( and possibly 3) & Kimber can bring one. (Yes?) However, I no longer have a vehicle that can transport 2-3 Boats! I live in Lake Hills, Bellevue, and this is where my kayaks reside as well. Do any eager prospective kayak divers have a pickup and can meet with me to transport boats? By the way, once you have your kayak dive skills honed, I have some EXQUISITE dives along the south shore of Whidbey Is. that you'll enjoy... and these are sites that virtually no-one knows of (other than ME!) Gene 0900-1:00pm @ Magnussun Park, Picnic shelter just south of the boat launch. Kimber; Please bring the Ocean Kayak you are storing for Mike; I may require help transporting one of my two O. K.s as I no longer have my Jeep. Not sure I can stack 2 on top of my Subaru. That's the experiment I'm about to conduct. There's a cool, little known dive site just off shore of the training area where we'll dive following the practice drills. Please bring line, stout bungies and, if you have them, a line reel & double ended "dog bone" clasps. These are very useful for this method of diving as you equipment will be either clipped to the boat, or worn by you at all times. You'll learn how to simplify & secure your gear, roll & recover, dive from & remount your kayak...

column2: Monthly club meeting at Sunset Hill Community Club - Seattle
column5: Come out to the monthly Marker Buoy Dive Club meeting in Seattle. Each meeting we welcome new members, talk about old dives / new dives and feature a guest speaker. Our guest speaker this month will be our very own Jim Boon. He is going to share some photos from his October 2012 trip to La Paz. After looking at the photos, Jim will select one of the 'RAW' photos and move it through the editing process, taking it to a finished photo suitable for publication. Jim's emphasis is to remove the mystery of editing a photo using basic software. He will talk about subject, lighting and composition: the 'big three' elements of making a successful image. This will move pretty fast and be a very iterative process so everyone can participate.

Meetup does not act like Yahoo did for ongoing discussions. The discussion placed in the [Discussion] section do NOT get automatically emailed to everyone immediately. It's more like a bulletin board where you have to go in and read them. I'm making this a "Meetup" with a date of Jan. 31 so it will act a lot more like Yahoo while we go through this transition. It's just a different way to use a new communitation tool we have to learn.

column4: Day Island Blvd. W. 19 St. SW (cross Street) · Tacoma, WA
column5: Seattle Aquarium Annual GPO Census: Medium-large current day. DIW experience would be good for this one but not the big day I thought. 3.2F > 10:47 slack > 3.2E - South Narrows (interpreted) 2.6F > 11:03 > 2.9E - N. Narrows (true current station) Splash ~ 9:15. Meet 8:15 - 8:20 AM. I had the original current data all wrong. Jeff caught it-see exchange below. Good going.
